headline: Great place to work, but too many people leaving
pros: The working environment is amazing. People are really nice. As a junior engineer, I do receive a lot of guidance and get many great opportunities to grow. They really put your personal interests first. The managers will often ask what I enjoy working on and assign something similar or something that can lead me to the next step.
cons: But ever since the selling last year, way too many people had left. It doesn't feel nice when so many people are leaving and no new people coming in. I don't feel the same energy I felt a year ago.

headline: Rusted on misogyny, bullying gets a pass
pros: Nice office, smart employees, plenty of talented workers at sub-management level, pay can be competitive at some levels
cons:
Short staffed, constant blocks to hiring or promoting, while women can succeed to some extent overall the culture is very male driven especially at the upper management level. Only women who act very typically ‘masculine’ are treated with respect. Womens ideas get taken and repackaged as mens ideas. Lots of uncertainty about future of the business. Constant change management. Bullying very common. Staff seem
Overworked and stressed. Pressure to return to office even though most ppl prefer wfh.

headline: Pretty perfect for 2 year stint
pros:
AWS based and happy to make use of different services/no penny pinching

Large projects but high impact

Good WLB, low/no stress

Yearly Cash reward that vests over 4 years which is called MEP, that is ~10% of salary.

Top of the line MacBook, iPhone/Samsung w/o bossware

Paid on call

Good culture, good people to work with

No pressure WFH arrangement for the forseeable future
cons:
Cash reward over 4 years used to be over 3 years than pre sale to Apollo

Typical small CoL raise, If you're happy with your offer then expect it to stay as your salary for the 2 years

Slow career progression, low to average salaries. Appears to be about 50% extra time to promotions in comparison to other companies, lots of people appear to be below their correct CL but happy with the company so going nowhere (in Ireland, at low to mid ranks)

Other side of the coin is that after the sale, seems lots of higher up people abroad are leaving which is a bit worrying!

Occasional late work/meeting as most are American though pretty rare and they're generally very accomodating

Food perk is gone

There are also many brands under the umbrella that claim to represent or stand for diversity and yet have little to no people of color on their teams. It is discouraging and troubling to see as more people leave teams in droves because white employees are promoted while others are taught to wait their turn.

The company is understaffing and current teams are overloaded of work and nobody has really time for you to explain things you really need. I was told differently so I took the job. I wouldn't suggest this company to a friend. I'm very disappointed. Very tense feeling inside as the company was acquired recently and nobody knows what is going to happen. People are leaving.

headline: Work hard, play hard. People are just awesome
pros:
I honestly loved working for Verizon Media. I believe the old Yahoo people are just awesome. I was happy with my worklife balance. Maybe salary isn't as high as other tech companies but I always left the office at the time I was expected to, we had great parties, good fun and my manager was just awesome, she's the best manager I had.
I had the time of my life and I was truly happy there. The gave us a mobile phone (that I used as if it was mine) and free food
cons: Working from home (pre-covd) was not always supported, also coving for holidays/xmas was always a mess. Some executive decision were despicable, but at the end of the day it's their decision and they might have a broader view

headline: Great colleagues, horrible management
pros: The workforce is young, and most people that are not in management are easy to get along with. The benefits are great, and the environment, for the most part, is casual.
cons: Management (specifically at In The Know) is horrible, and its incompetence is reflected in the high turnover within a year (most people who left were people of color). There is a real lack of attention paid to concerns over racism, and the HR team frequently gaslights people of color into thinking that no instance of racism at the office has occurred. Despite attempting to boast a "diverse" workforce, managers at In The Know are mostly white and have been known to say racially insensitive things or flat-out racist things (such as telling several Black workers that they are "benchwarmers," loudly questioning why "Black" should be capitalized, wondering aloud why LGBTQIA+ "has so many letters," etc.). Promotions are mostly given to white employees, and most BIPOC employees are often relegated to mundane tasks despite consistently working overtime. Managers on the team also give conflicting instructions but expect team members to meet unrealistic goals.

headline: Staying Optimistic
pros: Verizon Media is a progressive company with expectations of individually driven employees. Everything is self-help. It is a great environment for subject matter experts who can self manage. The company is big on communications. There is a regular cadence of weekly, monthly and quarterly meetings with executives. Work-from-home has been an added benefit during COVID, and the vast majority of my colleagues adapted quickly to this home-is-work "normal". I have enjoyed a lot of opportunities, work flexibility and great benefits under Verizon, that I am not sure are available anywhere else.
cons: Poaching. What happens when a company has a lot of high performing, subject matter experts that are self motivating and wake up with big ideas? They get recruited. It's great that someone is high-value and Verizon Media is made up of great employees, but turnover is tough even when a colleague leaves for a great opportunity. If you can't adapt and help train people, Verizon Media is going to be frustrating. The Apollo buyout is a disruption, and it is TBD what the positives and negatives are of relaunching as Yahoo. The only thing we know for sure is, our great Verizon Wireless discount will go away at some point.

headline: A Pretty Solid Place To Work
pros:
Super intelligent people that are very team oriented. 
A lot of them are "lifers" meaning they've been there 10+ years, which means either they wanna be there or they're secure. Regardless, I'm pro-security and pro-wanting to be there.
Compensation's generally respectable depending on your IC (Individual Contributor) level
Work Life Balance is pretty good too. Most people left between 4 and 6:30pm Mondays - Thursdays but on Fridays people left earlier.
cons:
Clients are awesome but as is the case with any role in digital advertising, they can be either annoying or completely radio silent. Not sure what your cup of tea is but yeah I've only seen two extremes.
Though they promote moving around within the company, it takes a minute to move around within the company. 
Many deserving candidates get passed up for managerial positions every promotion cycle which is the case when everyone's smart and good at their job.

headline: Great career launch pad, Verizon name carries weight
pros:
• Many areas of opportunity to contribute and grow outside of your main role
• Great benefits, 401k matching, flexible time off, ability to travel to visit teams
• Extremely well developed diversity & inclusion efforts 
• The Verizon name carries real weight in the digital media, advertising and tech space. Putting in time really helps your resume/LinkedIn when looking for your next gig.
cons:
• Verizon Media went through years of acquisitions and reorgs that slowed progress and caused infernal confusion. Went through multiple new managers and upper management in 5 years. Company is just now coming off of the bumpy trend. 
• Recent selloffs of brands and shuttering legacy products impacted morale
• Some of the most hard working people are here, but also some people are just here for a check. Definitely have to navigate individual work ethics.

headline: Incredible place to work, unsure of future direction
pros:
* Welcoming environment with some very intelligent individuals.
* Work with cutting edge technology, solving complex problems with scale rivaling well known tech giants.
* Personally, I am very happy I worked there. My experience there skyrocketed my professional development and helped me develop my skills as a programmer faster than my peers at other companies.
cons:
* Pay is not as competitive as other Bay Area companies
* After being bought out by Verizon it feels like the direction of the company is uncertain. It felt like Verizon did not respect the Verizon Media Group organization, to the point of almost regretting buying them out. It seems like Verizon is more interested in recouping the money spent during the buyout quickly rather than leveraging and maintaining talent and the strong tech infrastructure Yahoo developed.

headline: Good work/life balance
pros:
I've been at Verizon Media and its various incarnations for about nine years. Considering other places I've worked, I think I've had the best work/life balance here. At other jobs, I had worked seven days a week regularly and that rarely happens here. I think the company at least tries to show that they value their employees. I think total compensation is fairly good, but probably not as good as FAANG.

The 401K is the best I have ever had.
cons: Promotional opportunities seem non-existent. People seem to leave because of lack of opportunity.

headline: Hot mess of a company but great benefits
pros: This place is great for someone looking for strong compensation and benefits, stability. If you work hard, you will be rewarded. There's definitely upward mobility. But for some, the BS just won't outweigh the benefits. For others, it does. Definitely just depends on what you're looking for and what team you're on. Ultimately I would say Verizon Media is a great launchpad for your career, because it's a huge recognizable brand, and you can make an impact.
cons: Amalgamated strategy due to turnover and recent mergers. Direction changes all the time. Frequently asked to drop everything and execute on leaderships' asks that clearly are purely optical and drive no real impact or value. A lot of people from the Yahoo side have been there for 15+ years and quite frankly they are carrying a lot of dead weight. On the AOL side you have a lot of young, inexperienced managers with big egos who just know how to play the game.

headline: This is how the past year has been
pros: Good base pay and transferring for a different department
cons:
A union that doesn’t do anything that tries to tell you who to vote for. Verbal abuse from customers, no after call work, nitpicking and micromanaging. Forced overtime and will change your schedule while on your vacation without telling you. Having to sell to billing customers and such a tiny bonus it doesn’t even make a difference. No after all work. They give you 30 min a few times a week and tell you to use it  on callbacks so your basically strapped to a desk the entire shift with back to back calls. Only the favorites with family members get in the sales queue and they brag about getting bonuses and perks that you can never get even though your getting micromanaged to death dealing with calls other people would rather not have. 2 months of role playing training even when you come from a sales back ground and nothing to do with your actual job of customer service, tech support or retention. Angry customers that want a sup and sups won’t take the call. No one wants to do their job. No structure to training or anything. It’s a big mess. Threats while in training like get a doctors note or they’ll show up at your door to make sure your actually sick and other reps in building accused people in training class of making a mess in the bathroom. Just all together one of the most crazy atmospheres I’ve ever encountered. I’ll either transfer somewhere else when I can find a actual sales job where the working conditions aren’t as bad.
Also if you have a disability forget about hr or anything else. I was told in training I had to wait until out of training for my back problems and I don’t trust anyone enough to talk to about their chairs. You can’t talk to HR. I don’t know who these people are? The fact that I can never get out of my chair the whole shift and how bad the chairs where have caused constant back pain.

headline: Learn, then leave
pros:
Great salary and benefits
A wide array of tech to learn about
Backing by Verizon allows for deep pockets - R&D is possible...sometimes.

I WOULD recommend this company if you are interested in the following:
*Resume fodder - having a few years of experience with a big company like Verizon is attractive to future employers.

*Salary - the salary is good and has often been described as Golden Handcuffs. You'll get paid well, but you'll find yourself in a difficult position to transition out. This is very commonly discussed among employees. Silver lining of a potentially unsatisfying job is the stability of the salary. It's a double edge sword because some people have trouble tearing free and end up hating their job for years.

*Opportunity to Learn - Learn, learn, learn. Watch what management is doing and note what they are doing wrong, what results, and be diligent to consider how things could have been done better. This will prep you for your future when you leave and can offer experience to other companies of what NOT to do. There are a lot of teams, a lot of tech, a lot of repos, etc - there is no lacking of opportunity to grow your skill set...in preparation of leaving for a job that will allow for promotions and advancement.
cons:
Poor leadership

Little to no possibility for advancement/promotion

Constant job freezes - even after offers have been made

Cultural grab bag - merging with AOL and Yahoo! caused chaos that probably won't 
ever go away.

Little to no accountability for personal contributions - some people don't seem to do anything but are still there for years.

No commitment from leadership - every response is vague, every roadmap is flimsy, you simply won't get a manager to commit to an initiative. As a result every project gets scope creep, every planning gets interrupted within a week, etc. May as well just grab a raffle ticket to decide what you work on every morning.

I would NOT recommend this company if you are interested in the following:
*Career Advancement - simply put, aside from a few political maneuverings you won't likely get an opportunity to even make a case for your promotion. The promotion process requires approval from management 4, 5, or even 6+ levels above you. They have no idea who you are or what you do. If they haven't heard your name and what you've done you have next to no chance. It becomes a mad scramble to climb over each other in a fight for political recognition. Very toxic.

*Discipline & Order - Everyone does better when they are disciplined. Some jobs require it, and make you a better person because of it. This job is NOT that job. You will have every opportunity to drag your feet and make excuses why something wasn't able to get done. Never any push back. If you want to join a team to GROW and become a BETTER person then don't join this company.

cons:
Tech-bro culture with toxic managers allowed to run rampant— not as bad as a lot of Sydney newsrooms but still makes for very low morale among exhausted staff in content division. 
Very intense shifts with no breaks, everyone eats at their desks. 
Emotional burnout very common. Workforce becoming increasingly casualised in order to cut corners and exploit young (mostly female) content makers. Absolutely no work-life balance.

* Pay is not competitive with other software companies in the Bay Area. No stocks offered.
* Verizon has removed all of the Yahoo perks / Yahoo-esque qualities and created a bland company with no culture and no company pride.

headline: Decent so far
pros:
Free food, free gym, apple products. I’m a contractor right now but even for contractors, it’s nice. My team is great and very chill which I love compared to my previous job. Our team is small and mighty so there’s a lot of work to be done so it’s comforting that they need me. Reading the reviews, it just seems like some teams are worse than others. I’ve only been here for less than a month so we’ll see if this trend stays positive.

TLDR:
-Free food
-Free Gym
-Apple products
-Open space environment 
-You can bring any guest over to have bfast/lunch
-Free Barista coffee

Honestly, if you take away the free stuff, half the people would leave.
cons: It’s unclear what the future is for the company. We don’t know if half of us are keeping jobs so it’s scary for some people.

headline: Wildly Political Environment
pros: Great perks, fun culture, lots of challenges, always learning, great people.
cons: The culture was so political. Legacy employees are so deeply entrenched; they drive the machine. If you are new to the company, watch your back.  If you inadvertently step on the toes of a legacy employee, your career at Yahoo could be ruined.

headline: Sinking ship - stay away
pros: Food. It's absolutely lip smacking delicious. But that's probably the only good thing here.
cons:
Where do I begin? 
- Too many good for nothing managers and less doers. 
- My team had an extremely incompetent manager that had no clue on how to manage her employees. I was so overworked and unhappy.
- micromanagement
- lots of folks who'll just talk their way up by acting cool but have no substance and what's sad that it works here 
- The company itself is going down hill and employees have no real motivation
- the whole strategy is focused on regaining the Yahoo brand whereas it should be to improve their products quality
- The CEO and leadership team has no real vision but just keep talking and acting cool all the time. 
- too much beuracracy with the parent company reporting
- Braindrain - most smart folks have long left the company to go to greener pastures.
I can go on and on, but if you're reading this as a prospective candidate / employee please stay away from this hellhole.

headline: A whirlwind of chaos

cons:
No one knows who does what. Documentation is lacking for a lot of jobs. Upper management that is a holdover from the pre-buyout days tends to be competitive to the point of betrail. 

The culture is ridiculously left-leaning and as such tends to have a bias against males, and the diversity hires are not always the best choice for the job and often are a detriment to the team. 

Not enough hours in the work-day to complete all tasks, most nights are spent with a couple of hours in my home office working on a task of some sort.

headline: Good people, good products, evolving vision
pros:
Family-friendly
Flexibility in WFH when needed
Good, smart, talented people
Smart & friendly product team
Mostly supportive environment 
Good compensation & benefits 
Verizon overall has a lot going on - which is cool to see and it provides some opportunity for movement laterally. 
Really good DSP with great data capabilities 

This company has a ton of potential- the last couple years have been rough but im optimistic for its future 

Right now (2019) - the leaders are better than previous especially Iván
cons:
Constantly evolving leaders, vision, names, focus - The company doesn’t fully know what it wants to be and dispite having great product and tons of potential - it tends to sabotage itself. Hopeful that will change.

The media portion is always put first before the platforms (which may be a benefit too - depending what you work on) 

Very fast paced environment for sales & marketing. If you are the type of person that gets stuff done - you will get tons of work thrown on you, while others kind of cruise. Typical for a company this big... 

Poor work/life balance - teams are way way under-staffed with no backfills and bi-annual layoffs - so money always comes over supporting a healthy employee ratio

headline: Good experiences, terrible leadership
pros:
Verizon Media is a great place to get exposed to a lot of new things and to get new experiences. In a company as large as it, you can always find interesting projects to work on, even when the company is in shambles.

One unexpected upside to the problems the company has is they are throwing tons of incentives at top talent to keep them from leaving.
cons: Senior leadership seems to have absolutely no vision for the future of the company. They demand that you think outside the box and come up with new ways to innovate, but provide virtually no support to actually execute on those ideas. The company leadership appears too afraid to actually do anything, and as a result the company feels like it's completely paralyzed to inaction. Constant reorgs, layoffs, budget cuts, and employee turnover makes everything so much worse.

headline: Bleak and depressing place to work. Avoid at all costs.
pros:
- Good work/life balance, nice offices, decent salary, and benefits expected of a company of this size.
- Friendly and talented individual contributors
cons:
- constant fear of semiannual layoffs
- very little opportunity for promotion or intra-company moves
- salary increases beyond cost-of-living are nearly non-existent
- nearly impossible to innovate due to extreme risk aversion, despite top management's constant calls to think outside the box
- poor onboarding – you are expected to learn nearly everything on your own very quickly
- utterly incapable of/disinterested in leveraging senior employees' experience. The majority of attention goes to junior contributors and management
- questionable business practices such as the type of aggressive personal data collection that other companies scaled back on
- expect to work almost exclusively on Yahoo products. Former AOL employees have been either jettisoned or are treated like second class citizens 
- insular groups and silos galore
- inattentive HR 
- revolving door of managers who have no business working in their respective verticals

headline: AWFUL company to work for since Yahoo came on board
pros: Good pay, good work/life balance, good schedule flexibility
cons:
Horrible culture, horrible leadership as of the last year, constant layoffs.  Nobody is happy.  It's so draining to be there.  Going corporate now that VZ is overseeing.  I wouldn't recommend my worst enemy to work here.  I give the company 2 more years, tops, to survive. Run for the hills.

When Yahoo came on board is when things took a turn for the worse.  Cliques and poor culture is what makes this company so bad.  The leadership stinks, my manager (post-Yahoo acquisition) especially in particular.  I've never been treated so poorly by anyone in my life. It was sickening how terrible I was talked to.  My skills were often questioned and disregarded. Even when I was in the right and performing highly, I was wrong and not recognized by my work. My suggestions were always "welcomed", but they were never once taken into consideration or even heard.  I’ve never been so glad to leave a place in my entire life.  I’d go home feeling beaten down and useless almost every day.

headline: A horrible place to work
pros:
- Free food
- Good benefits (private healthcare, flexibility, subsidised gym)
- Beer trolley
cons:
- There was no concept of HR in it's true form at Verizon Media. There are "Business Partners", who only care about the business rather than the people who work for the business. They lack empathy and do not assist in matters that are deeply worrying to some employees. 
- There were a lot of shady decisions made here and the "Business Partners" worked alongside those senior managers to help cover it up, and present the rest of the employees with the standard business lines (which ofcourse everyone saw through). Instead of doing the right thing, which is to ensure that decision making was ethical.
- There is a massive discrimination between where you started your career (Yahoo Vs AOL). The latter meaning that your base pay is stagnant for potentially 6 years.  Any pay rise is put in to your "potential to earn as a bonus" rather than in your base pay. If you are promoted then all of that pay rise is not added to your base, and instead it's added to your "potential to earn as a bonus". The standard pay rises with inflation are also not added to your base pay either. While this may not effect any new starters at the company, I would question if you want to go and work for a business that has deep rooted discrimination issues? The effected employees have been fighting against this for nearly a year and nothing has changed. The "HR" have never listened. Neither have the senior management. There was no justice or equality.
- The promotion opportunities are extremely bleak. There has never been any "development plans" for my career progression. This shows how poor this business is with it's people management skills. 
- They do not care when they are losing their best talent. Everyone is just a number, If they can't retain talent, how do they expect to win in market against the likes of Google and Facebook.
- Unneccessary processes and projects to make people sound important internally, but with no real substance or results to drive the business upwards
- Poor senior management that did not inspire the employees

headline: Great people, questionable direction

- EXCELLENT benefits, which is to say, very competitive benefits in Silicon Valley (free meals, gym, on-site health and wellness center, great insurance, 401k matching, etc)
- Generous PTO policy: 15 -> 20 PTO days after 3 years, 6 floating holidays (you get them immediately at the beginning of the year, no slow accrual), unlimited sick days
cons:
- Retention: the company struggles with retaining this aforementioned talent
- Since the Verizon acquisition, corporate leadership feels fairly distant, and mostly interested in the sales side of the company
- Varying levels of quality and leadership across different divisions of the company

headline: It is a media firm, not a tech firm
pros:

Great place for product managers to learn advertising technology ecosystem
Work/life balance is easy to reach in most teams
Sunnyvale campus offers great amenities
cons:
Career growth opportunities are very limited
Almost zero guidance from senior management on vision or execution
Lack of large org leadership experience in some managers (most coming from acquired startups with limited process and/or people leadership experience)
General lack of ownership or unwillingness to take initiative at even senior management level (job is just a job attitude)
No established org culture (still unfinished jigsaw puzzle with disparate pieces of acquired start-ups)
Weak HR support (impacting managers more often than individual contributors)
Heavy consolidation, minimal innovation
Gradually losing its competitive edge (Amazon showing its huge presence, behind FB and Google)

headline: Hopeless Company with Mediocre Middle Layer Management
pros:
- Free food, although they've significantly cut costs after Oath was created. They got rid of all the snacks and cut down the lunch portions.
- Free cell phone & plan.
- There are still some decent co-workers from the remnants of Yahoo and AOL. But attribution is high, and all the good people are leaving rapidly.
cons:
- It's basically a mess. Their ad tech stack is so clunky and full of bugs. The leaders make stupid decisions of retrofitting existing platforms with features from legacy platforms. Why don't you just take the best features from all of them and build a brand new one from scratch?
- Not a tech driven company anymore. It's entirely a sales-dominated culture. Their motto is to just meet the "revenue goal" and throw as many features into a product as quickly as possible with little regards to software quality.
- All people do here is have meetings all day long. I don't understand how they can get anything done.
- They still keep the quarterly review process where they make you evaluate yourself and assign a score for each objective. You spend all the time writing thoughtful paragraphs, yet the manager doesn't even read them nor does he provide meaningful feedback. He only regurgitates what I wrote word for word. It's pointless. Even if you write a stellar self evaluation with solid facts, you're not going to get proper recognition for the hard work. There is zero potential for career growth.
- No more RSU issued post-Oath. The salary increase is measly and doesn't align with the rate of inflation (it's only happened once for the past four years). Effectively, we're making less over time. RSU is now only given to people who got promotions.
- No transparency on what's coming.  For example, re-orgs happened all of the sudden without prior announcements from the senior management.
- No respect for tech talents, because it's just a sales company now. They wouldn't have a clue on how to cultivate you.
- Did I mention we have all of these unproductive meetings where people just make desperate attempts to highlight achievements for the week when there really is no progress?
- High attrition. Good people are leaving left and right.
- Cost cutting on everything, including software licenses you need to do your job.

headline: Politics will save your poor performance. Be aware of the bureaucracy !
pros:
Fun culture. Best work-life balance. You won't need to work harder. 
Just be average and go to the pub after work on Thu or Fri to impress your social skills.
People used to be nice.
cons:
- bureaucracy will be exploded due to people who are scared of doing something they never have done.  They love to be stagnated, hate taking new challenges. So people love to spend their work hours to create processes which nobody really needs it. 
- If your work ethic is strict and focus on your job to do, you will find yourself out in the future how you were stupid and your hard working brings more bonus to other people who are good at politics and good talkers at the pub after work. 
Even you are good at that, your glorious days won't last long because new merge will get rid of your seniors at the end of the days.

headline: Mergers/acquisitions then multiple rounds of layoffs
pros:
Some really great co-workers/smart people in different parts of the company. Many of the employees came from strong startups that AOL or Yahoo! acquired, so there are pockets of really good people.

A lot of change in the last few years. By merging Yahoo into the fold, we improved the technical IQ of leadership, but there was a lot of business redundancy and disagreements in approach.

Work/life balance is decent for a tech company.

Some of the many layers of mediocre management have been cleared out, so that may improve things for the future.

Reasonably strong values focus, though some of it seems like fluff.
cons:
Sales-drive/biz-dev driven leadership. Weak technical leadership (this may be changing).

I've witnessed at least 6 rounds of layoffs across the company, and very little high-quality hiring. Obviously that's not a sign that the business is doing great.

When the CEO of AOL/Oath leaves within a year of forming Oath, that's not a good sign.

Arguably the worst company name in tech: Oath. It was supposed to be a new name with a stronger tech brand than AOL or Yahoo! had. The idea behind "Oath" is that every employee is supposed to come up with their own 3-word "Oath" that represents their attitude and commitment to their job.

Difficult to attract strong tech talent to AOL, Yahoo!, or "Oath".

headline: Other than free food, this place is horrible
pros: Free food and juice bar. There is a random group of Oath who attempts to keep everyone happy by throwing random parties or having yoga events. I guess they are trying to make up for all that I mentioned below. I feel bad for them because it seems like they care. But if your manager makes you work evenings or threatens to, are you really going to go to a party in the middle of the day then have to stay even later?
cons: Working nights and weekends is the culture here. Employees all looked drained and worn out. Constant change so walking down the halls I constantly hear people in random departments worry or gripe. Entire floors are empty or only have 10 people on them, its like a tech zombie apocalypse. Some managers literally act like sweat shop bosses, with threats and constant micro-management. Some of my employees remind me of indentured servants.

headline: Corporate Game of Thrones
pros: Depending on the team, there are some fantastic teammates you can work with.  Incredibly knowledgeable, helpful, and kind.  For the most part, my peer relationships here were outstanding.  The benefits and pay can be on the good end of the spectrum for the industry (sounds like this is changing though).  The ability to work with some powerful technology was also exciting.
cons: Oath is a bureaucratic mess of poor leadership and self-serving values.  Navigating the inner workings of actually getting real work done at Oath is akin to running through a rat's maze.  Every action or decision was politicized; with other teams and departments at open war with one another- to the point that normal personal relationships across "at war" departments would be scrutinized and questioned.  Straightforward decisions on how to benefit our customers were seized by upper managers in attempts to land grab or were slanted to embellish how effective that department was achieving its OKRs.  Senior Leadership was deluded to the point of insanity on ensuring that there was a constant slew of "wins" racked up each week, without calling attention to true business problems and missteps.  Whenever something DID go awry, leadership would scramble to find any person or team to throw under the bus and absolve themselves of involvement.   When asked to provide reporting of how our particular department was contributing to sales objectives, and it didn't show a positive story, I was instructed to "make it up".  Worst of all are the constant, deep layoffs that Oath has become infamous for.  Multiple times each year, hundreds of employees have been laid off, even after assurances from leadership that there is absolutely nothing to worry about.  Those laid off are often top performers who simply have become too expensive for the company.  Seeing good friends cast aside like that on a recurring basis was sad, demotivating, and created a culture of fear that was impossible to look past.  Ultimately I realized that I would never fit in a corporate culture that was fueled by maximizing individual gains at the cost of good customers and employees.

headline: Good with the potential to be great
pros: Oath is great for the relaxed environment, decent salary/benefits, and generally good co-workers. Working here is very much like college, you only get what you put in- yes you can totally skate by without putting in much effort or hours, but if you push yourself there is always someone around you can learn from.
cons: One of the worst parts about working here is you grow numb to the constant stresses. There is always something important "due yesterday". Then there is always a lurking air of uncertainty- it's not too often but it is just enough that it doesn't leave your mind, they like to do layoffs in waves without much forewarning. There is usually an eerie silence in the office for a few days afterwards, then people move on. Other smaller issues are- they want you to go to conferences and take classes, but when you submit your request there is either a budget freeze or a project that takes priority. They want you to do R&D, to learn new things, but they never formally give you time to do so... You get used to the broken promises too.

headline: It's going to take a while for the merge to settle
pros: Free food, decent benefits, global company, good people.
cons: It's going to be a bumpy ride for the people at the bottom. Because of the size of the company it takes a long time to get things done and to have an impact as an individual.

headline: Seek employment at Oath if you’re looking to get laid-off
pros: Overall the work connections you make are truly priceless. I was with AOL prior to becoming oath and later laid-off in the great purge of 2017 and the friends I’ve made who were also impacted are connections I stay in touch with to this day. The perks slightly improved by moving to a yahoo campus like free lunch and some more after-work activities but the generosity was short lived.
cons: There’s higher than usual turnover with a clear picture on who’s favored during the quarterly downsizing windows. Definitely a great place to work if you wish to fear for your job every 6 months. Complete shame that a lot of AOL directed projects were flat-out expunged following the merge but I guess that’s corporate business. A very clear message that Sunnyvale is truly the one the one calling the shots.

headline: Great Core Values and interesting commercial projects
pros: Lots of interesting project to support digital media brands.  Good compensation and flexible modern casual environment.  There used to be alot of grassroots employee-driven outlets for fun sports and activities after work, but those did drop off in the last 2 years due to downsizing in Dulles.  I still see job postings there, but I suspect that Dulles teams are at the mercy of overall future direction.  For that, I'm not quite sure how to rate the stability of the career opportunities.  Despite all this, Tim (CEO) always works hard and seems to genuinely care for employees.  It's more the luck of the draw that he has to give more opportunities to Yahoo as the latest acquisition to implement his vision, given that they are the bigger acquisition.
cons: Lots of projects and management authority given to the Yahoo side in Sunnyvale, so there are only pockets of work at the former AOL campus.  Big layoffs in the last year have definitely left alot of uncertainty with those remaining.  From what I understand, there are pending discussions as to what to do with the Dulles campus, since there are so many empty spaces.

headline: Marketing

cons: Management is very junior and clueless on today's industry technology.  All of the tech stacks are siloed making it difficult to truly know the health of the business.  There are a lot of older employees there that do not embrace change very well.  Most of the employees there are just holding on to a job and not producing much of anything.  Their systems are custom built by engineers that wouldn't be very beneficial at other companies.

headline: Opportunity to work with smart people but poor top management
pros: You get the opportunity to work with very smart and talented people at a large company with room to grow. As with any large company, a lot depends on the team you are on. I was fortunate to be on a great team that was managed like a startup within the larger company.
cons: I was at Yahoo! for 5 years. At the start things were great but the culture took a dive in the last year. This was in large part due to the fact that management encouraged internal competition causing employees to withhold ideas and information in fear others would steal the idea to reap credit. In addition, we had to deal with large egos at the top, often resulting in poor product decision. Yahoo became a top-down organization that in many ways stifled innovation and creative products.

headline: Rest and vest
pros:
- Work-life balance, flex time, WFH. If it weren't for the great work-life balance I would've left a long time ago!
- Good compensation. Not as competitive as "top" tech firms, but still above average and much more stable than startups. Not a bad place to stay for a year or two
- Catered breakfast & lunch
cons:
- Few opportunities for career advancement, which is getting worse because of uncertain business prospects
- Very hierarchical and territorial
- The vast majority of employees seem to be "resting and vesting". It's fascinating how much time is spent doing nothing (or net nothing, because we waste a year building something to only find out users hate it)
- They are cost cutting - I don't know if the pros I listed above apply to new hires

headline: Oath: Unfocused, Favoritism, Burnout, No-Growth, Political, Poor Leadership & Culture, and cannot keep its promises.
pros: - the pay can be somewhat average, depending on who you are and how well Managers/Directors like you personally
cons:
- poor work/life balance, specifically for non-Yahoo legacy employees
- rampant favoritism towards legacy Yahoo employees (non-Yahoo employees usually have upwards of 5-10x as much work as their Yahoo-counterparts, middle-senior leadership is mostly Yahoo and thus the favoritism rolls down the line from there, employee reductions always hit non-Yahoo employees first and hardest)
- 2-3 major employee reductions per year (this isn't to retain top talent, often times top talent is let go in order to retain favorite employees or to save money on salaries/benefits)
- employee reductions are used as first line tactic to hit short-term profit goals when company is performing poorly
- too many legacy systems, that are not integrated
- poor training and employee resources
- leadership changes "focus" constantly without following through with any mission they have previously slated for the company
- very few opportunities for pay increases or promotions, and again favoritism and politics will determine these rare occurrences anyways
- lack of transparency on employee reviews, promotion processes, company/staffing decisions
- because of lack of transparency on pay calculations, the gender-pay-gap is a live and well here
- HR is very poor to meet their deadlines, or communicating to employees, or responding to issues. Often HR and Leadership take the approach of gaslighting truth and blaming employees for company performance, morale, or issues
- terrible morale
- Managers/Directors are just talking mouthpieces for SVPs/VPs; employee best interest is not their function at Oath and they will not ever push back on behalf of employees
- company prioritizes money on "keeping-up-appearances" in the industry with parties and events, superficial fringe-benefits (like food), etc, instead of applying it to help relieve employee workloads/resources or instead of increasing direct compensation/benefits

headline: AOL employees not welcome by Yahoo Technology team based in Sunnyvale.
pros:
* Most of the employees are passionate about their job.
* Started offering free lunch to mimic the benefit offered on Yahoo Sunnyvale 
   campus.
cons:
* Morale is in the negative range and hit the lowest point possible by end of 2017.
* Minimum 2 layoffs every year, followed by reorganization etc.
* Technology decisions are now made by the new Yahoo CTO and his directs 
   based in Sunnyvale. If you are an Engineer based on the east coast, you will be 
   considered a remote and *dispensable* asset.

headline: Account Manager
pros:
-Free food
-There are still some talented people around
cons:
-Constant change and quarterly layoffs 
-Management has no clue what they area doing (they keep saying 'mobile first' - that's it) and is not transparent at all with employees; they seem to just be looking out for themselves to be honest ( I know of at least one that wanted to be laid off to get the 2+ year severance package but didnt so now he is just coasting)
-It's very difficult to nearly impossible getting work done, especially as an account manager, after the merger as there are 100s of products, systems aren't integrated and some just don't work as they should, and the teams we rely on are in same boat
-The AOL/Yahoo integration has been very poorly planned and implemented to say the least
-Extremely low employee morale with management not really caring to boost it
-HR is the worst I have seen at any company; literally when you think they can't perform worse, they do - miss all deadlines, do not communicate changes/updates, leaving employees and managers in the dark

headline: Stay Focused
pros: Perks are very good (free lunch and snacks, 4 weeks PTO, good 401K match).
cons:
The company is constantly acquiring companies (since the Aol days). Every year there is some big acquisition and new focus. This creates an environment of constant layoffs (consolidation). Also means that the company is constantly changing focus which becomes tiresome when as older focuses are forgotten before they have a chance to finish.

Additionally, current culture has been a drain as two giant companies are merging. These are growing pains that will pass, but right now it feels like groups have been abandoned without merit as groups from one company or the other get all projects in the area depending on leadership assigned.

headline: Up and Coming!

headline: The Tortoise and the Hare

Yahoo believes being the tortoise will get you there eventually but it's unlikely - Yahoo at times needs to be the Hare, invent fast, test and learn quickly and launch some winning products that are used and loved by consumers at scale.  The employee ranking/scoring system sucks.  Working from home is frowned upon.  Too US-centric/forgets is has an international business

headline: Lacking diversity at senior level
pros:
-Free food 
-Fun and well-funded Summer and Christmas parties 
-You get your own brand new mac and IPhone
-Great expense account if you work in Sales
-High energy atmosphere which is refreshing compared to other office jobs 
-Good emphasis on training and skill development . Lots of workshops to attend if you have the time.
cons:
-Serious lack of female or BME managers at senior level or even middle management.Apart from the odd token female pretty much all the managers are part of the 'old boys club' and are seriously lacking in technical knowledge. 
-Multiple rounds of redundancies after the merger with AOL.Many great managers have been let go whilst many dinosaurs have been kept on.
-Far too many outdated products , should pick a couple and specialise . This means that products are often mid-sold out of confusion. 
-Pay is very sub-par compared to the likes of Facebook and Google etc.

headline: Horrible place post merger
pros: Pre merger, Yahoo was a great place to work with great people and a great culture. Flexible WFH schedule, gym and phone reimbursement
cons: Post merger, Oath became a toxic place to work with frequent layoffs (2-3 months) and the feeling of Yahoo vs. AOL teams. Since the merger, a lot has changed including severe cuts to our benefits, canceled promotions, and mass layoffs.  Managers are incompetent and have no say in who stays or who goes and are unable to help in the promotion process. You are truly a number at this company

headline: Open culture, great learning and lots of fun
pros: People will be receptive to your ideas, and acknowledge your labor.  Media usually paints a different (and at times dismal) picture for Yahoo, but its a hard core Technology company. You'll get to work with really bright folks and will learn (and do) cool stuff that matters.
cons: Somewhat bureaucratic, and some legacy debt hounds certain teams.

headline: Yahoo: Lots of good, some bad
pros:
If you're a software engineer, you get to work with some very talented people, cool technologies, and develop some very large scale services and products.

I worked on some great stuff and really enjoyed at least 5 of the eight years I was there (my first 3 years, and then 2014 and 2015). I learned tons of stuff and had the privilege to work for tech managers who wanted to take advantage of new technologies.
cons:
- Lots of legacy stuff (a side effect of having staying power, I guess) that you have to take into account.
- Product management sometimes has this attitude: "Make this complex change that affects multiple front-end and back-end services to test some idea we have that might delight our users". This means we have lots of junk code polluting some nicely thought-out code, at least in the back-end services I worked on. Most of this junk code is for stuff that did not pan out but may be partially still in service, so it cannot be easily removed. Almost all of these "delights" seemed to me to have almost no value, as far as I could tell.

- In my last year there (2016), I felt a lack of shared mission amongst the teams in my particular organization: Teams seemed more poised to pin blame on other teams within the org. Other organizations may have not had this issue.

headline: Great teams, smart people but scattered upper management
pros:
Disclaimer: I quit many years ago. 

It was great to work on innovative products that were used by millions of people all over the world. The talent pool was all-in-all great and the work environment is fun and friendly.  Great compensation level.
cons:
Upper management changed constantly as did the operating thesis. This led to high turn-over and lots of missed opportunities. 

Slightly de-motivating to be with the constant beating horse of the Valley.

cons: Salaries vary widely. Very difficult to get any sort of raise.  Many silos of information.  Company wide collaboration is not great.

headline: Good

headline: Ad Platforms
pros: good benefits, invested in diversity, work/life balance, health/wellness, and empowering women.  many supportive managers.
cons: the day-to-day operation hasn't scaled, consequently it's too difficult to get things done and too many issues make it difficult to be successful

headline: Toxic Work Environment, A expectations, B level pay
pros: Free Food, Good Benefits, if you're in the stage of life where you need a lot of work/life flexibility, its a good place for that.
cons:
Terrible amount of toxicity from Yahoo employees focused on internal conquesting vs. winning in market. 
Pay is not competitive with the competition it is setting out to win against: Amazon, Facebook, and Google. Nor is it competitive with companies that are trying to compete against Amazon, FB, and Google. Basically, tier 2 pay grading.

headline: Lack of resources and stifling bureucracy

cons: I came from Google where you can run a job on 1000s of cores, no questions asked, to Yahoo where you got up 5 wimpy virtual machines... Then there were the early morning standups and status reports. Finally, everything seemed to be in a flux, with projects cancelled and arrogant acqui-hires - it wasn't quite clear what I should be working on.

headline: Best tech in digital media space
pros: The company had many once very popular products during its glorious days such as mail, netflix, etc, and it owned the systems like DSP, SSP, and Ad Exchange platform to serve Yahoo O&O banner, video, native, search and mobile ads. All those products were built on top of latest technology stack. You would never be short of the opportunities of learning and mastering new frameworks, and/or tools because they were kept revising in every few years.
cons: Since Yahoo was merged with AOL, its new management team would certainly bring its own style and culture. Only time can tell.

headline: Great place to work for
pros:
1. good work and life balance.
2. great company culture. lots of internal sharing event and after work social clubs. You can meet lots of talented people and learn lots of new stuffs.
3. Lots of perks and benefit in Taiwan office. you get the free breakfast, lunch, coffee, snacks, beverage, afternoon tea, fruit...etc. You can save lots of money on food and the only thing you need to worry about is to get fat in your first few months.
4.Good performance review system. you can get the feedback from your peer and manger quarterly and you can also rate your manager as well. performance review is always tricky and not easy to implement in the big firm. but Yahoo try to stick to the rule and encourage employees to write the anonymous feedback to their manager.  This could help to prevent the  middle level manager not doing any works or treat their team member unfairly.
cons:
1.not much career progress in search editor's role. 
2.not easy to apply for the internal transfer or relocate to other offices. not sure is this just the policy in Taiwan office. but in general, internal transfer is not encouraged in Taiwan office. 
3.need to fill in a form on the system which recorded what you have done every hour. Feel like being tracked all the time. This is a valuable job which provide the critical insight. you shouldn't treat people in this role like a supply chain worker.

headline: Yahoo Future Doesn't  look so bright .... or does it ?
pros: Not very hard working env. If that what you looking for, More play and have fun than actually doing any work, Free food, Everyone gain ~10 pounds the first year here.
cons:
Not very diversified work environment . 60% Indian decent, 30% Asian, 10% White.
Most people are 'followers' - like to be told what to do and wait for someone to tell them and manage them. 

Slacker environment, no one work very hard, Games and events every day can not imagine much work gets done when there is company. Wide event half the day and the rest of the day people eat and drink like it was not end, 

Talking about free food, I get turned off by seeing all this people bringing home food in food containers, just because it's free food (breakfast/lunch/dinner) it doesn't mean you need to stack your containers and bring home to you hole family the feed them!

headline: Not confident in the future...
pros: Amazingly passionate & talented people, inspiring vision, free food + other great perks, fun culture.  Lots of job opportunity if you're comfortable stepping up to the plate / earn trust quickly / like ambiguity / are a self-starter.
cons: Lack of execution from C-level & middle management, very few non-homogenous / diverse teams, severe lack of resources & support (when I left, I was doing the volume of work we had 3 ppl to do at this same time last year, but my compensation wasn't raised; makes it near-impossible to do anything well).

headline: Awesome and Awful- 2 sides of this coin
pros:
1.Employee Benefits, work culture
2.Pay scale- Top of class in some cases
3.Multiple Job/function/domain exposure
4.Divine Brand name, 
5.Amazing work environment-  At times you will never get to meet such talent and processes any where else ever in your career.
6. Yahoo!- Most of our generations first internet love .
cons:
1.Too much focus on investor/large shareholder interests. May be for obvious reasons, but leads to very short term, immediate -thinking only.
2.Historical Business/product mis- management/lack of focus haunts..hopefully not beyond the acquisition. 
3.Zero/almost negligible focus on New age growing markets/Businesses.
4.Large brand name bring s with it a sense of in security amongst employees,it is extremely intense in some cases, thereby breeding putrid team players/team managers/leaders.

headline: great learning environment, company lacks business success
pros: Yahoo has a relatively diverse set of consumer internet products (content, mail, search, social network) with long histories and varying degrees of success so you will learn a lot about strategies / practices / ideas which succeed and fail.
cons: Company lacks success in the market.

headline: Good environment
pros: Lots of flexibility to do what you think is right.
cons: Execution is slow and lots of projects from HQ,

headline: Good Company to Work for

headline: Support Engineer
pros: Good perks and benefits. Co-workers are generally great people and really care about each other. The company really does value their employees and shows it with company events and outreach.
cons: As with any large-scale company, it can often take months to get any projects off the ground.

headline: Developer
pros: The culture at Yahoo! is amazing. Although the work is fast paced and abundant, you can set aside downtime during the day to unwind. This is the kind of work environment that appreciates the well being of their employees.
cons: Because Yahoo and the department i work in is so positive, many employees have been here for up to and in many cases more than 10 years. Upward mobility is a bit difficult.

headline: Culture is amazing and people are great
pros: Culture, good technologies , free food and shuttles and onsite perks . Managers really are trained well to engage their employees and provide mentorship. They are also pretty hands-on. Looks like moving internally is pretty easy given you have good contacts and make a good impression. Other benefits like tuition reimbursement, internal tools training, onsite farmers market, gym and paid laundry facilities are pretty good. The Starbucks like free coffee bars and the juice bars are awesome. Basically , this company makes me feel that I'm valuable to them. They have pretty good health insurance and 401k match.
cons: No cons so far. May be how the benefits and reporting structure will change post Verizon take over is one of the anticipated con:

headline: Engineering
pros: Great culture (fun), very large user base (1B total) makes job very interesting and challenging. Current CEO brought much energy and focus. She also streamlined many process and reduced most bureaucracy.
cons: Not as hot as some other companies of similar or even smaller scale. Verizon acquisition throws uncertainty in some people's mind. At times can still seem to be too inward-looking by some old timers.

headline: Director

cons: Things moved too slow with many bureaucratic processes.

headline: Big changes need to happen
pros: Verizon is acquiring Yahoo for meaningful strategic reasons, and it's good (for the moment) to be near the center of the target they are aiming for.  Verizon is a good company with strong leadership.  However...
cons: Unfortunately, acquisition and combination with AOL in and of itself accomplishes nothing.  In fact, it complicates the problems both companies face independently.  Verizon will have to be much more aggressive with the changes it makes than Yahoo leadership has been in order for them to have any chance of changing trajectory.  The road has been rocky for a long time, and it's going to continue.

headline: Engineering

headline: Great teamwork and fun environment even though future outlook is uncertain

There are a lot of good inspiring leaders here if you are working in the right team. People work hard and play hard at the same time. Culture is good as there is transparency and culture inherited from Google due to the CEO who is an ex-Googler. Teamwork is great as people help one another and work towards a common goal. Perhaps I was in a good team.
cons: The management had made some bad decisions in acquisition and as such, business is not doing well. With such an uncertain future, a lot of good people has left. Even though there was a strategy on how to move the company forward, the execution was poor.

headline: An Iconic Company
pros:
In short: great people, lovely office, good benefits: free health insurance, pension contributions (although very small amount), free food, mobile, laptop, gym on premises, degree of flexibility - depending on manager, 25 days holidays

Loved working for Yahoo, being and playing a part in this iconic company and will always carry a purple cheer with me.
cons: In short: unnecessary heavy processes, a degree of micro-management, too many uncertainties, too many disruptions through constant re-orgs and management changes, lack of communication although same linked with transparency is suppose to be one of the company's top goals, no pay rises or rewards in line with performance and growth, same base salary (lower than competition) YOY regardless of achievements and only reward is a tiny number of RSUs over four years vesting, not enough career progression/ growth opportunities. As someone else wrote already: Too many managers but not enough real leaders.

headline: good pay, low morale
pros: I came over to Yahoo via an acquisition and our team was relatively isolated for a while, but ultimately got integrated within the broader Yahoo org. The pay was good, there were lots of opportunities to work on interesting projects, and there were some smart and motivated people still there.
cons: Unfortunately the majority of Yahoo employees seemed to have lost their drive and motivation, and I think it was a direct result of lack of inspiration and clear strategy from the top.

headline: Great software company in Taiwan
pros:
Work/life balance (almost no extra working hours need).
Using latest technological tools (e.g. npm, nodejs) to develop fun media products which is enjoyable in the process of development.
Free breakfast, free lunch.
A lot of great people here willing to train newbies who had little working experience
Lots of festivals, gifts from the company.
cons: The company needs more investment in artificial intelligence that sort of thing to compete with other tech companies.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: I very much enjoyed being part of the Yahoo! team working as a sales manager. The team was international and dynamic and the management very supportive. Although the job was pretty demanding with high goals in a fast changing environment, it was worth going the extra mile, not only due to the competitive salary packages.
cons: Career opportunities were quite limited in the Spanish office, so everyone who wanted to take their career to the next level, had to relocate at some point. The good part was that management was supportive in it.

headline: Friendly Environment
pros: Friendly, vibrant and collaborative environment, competitive salary and perks, good learning opportunities for interns,
cons: Currently Yahoo is in an unstable situation and after acquisition by Verizon it's not clear how are the future strategies and outlook for company

headline: Always under continuous pressure, no clear future, management is the worst, firing happens randomly
pros: free food, fun environment sometimes.
cons: no job security, firing happens always and usually, for no clear reason, has many jerks on senior positions and in management. managers are liars.

headline: Creative Strategist
pros: Excellent training, excellent people you work with, great technology, food and drinks (breakfast and lunch served), you can be YOURSELF (no dress code). From what I can tell, a great work-life balance.
cons: A little unorganized during first couple days but your awesome coworkers help you if you just ask for help. Media isn't the best but the new Verizon deal means a lot of opportunity for the business (from what I can see and hear).

headline: Great place to change hats!
pros: Ability to move around within the company. Work life balance. Good perks. Free food.
cons: Negative media. Quarterly review system. Hiring is very difficult and it can be hard to get the right people in the right jobs.

headline: Yahoo Review
pros:
Great People and Culture
Good benefits (parental leave, best insurance, stocks, special events, 401k)
Transparency from CEO
cons: Sold to new company, long merge process.

headline: Yahoo
pros: Very good benefits and a very positive atmosphere. Marissa Meyer really made a difference.
cons: Not that many cons.  Yahoo was a good place to work where people were very well treated.

headline: Yahoo experience
pros: Great company culture and very smart people. I loved the environment, it's one if not the best company I worked for in terms of happiness in the workplace. There is good communication and collaboration across teams.
cons: The future of the company is not well defined, there is a lack of direction, and a feeling of uncertainty given the recent events.

headline: Supply Chain
pros: Perfect working place to improve your personal qualities.
cons: Bad Location, with not good lunch places. If you wont a good food do not go there

headline: Maddening Inconsistency
pros: There are some very nice people working at Yahoo - below the VP or Senior Director level
cons: Completely inconsistent about everything from the way people are treated and compensated to performance reviews to products being given budget or shuttered. There is literally no logic at all. At the VP and above level there appears to be a strategy based on rolling dice.

headline: Director Strategic Partnership
pros: Very interesting as we work on a large portfolio of partnership type (content, monetisation, products, distribution..)
cons: Complex deal approval process; not much flexibility to customised product/deals; Company is US centric

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Great autonomy and professional development
cons: sometime it felt too big

headline: Ad Tech
pros: Worked with a small team that was very cooperative.
cons: It's Yahoo.  Lots of layoffs

headline: Mixed feeling
pros: Very relaxed working environment.  Very nice campus/ facility,  pretty good gym offers lots of free class.  You can also play basketball or sand volleyball, overall one of the best company campus out there.
cons: Had lots of tech debt accumulated over the years.  Does not pay well compare to other big companies.

headline: Overall good experience
pros: Good support from management and possibility to grow in company and/or field.  Easy access to numerous people with exceptional knowledge.
cons: The news is not the kindest to Yahoo and its recent ups and downs....but I guess bad news is what sells these days.

headline: Manager
pros: Quality of people that work here.
cons: Limited career growth opportunities and internal obstacles.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: good culture and technology. It is a good place for learning
cons: low salary and stock, other is fine.

headline: Great to work but no job security
pros: Awesome experience, great work culture, amazing perks. You will learn a lot here and learn a lot about where you want to grow as an employee of any company.
cons: Its a very unstable work environment. Layoffs happen constantly and then they end up re-hiring for the jobs they layed everyone off for. Theres very little communication as to why and how you were chosen for layoffs.

headline: How far they've fallen
pros: Decent salary, good benefits, free food, flexible schedule. Great coworkers for the most part. At one time felt good to be part of a major internet company.
cons: Dizzying ups and downs, upper management out of touch with workers, customer base. But they could be really good at slinging corporate jargon! More concerneed with "maximizing shareholder value" than with delivering a stable, useful product or work environment.

headline: Yahoo - Interesting Place to Work
pros: Great internal mobility. Huge focus on maximizing managerial effectiveness via employee surveys. Much more transparency around executive direction compared with past leadership teams.
cons: Lots of layoffs leading to poor office morale. Too many managers and not enough IC's. Fluctuate between strategies and never seem to land on anything that can make the company the greatest at something.

headline: A good company that has lost it's way.
pros: Extensive training, company provided iPhone/Galaxy, free breakfast & lunch, free snacks, company events, travel opportunities, competitive pay, will open the door to future career opportunities, great on your resume.
cons: Unstable company overall, poor c-level leadership, poor communication through ranks, no overall identity or common company goals.

headline: Regional VP
pros: Great and smart people focused on delivering value to customers
cons: Continued change in leadership made it difficult to get things done

headline: Inconherent company
pros: Free culture, very active employees.
cons: Disoriented business, corrupt and incompetent management.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: Have very fun culture.  Yahoo cares about employees and respects everyone in the company.  We work like a team, like a family.  No hierarchy in the company and the company encourages us to think outside of the box
cons:
Lack of killer products, which make the brand week.
Before Marissa Mayer, all previous CEOs focused on revenue, not on audience needs.

headline: Sr tech yahoo
pros: Brilliant engineers, free food, get your hands on whatever technology you like!  Purple power.
cons: Y! Specific, sometimes you're not part of the cool clique club in which case your career suffers

headline: A lot done, more to do
pros: Willing and dedicated people, Culture, Benefits (especially for new parents), Increased leadership transparency
cons: Leadership, Too US-centric, Always playing catch up rather than taking risks

headline: Director
pros: Free gourmet coffee, one of the few South Bay companies in the consumer Internet space,
cons: Archaic, very political, no strategy or direction, management shuffled every 6 months.

headline: Content Employee
pros: Culture, atmosphere, perks, benefits, flexibility,
cons: Negative headlines, up and down morale

headline: Customer Service
pros: I liked the free lunches, snacks and drinks. Yahoo had decent benefits.
cons: Yahoo recruiters misled me about the position. They left our that we were required to work until 10pm during the week and that we would be required to work weekends and holidays.  They embellished the responsibilities of the job, when all I was doing was resetting passwords all day. The Manager was rude & could cared less about the female staff. The Manager inappropriately flirted with many of the male staff.

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Culture
Perks and benefits
Location and offices
Some of the products
Fun
cons:
No clear direction
Changing CEO so many times
Struggling with ad rev growth against competitors 
Lack of resources in some areas

headline: Once great, not so much anymore
pros: Some of the legacy staff are great to work with.
cons: Executive Leadership is a bit clueless

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great people, good products, wonderful team work, strong collaboration
cons: Constant change in management, repeated rounds of layoffs, lack of clear direction, focus, and mission.

headline: Work is challenging, but the management sucks
pros: Your design could reach a lot of users, you would learn how to balance the user needs and business needs.
cons: You need to deal with the office politics more than your work, some of the leads sucks and make no contribution

headline: Yahoo Review
pros: Very widely known company that commands a lot of respect from peers within the industry. Was a blast to work there, especially with close knit groups of developers.
cons: Work could get a little dry sometimes. There were instances where I'd be working on a project for many months on end and would go seemingly nowhere.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Amazing people, great products, wonderful team work, strong collaboration
cons: Change in management, layoffs, QPR process, direction and focus

headline: Ungrateful management.
pros: Free food, free smart phone, friendly co-worker.
cons: Unfair QPR system ,Indecisive management, poor spending habit on IT hardwares.

headline: Technical Intern
pros: Very fun summer with plenty of product exposure plus fun events
cons: company acqusition might be a reason that I don't go back work full time.

headline: Lacks Management
pros: Good work culture, good food
cons: No strong management. Engineering team dismantling soon.

headline: Editor
pros: Great team; free food; good benefits
cons: Expected layoffs with Verizon acquisition

headline: Software Engineer
pros: famous world class company in past twenty years
cons: business going down in recent years

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great flexibility to work, independent to take decisions impacting work.
cons: Nothing specific, everything is going well

headline: Great company with great assets
pros: Great employer, good pay and benefits
cons: Lots of the bad light over the company is unfair; too US-centric

headline: Great people culture and perks
pros: The benefits at yahoo are second to none. The culture is lively in most offices, Boston and Sunnyvale having some of the best culture. The perks including free lunch, work phones, amazing events, corporate cards, are industry standard or above. Most importantly, the people are what makes any job great. Yahoo has some great talent, approachable leadership, and all around smart people.
cons: If you're risk averse, like any company in the industry, yahoo goes through a lot of changes like the recent Verizon acquisition. There have been layoffs in 2016, and that can make people uneasy. Additionally, depending on your role, internal career pathing can be difficult.

headline: Great talent, but lacks great projects
pros: There are a lot of smart and talented engineers.
cons: Towards the end of my time there, you never knew if your project was going to see the light of day. Management stressed very aggressive deadlines on a project that never launched.

headline: Graphic designer
pros: International company with bigger platform.
cons: The directors are not creative and the directions are miserable which bring the team spirit down.

headline: Miserable
pros: Benefits generally good and comparable to other tech companies in the area, free food and other perks.  Transportation to and from bay area locations, and that's about it.
cons: Working in constant threat of being laid off any moment, spending more time justifying the work you do (tons of paperwork) and explanations to keep even critical projects alive like fraud and security.  No new projects, same old stuff, keep redoing it with fewer and fewer people.

headline: Desktop support
pros: Great benefits, great working environment,free food.
cons: not enough recognition throughout the company.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: Company provided free food and smart phone for employees.
cons: The stack ranking system, quarterly goals and reviews were stressful

headline: A good company
pros:
Great work culture.
Good team.
Free food
Good balance between work and fun
cons: More planning would help the company

headline: Sr. Engineer
pros: Great company with good benefit
cons: Not very clear direction and not very good to execute.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Team work, camaraderie and fun place to work

headline: Great People, Horrendous Management
pros:
Work/Life Balance
Friendly working environment
Competitive cash pay
cons:
Management team is paralyzed due to CEO's micromanagement, which leads to employees sitting around or never being in the office
In addition, management doesn't speak to each other and many of them are off on their own crusades rather than wait for the CEO to articulate a clear strategy

headline: Interesting Experience
pros: There are some really great and dedicated people working there.
cons:
Difficult to get anything done with the hierarchy.
Wasn't everything I hoped it would be.

headline: Smart, friendly coworkers
pros: The culture is one of a kind. Very friendly and gregarious bunch of coworkers. Very diverse group that loves fun.
cons: Brand's hit to reputation has been frustrating. I'm no longer as proud to tell people that I work for Yahoo.

headline: Good company
pros: Yahoo! is slow-paced and have great cafes.

headline: Technical III
pros: It has free food, delicious
cons: It is declining. Many people are leaving

headline: Sales Designer
pros: Professional environment, well balance between work/life, great resources and talents, free food (lunch+snack)
cons: Lots of meetings and too many cooks in the same kitchen end up the difficulty to compromise. Layers of upper level management and confusing strategies leads to lots of changes in terms of sales/products plans and directions. Want to make a clear focus especially during this transition period to Verizon acquisition.

headline: No Upward Mobility
pros: Solid benefits. Solid pay. Most co-workers are good people. Lots of smart people as well to learn from and be around.
cons: Don't expect a promotion for busting your butt and taking on more work. It's all about which projects you're on and how you spin your accomplishments, and whether or not your manager wants to promote you.

headline: Loved my time at Yahoo!
pros: Great leadership team who invested in employees.
cons: Exec team missed a few opportunities to stay relevant in a changing digital world.

headline: Software engineer

cons: Compensation ceiling too low, too many changes and lack of transparency in submission guidelines

headline: Very Happy

cons: It can be disappointing to read news that often suggests that we are failing even as many Yahoo products win awards from third parties for great content and experiences.

cons: people work there are not always nice, some are arrogant but not really hard working. this might explain why Yahoo has so many turbulence in recent years.

headline: great place

Awesome place for software engineers
Interesting projects, very smart colleagues

headline: Used to be cool, not anymore.
pros:

cons:
1. Oncall sometimes might be painfull
2. Sometimes Need to navigate through regular company politics to get things done.
3. Lack of genuine products.

headline: Software Development Engineer

headline: Software Architect
pros:
- Free perks: food, Top of the line MacBookPro, paid iPhone and service 
- Be able to work with some very smart people
cons:
- While many people are smart, there are many that are very bad as well.  
- Organization is too big and some of the under performer was able to hide from the system
- Poor stack ranking system on Engineers which rely on management's favoritism
- Silently letting go people weekly, if not regularly to by passing lay off announcement to avoid bad publicity

headline: Unfocused
pros: Good perks, good salary, good data

headline: Great atmosphere but too much changing of the guard
pros:
Great people
Nice main campus
Good alumni network after you leave (I left in 2011)
Media properties was a great BU to work in
cons:
Too much of a revolving door for C level leadership
Challenges breaking the glass ceiling for women seeking to get to the VP level
Quality of products has gone down - can be buggy (broken links etc)
When I stated in 2003 the culture was amazing, when I left in 2011 it had changed for the worse dramatically

headline: Project Manager
