headline: Work
pros: Everything was awesome working there
cons: Nothing was wrong working there

headline: engineer
pros: yahoo's culture is great overall
cons: decision for project was not impressive

headline: Good people, haphazard management and antiquated employee metrics
pros: Great people to work with!  Tech industry perks are above average for corporate business.
cons: Haphazard management with constantly changing directives and focus.  Lack of fresh ideas and more preference for doing what the bigger, more successful tech companies are doing rather than innovating the next big thing.

headline: Great company that still has some great innovation despite what you hear in the press
pros: Big company with lots of resources and the standard benefits working for a company like Yahoo.  Work with some really great people.  You have the ability to learn about anything in the media industry.      CEO has weekly meetings to keep the company updated on everything they are doing - pretty much unheard of for a company of this size.
cons: Big Company makes it more difficult to be agile.   Change requires lots of involvement from other groups, which is expected since a small change at Yahoo can impact 1B users and hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue.  Sometimes, things change without notice and then everyone starts scrambling to find out what they need to do or how it will impact their customers.   Because of investor pressure to turn quick profits, everyone is scared they will lose their jobs and then people start turning political which is never fun.    internal career growth is limited, unless you're the 1% star player working on the 1% key project.

headline: Principal Applied Researcher
pros:
-Very good mix of research and production
-Published papers and pushed algorithms to production at the same time
cons:
-lot of uncertainty in the environment with the talk of take over etc, which is what made me move
-Since I left, a lot has happened and I would not recommend friends to go there. It was a great place to work though in the past.

headline: Great place to work for
pros:
New Parent Perks.
Salary is very competitive in my market area
Free food
cons: Uncertainty at the top makes us at the bottom scared

headline: Makes you feel completely disposable
pros: A working experience in a well-known company.
cons: They keep laying off and hiring different people to keep the pay low, no opportunity really, you are out when the time is up.

headline: Purple Haze
pros: Can't think of any left, given the stage the company is in.
cons: By this time the talented people have probably all left this sinking ship.

headline: Would you board the Titanic?
pros: Free food at the office. Great benefits. A lot of fun parties, free clothes and gifts and fun co-workers. If you get to travel, it's quite lavish. Stay in top hotels, expense your meals, the works.
cons:
At this point, I do not know why anyone would jump on this sinking ship. This company is failing because they honestly have no idea what their strategy is. Hopefully Verizon can strip them for parts and put them out of their misery or at least lead them in a better direction, because Marissa Mayer and her "e-staff" have epically failed. 

The HR and payroll staffs are the worst I have ever come across. 

I received positive performance reviews during my time there, but the review practice is really unfair, there is ridiculous red tape for getting promoted and in general, a lot of Silicon Valley rah-rah nonsense.

headline: Tech Yahoo
pros: Free food is very good. Fun place to work if you care about having fun. Otherwise OK. I really like hanging out with friends and colleagues.
cons: Leadership not good. Especially senior leadership could be better but I do not worry much as long as my paychecks keeps coming.

headline: AE
pros: Strong product set with first party data that does work for clients.
cons: Very poor senior management with lack of direction who define disengenious people. Stay far away from the NYC sales office. Iceberg right ahead!

headline: Yahoo is a very good tech company
pros: Engineers around you are very talented.
cons: How its business will go I am not sure.

headline: Interesting times ahead
pros: Should be plenty of opportunities since they sold to Verizon.
cons: Will be challenging to merge with AOL.

headline: Great company a little unstable.
pros: Solid management and training, as well as benefits and comp packages
cons: Yahoo! has had some serious upheaval over the past 9 years.

headline: Software engineer
pros: Good co-workers, good food, and work content
cons: Sold its core business no others

headline: Very good
pros: Good co workers and lots of fun projects to work on. Nice office space and good food
cons: Big groups, lots of meeting it was hard to focus on one task. Annual reviews was not organized very well

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: Flexible working environment, goals setting every hall year to make sure you're on track.
cons: Every changing platforms for daily operations, make sure you love chnages

headline: Sr Engineering Manager
pros: Great colleagues, opportunity to work challenging projects, great perks and benefits.
cons: Frequent re-orgs and churn in management.

headline: Yahoo Intern
pros: Great company benefits, everyone treats each other as equals regardless of standing, very open environment both figuratively and literally. Lots of opportunities to get involved with events around Yahoo and in the community, pretty cool technologies are used in every Yahoo product
cons: Depending on the team, stability may become something of question with the recent Verizon acquisition; larger Yahoo products should be safe.

headline: sales
pros:
great food
great benefits
good beer mugs
cons:
too many ceos
middle management top heavy

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Perks, lots of them. Good work/life balance.
cons:
Almost everything else. Very poor Upper management. My manager had no clue whatsoever as to how to manage the team. Hardly saw him at work, my teammates used fowl language all the time, very rude and made me feel uncomfortable. The quarterly review is brutal, since my manager has no clue as to what the team is up to, you are at the mercy of coworkers. It doesn't help to work hard and do a good job. Lots of politics, you have to fight for your survival.

I heard last that the perks are going to be cut shortly, so I fail to see how Yahoo can hire any talent given the circumstances.

Lastly, beware of the chaos and commotion that is Yahoo!. You have to be at the edge of your seat everyday, not knowing when the axe falls. I couldn't survive that kind of uncertainty everyday, not knowing what is in store.

The reason behind the hiring is all the attrition. I assume, there are so many open positions because of the numerous people who are leaving voluntarily. Watch out before interviewing and even more before you accept an offer. Moreover, lots of stuff promised on your offer like bonus will depend on the company's perf, and you definitely won't see that money knowing Yahoo!.

headline: A cool place to work
pros: Cool and international environment,  very friendly atmosphere.
cons: Redundancy always in front of you

headline: Great for me
pros:
- Looks of great opportunities to grow and learn as a junior engineer.
- Was able to switch from BE to FE and learn on the job.
- Perks/Benefits
- Good people
cons:
- Lots of people are leaving
- Raises and promotions are fairly common to see.

headline: Awesome place!!
pros: It is a great company to work at and learn new things. Excellent culture, working environment and perks!
cons: Free food can make you fat :)

headline: I loved it
pros: Great support and training programs
cons: Not enough account managers to support AEs

headline: Director
pros: Old culture is still there, just. Not a huge amount of ego among the front line staff. It remains a nice company to be associated with and it would be great to revive what made it great.
cons:
Marissa has single handedly ruined a bunch of products such as Yahoo mail, destroyed the beloved messenger and introduced Tumblr which is a dreadful platform for us to use internally. There has been money just wasted on her "rich woman handbag shopping spree" type approach. She has held all of us accountable for performance reviews over the last 4 years which has been quite painful, but all the time she has never been accountable for her failures, which have been many. The employment of her ex Googler friends and their companies is ethically, very questionable.

She has "purple blood" on her hands.

headline: Going downhill
pros: Tech culture, cafeteria, perks and access to tech.
cons: Too many shakedowns and too many higher ups leaving for other jobs. Upper management quality varies and there is double talk often.

headline: Despite the perception, Yahoo is a great place to be
pros: I have the fortunate opportunity to work in the Platform & Exchange org and love the "start-up" type mentality of the group.  Its an exciting time to be at Yahoo and we look forward to the future with Verizon/AOL.
cons: With the impending Verizon acquisition, there's uncertainty on the long-term future of our roles but then again what job can you have 100% certainty on what the future will bring?

headline: Yahoo
pros:
lots of perks
-free food, snacks on every floor, coffee shops in every building
-free smart phone and carrier usage
-free vta pass
-good onsite gym
cons:
-Uncertain Future with the pending Verizon deal
-Lot of restructuring
-Bonus payouts not good
-salary hike per year and even on promotion is negligible

headline: Sr Business System Analyst
pros: Exciting, Challenging, very good talented team
cons: Salary, nothing new to learn.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros:
1. Great people to work with
2. Free Food
cons: 1. Direction of the company

headline: Yahoo Employee
pros: Loved the people and the culture.  Alot of good friends and relationships made at Yahoo.  I especially loved the volunteering as a team, always thinking of the greater good.  The employee was like your customer - how can we help, benefit and make a transparent work environment. I started at Yahoo when Carol Bartz was there and went through alot of change, managers in HR were amazing at handling change and supporting employees. Always an open door.  I miss working with such a bright, talented group.   The benefits are amazing.
cons: Sometimes change is good but with change comes an uneasy work environment.   There were times that I felt uneasy about the shape of the company or if the company would last.  I had faith in my management but that can only go so far.

headline: Internet pioneers but still very very cool today
pros: Information is available pretty much to anyone who spends time to find it. Salary, bonus and benefits match the most popular and successful companies in the industry.
cons: Numerous rounds of layoffs have a demoralizing effect on everyone even those highly engaged and motivated.

headline: The people make it great
pros: Fantastic colleagues, great atmosphere in the Dublin Office. Good opportunities for career development. Great work environment, particularly after the arrival of Marissa Mayer.
cons: Top Management changing too often, both the people and the strategy. went through 5 CEO in 3 years.

headline: Network Engineer
pros:
1. Best working culture.
2. Best perks.
3. Best peers to work with.
4. Awesome facilities.
cons: Dont like QPR process.

headline: Worked in the University Recruiting team for over 5 years. Focused on hiring engineering students and new college grads.
pros: learned from very talented people, great company culture, a lot of room for advancement, good mentoring and coaching tools available.
cons: the company in general had a lot of ups and downs which made it feel unstable. A lot of new management and CEOs the last decade which resulted to a restart button on many initiatives.

headline: Very Good Exposure at Singapore Office
pros: Flat hierarchy. Manager give ample opportunities for growth and learning. Always very open and approachable.
cons: My first exposure to corporate communications - A worthwhile experience.

headline: Scientist
pros: A lot of good projects and motivations
cons: Uncertain direction of company's future

headline: I worked at both Verizon Wireless and Yahoo
pros:
- Talented employee base
- Can be a nice environment, once you set in.
cons:
previously Shareholders, now Verizon
Entrenched mid-management, that seems stuck in a rut
I shudder at a company like Verizon buying Yahoo. IMO it is certainly a new low, with more lows to come.

headline: Just okay to work for...
pros:
Worldwide company, always lots going on
Fast paced
Lot's of social events
Chance to make friends with colleagues not just locally but internationally
Free food
cons:
Product tools can be frustrating to use
Not the clearest of business strategies
Not great job security

headline: Yahoo Sunnyvale
pros: Really good free food and snacks in multiple buildings. Snacks on every floor. Good 401k match. Hack Days and CEO/CFO challenges encourage creativity. On-site gym or stipend. Flexible hours. Free smart phone (multiple options) or a stipend for personal phone. Most of the company has migrated to Mac Books. Great GSD (global support desk) team and center. Space is set up like a mobile store with the phone and laptop options on display.
cons: Morale down in 2016 since the layoffs which were followed by a lot of turnover, leaving us short and struggling to hire to fill the positions they wanted to keep. Future uncertain with the pending Verizon buyout. Bonus payouts in 2016 were horrible. The calculation was changed without telling the employees. Was based in the mean of the job level rarher than actual salary. Someone at the high end of this job level may have been paid a bonus on a salary $40,000 less than theirs. Some people got RSUs but not everyone. Saw a 5% increase in salary with a promotion; no other raises in four year tenure. Have heard stories of Yahoo offers to new employees being turned down due to salaries lower than area average. Turnover continues to be high and reorganizations frequent.

headline: Good things at Yahoo
pros: Bleeding purple is a common phrase that unites the purpose of employees.  Great opportunity for starting careers straight out of college.
cons: Rotating leadership, but strong employees support the business with great passion. The company has tried many CEOs and ultimately they're responsible.

headline: Advertising Operations Specialist
pros: Great work environment and culture, great position to gain a broad knowledge about advertising products, agency relationships and a technical background.
cons: Little opportunities to switch roles within the company

headline: Uncertain future
pros: Pay and benefits were top notch.  The culture is honest, though not always transparent.
cons: The Verizon acquisition of part of Yahoo leaves the future hard to predict.

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Wonderful benefit packages. I had top notch health insurance and perks. Free Lunches, Company events, etc.

headline: Internal IT Support
pros:
Great benefits, good people (until you start getting closer to upper mgmt and execs).  Upward trajectory is there *if* you work your butt off -- but still, no guarantees.

Fun culture, especially if you're at the headquarters.

Good name to have on your resume, despite the company's troubles.
cons:
If you're not already in the department/organization you want to be in, it is VERY difficult to cross over to another.  If you're lucky, your manager will have connections to help you network, but you still have to do your own job and cannot fall behind on quarterly goals -- if you do, your ratings suffer.  This can cause employees to strive only for better ratings, not necessarily better work.

Quarterly goal structuring (especially in IT) is absurd, with many arbitrary measurements and sub-goals that can easily end up hurting you if you don't write your goals properly before the quarter.

Quarterly/yearly rating system is ridiculous; nobody except Marissa seems to fully understand it or approve of it and she's made it clear that it's not changing anytime soon.

Those at the bottom (Global Service Desk; Customer Care) are still pitifully underpaid.  Some new hires -- even contractors -- can be making tens of thousands more than full-timers who have been with the company longer and/or even moved to the headquarters after their office got shuttered.  (This knowledge, of course, is NOT transparently known).

As usual, upper management never fully grasps how important the "little people" are, especially those who support their IT infrastructure.  They say they do, but at the end of the day, their paychecks are leaps and bounds bigger and nobody is going to do anything to endanger that stability they have "earned."  They still view "IT people" as replaceable because there are so many out there who can be hired at any time; however, the less you respect your IT org, the less they will respect you.  We may not do "X," but we support EVERYONE who does -- REMEMBER THAT.

Company culture loves to push "transparency," but make no mistake: this is still Corporate America -- if you don't perform a function deemed "essential" to the company (i.e. make money for the company), you will be among the first to be culled when the yearly axe comes down.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: The benefits, perks, free food, and  401(k) are really good. Got to work on really BIG Data which Yahoo has like non other than maybe Google and Facebook. If you are in the right group, you will be surrounded by really smart people.
cons:
Why did it take Yahoo management so long to realize to focus on a few products. Legacy tech stacks were dragging down resources and innovation was inhibited.

Yahoo purchased all these great companies but let them die. Good case in point: Flickr could have been Instagram, Messenger could have been all the messenger/chat programs out there.

In addition, Search would still be competitive had they not signed the Microsoft deal. We sold our soul to the devil!

Now that the company is selling its core assets all the top talent is heading for the doors, and what you are left with are second tier talent that have no clue.

headline: Pretty nice place to work if you're seeking for work-life balance

* Management level & PMs are very reasonable and willing to communicate with engineers
* Colleagues are very friendly

Perks are really good: 
Free lunch, drink, snacks
Free fruits twice a week
Free half-hour massage twice a week
Fitness reimbursement 1500TWD/month
...
cons:
1. No overtime pay, (but the work time is really flexible as an engineer, you can control your work time to make it not working over time)
2. Salary is too low, especially when considering the required talent level.
3. Pretty hard to get promoted

headline: A failed company
pros:
Competitive compensation and perks
Talented people
cons:
- The company has a lot of bad managers . My last one was a former good engineer who was promoted to be a manager (who probably accepted the position to speed up his green card process and not because he liked) and became a terrible leader, without any kind of people or soft skills. There are also a lot of directors/VPs whose effectiveness is highly questionable, who barely know what's happening at ground level, know a few buzzwords ("automation" is a good one) and that's all.

- The performance evaluation (QPR) is questionable (to say the least). There's no transparency at all. During layoffs, a lot of people with a "exceed expectation" performance was fired. while others with a mediocre performance stayed (probably because they belong to more "strategic" groups)

- Company loves to reinvent wheels. For example, out there people use Docker; most Yahoo properties uses  container platform with no cpu or memory isolation very similar to a BSD jail.
Companies use Kubernetes or Fleet, Yahoo uses a proprietary and mediocre platform that probably spent millions to develop it.

- No winner strategy. It changes all the time, btw.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Company treats the employees very well. Good benefits, salary, etc. Well established training program for new hires. Collaborative environment between teams.
cons: Too many middle management members. Company morale is low. Too much on our plates with products, offerings, etc. Hard to stay focused and keep up with the changes.

headline: Meh
pros: My co-workers were great.  Good group of people, and some of them were very talented at what they do.  Free food was very yummy.
cons:
Ridiculous corporate bureaucracy.  For a while it seemed like we had a new CEO every 6 months.   Of course, each CEO wanted us to maintain LASER FOCUS on our goals.  These goals were rarely actually defined and were always short-lived.

Also, don't get me started on the annual review process.

headline: Most eye opening and enriching job I've had
pros: The people I've worked directly with are damn smart. You soak up a lot through osmosis; you just get more knowledgeable just working with these folks and on tasks you need to accomplish. People are friendly and welcoming. You can just feel the love and pride everyone has for the company- we all bled purple through and through. Always.
cons: Top management- like way at the top- have no idea what to do with the advantages they already have. Wasted Emerging Markets, wasted Mobile, wasted opportunities and people. Forced ranking led to lower morale not just for the subordinates but for the managers themselves who hated the process. Why, Yahoo!? Why?

headline: Great place to intern
pros:
My internship was at a research lab on mobile and Internet technology.
- The environment was extremely friendly. 
- There were plenty of learning opportunities, not only in the subject matter of my work but in terms of learning how a big Internet company works
- Senior staff were super supportive
- As an intern, I had access to most in-campus benefits (gym, complementary food and snacks, free public transport, city shuttles, etc.). The only exception was the computer gear "vending" machines. But that makes sense.
- Similarly, interns were invited to participate in all company-wide activities.
cons: None, really. Some months after I left the lab I worked in disappeared. It didn't affect me but it is really sad.

headline: Racial Discrimination at its finest.
pros: Cookies on Tuesday. The gym was nice. There were a lot of healthy food options.
cons: Well Yahoo likes to tout that they have higher diversity numbers than other companies. It might be nice to report that, but they should also report that they also do not treat their black employees the same. I wish i had some great story about how i tried and tried and my manager had a sit down with me to let me know that there were things i had to work on, and at the end of the day, it just wasn't going to work out. But thats not the case....i was 3 times more productive than my peers and yet was let go....i was told that i received coaching......really????? No one said a word to me. Im guessing that must be the policy and someone was trying to cover their tracks when they fired the only black female on the team that was clearly a high perfomer. I would have loved coaching! I asked to be shown this "review" i allegedly received.....turns out it never existed....to add insult to injury.....i was also told that i made a comment..... the comment that i supposedly made....no one ever heard me say it, and again no one let me know about it. Why would there be sooo many lies about me....with not one shred of proof. Well the great thing is, the department i was in, no has less than 1% African Americans. How about that for diversity!

headline: Past its best days
pros: Yahoo was a very exciting company to work for a long time ago.  Then, it became a reasonably stable place to work for people with families, or a place for new grads or H1Bs to gain some experience.  There was new hope with the Alibaba IPO and Marissa for a while, but that has faded.
cons: Most managers don't have a clue about technical topics.  Product Managers have all the control and most technical managers are afraid to stand up to them.  They do user testing and then ignore the results until the drop in traffic after the poorly designed or buggy site is launched.  Then, it's time to redesign again.  Products in this environment end up being second class at best, as we've all seen.

headline: Loved my experience at Yahoo!
pros: I loved working at Yahoo because I learnt a lot and grew a lot. During my 5 years tenure, I changed roles and grew to a more challenging position that allowed me to get out of my comfort zone and prove myself in sales.

headline: An epic clusterf**k
pros: Good benefits, competitive salaries, some nice perks. The offices are nice, the food is good (or at least it used to be).
cons: The level of incompetence and bureaucratic dysfunction is mind boggling. It's like they recruited the top level of management directly out of Clown College. People in senior management leave and never get replaced; their direct reports hang around waiting for a new manager or at least some marching orders, but none arrive, so either they rest and vest or they get bored and leave. The organization is highly silo'd; the engineers don't talk to the marketing or media people and no one understands each other. There is no chief operating officer who can make these factions work together, so they end up working against each other -- thus explaining why Yahoo cannot get out of its own way. And the HR process is a disaster; it takes months and months to approve a single hire.

headline: Yahoo used to be a great place
pros:
Provided great work culture, was a great place to work. As an engineer you got to work on the best of technologies, developing products that could scale to serve millions of users in an agile manner.  People with drive were given a lot of ownership.
 
Extremely smart colleagues and talent was present at Yahoo.

 It is sad that it is in such a state though now.
cons:
Senior management should not have done the BING deal and focused on Yahoo Search, YST and YSM.
Should have closed down loss making sites.
Should have invested more in Finance, Sports, Local, Cricket.
Tumble acquisition was not a help.

headline: Old timers politics
pros: Yahoo is one of the most employee friendly companies to work for. The company and top management had made many great strides to make employee experience great. Free food, free phones, flexibility and good work.
cons:
The issue with the company stems from politics from old timers. There are many employees that have been with the company for more than 8+ years. Some of them have been fired but managed to get rehired back in the same team which itself shows badly on the company - meaning either firing decision was wrong or the rehire decision was biased. 

The company needs to bring in fresh and passionate talent who can think about making a difference rather than merely saving their job

cons: Yahoo is a bi lost in it's strategy right now and  has been for some time. They always seem to be behind the 8 ball and constantly trying to catch up. In order to reach goals the higher ups launch products that aren't ready to go to market just to get it out there and that sets sales and account managment up for failure. Yahoo has a lot to do to turn things around or clients and employees will continue to walk away.

One project can have up to 6 project managers from various teams. Some initiatives are worked on simultaneously across several teams and orgs in redundant fashion.

headline: My Dream Company
pros:
Yahoo had been my dream company since I met my first Yahoo sales reps as an intern at an online ad agency. I saw how insightful, professional, and knowledgeable these Yahoos were, and as a struggling intern at the time, brand new to Search, I instantly wanted to become like those wonderful Yahoos. At my next ad agency in a different part of the country, the Yahoo team worked even more closely with ours, confirming to me that there was a common value shared among Yahoos all over the world. I knew I had to come here myself when it came time for my next challenge. It was the Yahoo team that taught me about how to succeed in a changing marketplace, demonstrated exceptional customer service, and made me proud to eventually get a job on the vendor side. Yahoo reps roll up our sleeves and teach our clients, we empower them to be self-sufficient in our platforms, and customize trainings to help them succeed. If you care about your work, you will feel recognized and supported at Yahoo by your peers and managers, too. 

Yahoo is one of the most generous, fun companies I have ever worked. The most important difference about my day-to-day coming from the agency side, was new autonomy--not a single soul micromanaged me in my 16 months at Yahoo. There was also no drama within my teams. I was given creative freedom to drive the businesses in my portfolio to fit my clients' needs and had a strong, capable, efficient support team of Ad Ops and Creative Strategists to grow those businesses. I was given responsibilities to strengthen my insecurities and had 1:1 with my manager weekly throughout the course of my Yahoo life. I had time in weekly team meetings to ask questions, present wins and challenges, and make an impact for my peers. My ideas were valued from Day 1, and even only after 7 months of work, I had the chance to apply and was selected to fly to London for a Global Exchange program. I worked in the Yahoo UK office for 3 weeks, which was not only a significant career booster, but yet another personal accomplishment I had dreamed of for years. I don't know any other company that would support such an initiative for a relative newbie. 

I wish this unique company the absolute very best. Despite the difficult press and evident struggles, Yahoo is a company that most consumers have a soft spot for--many grew up with Yahoo products and don't want to see it fail.
cons:
I was cut in the latest round of lay-offs, along with 90 others in my role. 

Regardless, the folks working at Yahoo are true believers of Yahoo products; we even used Yahoo mail for corporate communications --a frequent pain point-- (no Outlook/calendar), but were also using integrated Google tools on a daily basis. Some may find it difficult or cumbersome to adapt to these tools, but the overall culture and people that work here make it all worth it.

cons: The company and top executive management were clueless for most of my tenure (Carol Bartz, Scott Thompson etc). Marissa brought in some stability but then started stack ranking. This killed any semblance of a team spirit that we may have had. People are demotivated and want to play it safe.

headline: Solicit advice from the employees who actually do the job
pros: Lots of great, very talented people. Great benefits, perks including free lunch, commuter subsidy and discounts to various businesses, including amusement parks, loans, etc.
cons: There was a disconnect with reality once you got beyond immediate managers.The higher up you go, the greater the disconnect. Their stacked employee review/evaluation system kills morale. Managers are forced to assign a specific number of people into each bucket, even if the manager does not truly believe that a specific employee belongs there. Management who never met you, or worked with you, endup making the final employee evaluation.

headline: Stop listening to activists!
pros:
It is an undeniable privilege to work at a pilar of the Internet. Everyone has heard of Yahoo, which feels great if your previous employers are flyspecks on the map.

I worked with the nicest, most helpful, and most collaborative people in my career. There are many smart people are willing to explain things, work with you, and generally help, which also feels great.

The perks at HQ are very nice. The gym, free food, and plentiful events keep you going. The free shuttle bus made my commute possible.

Top management makes a big show of being transparent, and tries to keep the employee base informed of what's going on.
cons:
Everyone has heard of Yahoo, and many people have negative opinions that they are eager to share. This extends to the media. Heck, it starts in the media.

The bench seating undeniably removes barriers to collaborations. Your co-workers are right on top of you! It is distracting and requires much mental effort to handle. I would rather spend my mental energy creating better solutions.

headline: The best job you'll be happy to leave
pros: You'll work alongside bright, talented and ambitious peers who often see the big picture and have good instincts on how to achieve success when faced with significant obstacles.
cons: The bane of Yahoo! is senior management.  They're a tribe of executive nomads who roam between companies looking to loot as much as possible until they either leave of their own accord or are forced out.  I attended a company all-hands meeting once where a brave soul stood up and verbalized what I held inside for the better part of 5 years... at Yahoo!, the only criteria for strategic direction is that it be significantly differentiated from that of the former regime.  Plenty of accountability at the lower levels, but executive management gets endless free passes.

headline: Respect and consideration from the top is non existent
pros: Free food, flexible work life. Good people
cons:
Lack of respect from Executive team. Failure to accurately remunerate. Every change implemented is managed extremely poorly creating issues directly effecting clients and company revenue. Product focus is not on users or advertisers but on revenue creation, to the extent that advertisers are driven away.

Over the past 2 years there have been several realignments, reorganizations and product launches that have all fallen short with the first attempt. The product with the highest growth rate and potential has been devalued by short term money grab syndication deals.

headline: Rearranging furniture on the Titanic
pros:
Best place I've worked at so far

Excellent benefits

Competitive salary and bonuses

Free breakfast / lunch / dinner

Free coffee / juice bars all day

Excellent networking opportunities since many ex-yahoos go to LinkedIn / Google / Facebook / Apple

Since the company has been around for 20+ years, it's a great place to learn what works and what does not

Macs everywhere, no Windows

2 factor auth system is seamless

Enormous scale - your work can affect millions of people daily
cons:
No company is perfect, definitely not this one

Constant looming fear of layoffs

Endless negative press

High attrition due to the above 2 cons

SO MANY POINTLESS MIGRATIONS... one quarter it's migrate to this, next quarter it's migrate to that, next quarter the team maintaining that platform is either laid off or bails to another company because they are tired of this BS, next quarter it's migrate to another platform because nobody is maintaining the last one. Repeat.

Many of the internal services are extremely unstable and are not treated with the same respect as a production service. This has resulted in a large portion of the company using services like slack because we can't keep our own damn internal messaging services online.

Recruiters will spam your inbox, even your work inbox... and don't even think of answering your phone. I seriously cannot answer my phone anymore.

ESPP was discontinued about a year ago and replaced with stock grants that have lost 50% in value and take forever to fully vest

Stock price is tanking with no end in sight

Direction and future of company is unclear. Facebook / Google are leeching all of the ad revenue and ad-block software is reducing it

Management fails to see the harm QPR is causing to the company.

You will only receive high ratings if your projects are in the spotlight. This means if you end up with a streak of un-sexy projects for multiple quarters, you are at risk of being fired. The number of people that can receive a high rating is extremely limited. This means if you have a team of 10 world class engineers, only 1 would get the highest rating, 2 would get the next highest, and everyone else would be rated "average". This is extremely demotivating and causes high performing engineers to leave the company and go somewhere they can be property recognized.

headline: Amazing Benefits
pros: I very recently left Yahoo to join Google. I have to say that my 2.5 year experience at Yahoo under Merissa Meyers have been nothing but awesome. In particular it had several simple benefits that even Google, my new employer, does not have. For example, at Yahoo they used to not only have a company shuttle for commuting but also they paid for my VTA via a Clipper. Google does not provide for VTA. Yahoo gave me a free Mi-fi device which was super cool. They also gave me a phone and paid for the entire unlimited data plan. The food at Yahoo is amazing and for me in particular they had a juice bar that I miss very much. You can basically tell them to put together any combination of fruits and vegetables to make any smoothie or juice you want. Google does not have that so I miss it for sure. The office spaces at Yahoo are really aesthetically pleasing and very well-lit. At Google my current office has almost no light. The culture at Yahoo is amazing with regular company-wide events where celebrities like Jennifer Lawrence or the Guardians of the Galaxy or sports stars come over etc.. Lots of awesome parties. They have a weekly sitdown between the entire company and the CEO along with all her execs where we could ask them any questions we want. The company has a lot of successes that gets hidden by the decline of Yahoo's old businesses, but if you are are employee in one of the focus areas of Merissa Meyers then its a really awesome place to be.
cons: There is so much negative media scrutiny on Yahoo that it made it really hard to hire new good people. It also made existing employees feel uneasy about Yahoo's future, making all those negative opinions become a self-fulfilling prophecy.

headline: It has been a rollercoaster which has ultimately provided great experiences.
pros: When working for the right people within the company the experience is great. Produce and stay employed. The free food is nice on the Sunnyvale campus. Plus the work that Yahoo does is very under appreciated.
cons: Office politics, the QPR system, and the sudden but not transparent cap on position salary. Wall Street undervalues the company and as a result we continue to play the shareholder games.

headline: Incompetent management
pros: Smart people. Get to work on products used by millions of people. Good work-life balance and benefits such as free lunch etc
cons: At times too much over-engineering and poor architectural decisions made by architects who have not touched code in years. Too little autonomy in engineering teams. Too much politics and lack of long term vision due to performance reviews and people wanting to work on the latest (failing) new and shiny thing (because of quarterly reviews).

headline: Great Culture but has Lost its Focus on Core Competencies

cons: Yahoo has lost its way by having too many of its eggs in too many baskets.  In my opinion, Yahoo has spread itself too thin and has created an environment where systems are broken, old and don't communicate/sync with each other.  It makes for a frustrating work environment...

headline: A micromanagement hell & innovation stifler.

headline: Stupid CEO, street smart managers
pros: Home of many open source projects, including Hadoop, Pig, Storm, Spark, and Oozie. Experiences of open source project contributions can be easily attract eyeballs of external recruiters.
cons:
Marissa is extremely stupid, if not very stupid. She only knows UI and project management, and nothing else. A few e-staffs were hired or promoted by her directly and left Yahoo with very handsome packages. If the board applied Quarter performance review, QPR, to her, she had probably been fired multiple times.

Additionally, Yahoo is a heaven for the following two groups of people.

1) Quiet a few VPs/directors and senior individual contributors have worked in Yahoo over 10 years. They are really good in politics. Maybe they were sharp in their prime time, but now their expertise are politics only. They only cares their own job securities. Their promotions were mainly based on seniority, not by credits. If they leave Yahoo, they can't find jobs outside.

2) Junior folks stay in Yahoo because (a) waiting for green card, (b) not getting offers from FB/Google/Linkedin after interviewing, or (c) waiting for $$$ from startup acquisitions.

If you are neither (1) nor (2), you would leave.

headline: Learn everything!
pros:
The APM Program at Yahoo is the best place to become an exceptional Product Manager.  We get a solid foundational introduction the first few weeks, and begin our projects right away.  It's a bit intimidating at first the level of responsibility you're given, but it's awesome.  I meet with my manager regularly, have a few mentors who have helped provide additional perspective, and an executive coach who works with me on developing my leadership style, communication skills, and anything else I need help with.

Throughout the year, we have chats with SVPs, Design directors, Architects, and other teams such as the Accessibility Labs and User Research groups, to learn more about what they consider / how they approach product.  We have outings and fun events with our class and other APMs.  We also went on a 2wk international trip to study tech markets in Israel and Asia, specifically focusing on how tech is created & consumed in those regions by speaking with venture firms, startups, tech policy makers, and university research labs.

There is a lot of change, and keeping up with it can sometimes be challenging.  However, I've found that this has helped me work more flexibly, so I'd consider it both a pro and a con.  Yahoo can only grow as quickly as it has if there is constant transformation, which requires change as the company evolves.  It's a special time in the company's history to be here, and it's cool that my work has such a large impact!

If you want to be challenged to do great things with the support system of champions, the Yahoo APM Program is the place to be.
cons: Constant change = a pro and a con.

headline: Awesome Perks But A Bit Too Money Centric
pros: Great benefits including free food at all hours, free phones and laptops, occasional filed trips and parties plus your phone bills are paid. Love the fun and colourful office decor. Yahoo pretty much thought of everything an employee would need to be happy about a workplace on a physical level.
cons: Perhaps it's because I worked at Yahoo Taiwan, I found the people overly money centric about how they would cut you out next quarter if you don't meet the goal. I understand to overestimate an expected goal is to motivate the employee but when the goal becomes unrealistic, then we have a problem. Also, the coworkers at Yahoo Taiwan don't really interact with one another. Everyone sort of just minded their own business and you wouldn't know whether the person next to you simply had a sick day or quit for good. Walking into the office was like stepping into the library's silent zone. Wasn't the Yahoo I imagined at all.

pros: Interesting work. Opportunity to work with some nice people.  Good food and coffee.

Unfortunately, decisions were made to manage people out of the company when truly they should have  stated they needed to layoff employees to meet business needs. Many employees work smart and they are intelligent and bright.  Contributing  performers were told they did not meet Yahoo's performance standards when in reality they did. They just weren't political enough to hold onto their jobs or steps on their coworkers' toes to save their jobs in order to get ahead. It is a Company who wants to delight and entertain it's customers but forgot how to treat their most valuable assets - their employees.

Too much time by just about everyone on self promotion, often based on inaccurate or outright false data. Desperate managers so afraid to leave their cozy nest that they generate ridiculous efforts just to toot their own horn, with little or no regards for the actual financial or humane value. Lack of work life balance except for those either skilled in deception or too workaholic to need an outside life. Coworkers so eager to please they'll go along with any harebrained management request at the drop of a hat.

headline: Even valued employees can get screwed. RESEARCH YOUR SALARY
pros: Amazing, talented co-workers, great health insurance and 401k match, free employee stock, daily free lunch, tons of snacks and cute events, great on resume, paid better for entertainment positions than non-tech companies.
cons:
Was a Temp worker who was converted to full-time, which was already a lengthy task that took over a year to complete, even when my dept barely operated without me. A year later I discovered I was being paid about 40% less than my peers, some of whom were were less valued and far far less skilled. Found out only because another dept wanted to poach me and that manager was literally appalled at what I was being paid at the time. I verified this asking other trusted co-workers in similar positions in my dept. They were also shocked at this information, fully knowing my excellent reputation. 

I was so highly-valued that during the constant layoffs, upper management told me point blank I was one of very few out of dozens of employees they wanted to keep to help shape the new regime. I had even won an annual Yahoo award, beating out seasoned veterans in my extended vertical. When it was discovered I was thinking of switching departments, 3 heads privately sat me down multiple times to plead for me to stay. I brought up the gross income discrepancy to them, they promised to try their best, which I believe they did. But even my upper management was powerless to do anything, as traversing Yahoo bureaucracy is so impossible that nothing gets done. 

Ended up quitting because it wasn't worth spending another minute there being so underpaid, and I was too valued to be laid off with their awesome severance package. I survived about 5-6 waves of layoffs in 4 years.

headline: Good company bad management

- Company's focus keep changing which impacts employees morale who had already put in a lot of effort in an ongoing project.

headline: Interesting place to work

pros: Free food and free phones.
cons: Lots of politics, and the CEO that bottlenecks everyone, doing minor pixel changes. Yahoo needs a new leader with actual vision, not another pixel pusher.

cons: scheduling issues , and communication issues with home office . between property managent and field services company is spread very thin with management staff

headline: Salary issues
pros: Excellent work environment and inclusive management
cons: poor salary package and no effort from the team managers or HR to make an effort to give a proper hike to the employees. A layoff process twice a year is high probability

headline: Some good, some less good
pros: Health insurance & benefits; free food; free iPhones; nice new laptops; nice offices; excellent benefits for LGBTQ employees; maternity leave & adoption leave policies; relatively transparent top execs; flexible scheduling; lots of vacation hours that roll over at end of year.
cons:
bureaucratic hurdles from size & sprawl of different divisions; challenging performance review process; quickly shifting priorities; way way waaaaayyyyy too many directors, Sr. directors, and VPs clogging up the upper middle of the org structure and making operations difficult. 
In those below executive level, there is Widespread lack of trust in the top execs, with the exception of CEO.

headline: Awesome work environment and perks
pros: Amazing benefits and perks. Great work environment
cons: Should focus more on increasing hike

headline: Human Resources
pros: Always changing, dynamic, learned a ton
cons: Almost too much change, hard to be strategic

headline: I would recommend
pros: Its a great place to work, all the usual tech benefits that are trendy these days. Lots of optional to attend company events. Lots of development tools available to staff which can help within and outwith the company.
cons: One of the pros was some clever people work here but there are also people who are iin positions they really shouldn't be. Technical teams and sales are often not on the same page.

headline: Working at Yahoo (Sunnyvale) as a creative designer
pros:
-Work alongside some of the brightest talents out there.
-The benefits are great.
-The pay is competitive. 
-The experience offers exciting challenges.
-The corporate exposure to other competitors.
cons:
-Shortsighted in marketing strategies.
-The creative ceiling has a limit...creative strategies can get stagnate.
-get ready to lose your social life, as it mainly resides on their campus.
-The Silicon Valley as a location to live is a bit depressing as well as the cost of housing...rentals or owned.
-Quick turnover of employees.

headline: No clear vision
pros:
1. Awesome work place
2. Great benefits
3. Smart and talented work force
cons:
1. Vision is not clear
2. Fails at attracting new users

headline: Yahoo
pros: Great people, great technology very nice working environment.
cons: Management not that great, heard it has improved dramatically since Marissa Mayer took over.

headline: Not the worst, but far from the best
pros: good health and education benefits, flexible work schedule
cons: low and stagnant wages, little future career growth (unless willing to move to Sunnyvale or wait out for a position in lower level management)

headline: Excellent large scale tech company
pros: Get to work at huge scale with some excellent colleagues
cons: Its struggling which means there's a lot of pressure

headline: Good launching pad
pros: Lots of opportunity to work on diverse set of problems including building platforms.
cons: Continues to struggle to boost revenue.

headline: They look after you..
pros: Lots of perks and benefits!  Just like the googles and the faceboobs..
cons: They lay people off quite regularly, even though they stopped for a while, they're back at it!

headline: Great company
pros: Free food, love the tech culture
cons: Free food, Office in Times Square

headline: Learnt a lot!
pros: Awesome place to work and learn skills.
cons: Job stability is not there.

headline: A giant full of politics
pros:
The perks are pretty awesome. Free gym, food, phone, shuttle, swag, events, sport courts.

Culture is still good and there is still some great engineers that are going to teach you lots of cool stuff.
cons:
The easiest way to get a promotion or a raise is by leaving the company for some time and come back as a new hire. Or work 14 hours a day and suck your manager's balls.

Yahoo is bleeding talents. And the VPs/Directors fight for power and don't collaborate. It is not uncommon to see two different orgs building the same product instead of collaborating.

headline: It is a great experience for me!
pros: Yahoo treats interns very well. We have lots of intern event and free stuffs. We can meet different level manager and learn the latest tech skills.
cons: The lunch is fantastic and various but the dinner can be better...

headline: not a good place for any kind of career growth
pros:
- Not too much of work load
- Decent perks (specially the food is very good)
cons:
- Confused management; they have the money and no vision, so they're basically gambling on their half-baked ideas
- Unqualified old engineers designing broken systems, unqualified new college grads implementing those systems, and system engineers sitting there restarting services to make a request hopefully go through!

headline: operations manager
pros: got very good exposure & experienece regards to businness operations as I was deployed in a clients place which was in to import & export
cons: it took some time to stream line the business as we had too act as mediators due to deployment in client place

headline: software engineer
pros: 1. Great minds at work, 2. Lots of opportunity to work on big data, distributed systems. 3. Fast pace , latest technologies in use. 4. Open culture , fun events and great work life balance as well.
cons: Need more focus on improving the quality of products across different verticals and keeping customer experience at center.

headline: Good people
pros: Good people, genuinely care about the company
cons: Constant management refocus, unclear priorities

headline: Tons of Talent, Buried under Piles of Risk Averse Management
pros: Great perks, offices, and good people. Technical solid. Great innovation exists in those walls.
cons: Amazing engineering talent, unfortunately all scattered about, working on multiple competing projects, sitting on a stack of 15 year old legacy code. Change requires almost direct line up to Filo, with teams projects often getting scuttled for no reason, or timelines that are just incredibly long winded and surrounded by layers of management

headline: Sr. Manager, Account Management
pros:
Amazing culture and even more amazing people!
Large, loyal user base
Awesome benefits and very competitive pay
cons: Once you are a manager, it's difficult to get promoted after that; folks in those Director+ roles tend to stay for years, blocking upward mobility to others.

headline: sr. principal engineer
pros: excellent pay, benefits. flexible working policy.
cons: rudderless direction; no investment in technology

headline: principal software engineer
pros: get good experience to learn big data
cons: unclear company vision, review rating by quarter

headline: disappointment
pros:
- free food
- nice colleagues
cons:
- no product strategy, 
- poor communication
- no clear career opportunities
- poor management
- no work-life balance

headline: Software Intern
pros: Amazing stuff going on. Totally recommend
cons: Intern housing instead of asking us find one ourselves would be better

headline: Slowly but surely
pros: Great collaboration and friendly employess.
cons: Not really sure where the company is going. Feels stagnant in terms of monetization and growth.

headline: Good
pros: free food, great people, fun team activities
cons: pay, slow to move up

headline: General
pros: I love the culture in the office
cons: I had 4 different managers within a year

headline: Neutral
pros: Benefits of a large Silicon Valley tech company. Excellent and talented colleagues.
cons: A tremendous amount of effort is put into hiring the best candidates only to turn around and micromanage. Quarterly reviews have the potential to build a strong culture if they were used to encourage growth. Unfortunately they only inspire fear based management and, in turn, fear based performance. Middle management is not trained well to improve as managers. Too much focus is placed on appearance of providing support to all product teams and recognition from senior management, rather than setting a strategy for where effort will make the most impact. Direct reports are expected to keep doing more because management doesn't understand (or just don't hold themselves accountable for the fact that) providing quality support to product teams begins with setting a strategy and clearly communicating to product teams what can and can't be covered. Employees end up being asked to do more and more because management doesn't play the role of prioritizing and saying no even when it's appropriate to do so. Employees are left to do this on their own and then not supported when issues arise. Last but not least, there is lack of understanding that while pay is important, morale and support is often more important.

headline: Jack of all trades, master of none
pros:
Yahoo employ some of the best people in the industry. You will learn a lot from your colleagues and co-workers in your team and others. 
When Yahoo believe in a project, they will put the appropriate resources behind it. 
Excellent package from low-high level. Free breakfast, lunch and dinner (dinner at HQ only).
cons: Very high attrition. Lack of direction behind one particular product. Nobody will ever understand exactly what your company does when you say you work at Yahoo.

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Coworkers are great. Work on things that hit lots of eyeballs. Good engineering backbone. Treat employees pretty well.
cons: A lot of politics. Infighting. The usual corporate bureaucracy.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: Good benefits.  Subsidized cafeteria.  Looks good on a resume.
cons: Constant reorgs.  No clear direction.

headline: Yahoo Europe
pros: smart company, good product, nice working enviroment
cons: struggle against competitors, too many CEO´s in last 6 years

headline: Great place to work and prosper
pros:
Good opportunity to pursue one's desire
Open platform to communicate with senior management
Good perks and benefits
Excellent work-life balance (at least in my group)
cons:
If stuck in a group with polarizing priorities then glass ceiling is inevitable. May be that is the same with any enterprise. Creativity and assertiveness may pave the way.
Most of the time if major shake-up is on its way, it could hit you like lightning. I've gone through 3 lay-off and rehire before the termination date. No complaint - every time it is a wake-up call to reality and psych up my survival skill.

headline: HRBP
pros: The Company has a lot of heart. People who have been there a long time are loyal and motivated for it to succeed more because of their history with the company. The Company's products are wonderful (apps, digital magazines, website) but they don't put much thought into marketing what's working--they continue to market the "same ol same ol" so unfortunately, most of the world isn't aware that the digital magazines exist, which is a waste.
cons:
--Marissa makes all decisions (the good, the bad and the ugly) with very little input from her leadership staff
--HR is a complete mess (little to no strategy, constantly restructuring support functions, constant management churn)
--Its exhausting to work for Yahoo. It starts out seeming like an adventure, and then by the time you're in the thick of it and you're invested, you start to notice your opinion doesn't matter, your input doesn't matter, they'll never change, and the way they are is how they'll always be.

headline: Yahoo review
pros:
Outside of Sunnyvale, there are a lot of wonderful, smart, hard working people.
The benefits package is fantastic.
Obviously the free food & other perks are a draw as well.
cons:
Everything is politically charged & favorites are sometimes played.
The QPR process has wreaked havoc on the culture and on morale.
The hiring process is painful for those hiring & those being hired.

headline: Lack of focus, hard to see results
pros: Legendary brand, great benefits, awesome work environment/apple devices. Smart and hard working people.
cons: Too hard to get in front of young generation, too big to keep up the game in the industry. Lack of focus, lack of the killer product/service. Everyone tries very hard, but slow to see results. Too many layers, slow to get things done. Too many changes in leadership that various teams don't have clear responsibilities.

headline: Good company
pros: The salary was decent there.
cons: Management obviously needs improving there.

headline: Experience working full time
pros: culture, work quality, people,location, flexibility
cons: Fading away when compared to other giants and small companies coming up in the tech scene. If you wana be on top of the tide, this is an option for sure but not your first option.

headline: Fun and Good Place to Work
pros: Good Benefits, Free Food, Great Colleagues, and Leadership is very Transparent
cons: A lot of work still needs to be done to turn Yahoo around, which means aggressive deadlines and plenty of work to go around

headline: Awesome Company
pros: Great company to work with
cons: nothing to report for cons

headline: Yahooooo'ed
pros: Excellent working environment and great place to showcase ideas
cons: Way behind in digital innovation and development

headline: This company has no structure!
pros: great food, great coffee, great snacks
cons: Yahoo used to be a good company with great culture, but now they are only hiring and promoting sycophants, if you believe you are one of them, then just come! Managers in this company do not care how talented you are, how dedicated you are, all they ever wanted is you to be sycophants, and you will get promoted someday. .

headline: Yahoo review
pros: Very transparent company. Challenging work
cons: Work gets overwhelming since there aren't enough developers

headline: Aimless, Full of Politics
pros: It was widely used and you could create and shape products that helped many people.  The office environment was nice.  Fancy standing desks, etc.  Travel was reasonable, and comfortable. The perks have only improved since I left.
cons: Uncertainty over direction, changes in management, frequent layoffs, office politics.  Lack of coordination and waste of resources.  Some of these things began to be looked at after I left.

headline: Great Company, Suspect Future
pros: Great benefits, Good Pay, Opportunities to work on web scale problems, Work with really smart folks
cons: Future of Yahoo is suspect

headline: yahoo US
pros: very talented co-workers.  Learned a lot from my co-worker and manager. Nice culture. Good work life balance. Free coffee bar sponsored by the founders.
cons: sometimes things move slowly. You don't get opportunity to work on different projects and you may get bored working on the same thing forever.

headline: Great Perks and Balance
pros: Love the perks in the Sunnyvale HQ - great food, lots of fun events (octoberfest, concerts on the quad, etc). They treat you very well while you are there and have pretty good work/life balance, especially for parents that can't stay late everyday due to family obligations.
cons: Company is too large, so it's hard to make big contributions as an individual.

headline: principal engineer
pros: lots of opportunities to work on something you find rewarding. lots of great perks. great free food and lots of activities. good focus on engineering excellence.
cons: good people but really need a few more great people. systems are quite old and hold back progress. however the right investments are being made to modernize.

headline: good place
pros: Overall, it's a good place to build and grow in your career
cons: Generally it has been unstable due to well known reasons

headline: Principal Software Engineer
pros: free food, compensation, good engineers
cons: Politics, QPR, hidden layoffs, unprofessional management

headline: Senior Program Manager
pros: Yahoo has been a remains a great environment to work with some of the smartest talent. There was great team cooperation and willingness to go the extra mile for your colleagues.
cons: Lack of a clear vision that will turn the company around. Market perception remains negative unless company can find a way to grow revenues and profits.

headline: Great place to work at!!
pros:
- Cool people
- Competitive work environment to motivate you to perform better!
cons: There are none I believe!!

headline: Great Benefits
pros: good pay, good benefits, convenient - there were a lot of great people in the department until it shut down - there was a good spirit in the area where we worked.
cons: lack of open communication, too much turnover, rapid and random changes, other typical issues of call center work especially call management

headline: SWE
pros: Very friendly enviorment, nice people
cons: Long working hours, but feels good

headline: Software Development Engineer
pros: Free food, free phone, gymnasium allowance.
cons: QPR (Quarterly Peer Review) sucks.

headline: nice company
pros: many smart people, good working environment, nice campus. Sunnyvale headquarter Location is convient to commute in bay area.
cons: Upper management is not good, often make decisions that's hard to understand. may be not making much sense either. product manage not very good, don't really understand user's needs.

headline: Disorganized
pros: The people are the best thing about yahoo. Everyone is willing to help, to work together.
cons: Departments in silos. Products rolled out quickly without quality.

headline: Happy here
pros: Great learning, Free food, lots of perks, beutiful office, free shuttle
cons: I don't really have any cons

headline: overall very good company and work atmosphere
pros:
definitely a good work environment. i was able to work alone and never in 3-4 yrs felt any pressure to do my job, i just did it.
sometimes i miss the place
cons:
i worked there at a time before marissa got there and there was a shuffle of a few different CEOs.
so there was definitely a lack of guidance from CEO level, and there were some bad acquisitions by the company.
at the time, because positions were limited in the area, there wasn't much room for any sort of advancement unless i was willing to relocate

headline: Very disorganized, low morale when I was there (2011)
pros: They had some great perks and you get a chance to solve problems on a very large scale. I got some exposure to exciting open source projects.
cons: Very disorganized and very low morale. There were huge layoffs while I was there, and one of the founders left. It was a rough time for Yahoo! Also, although they embrace open source, a lot of tools that are critical were forks of open source things that were poorly maintained or quickly abandoned. Some of the more mature forks developed into basically proprietary tools, with little, or poor documentation. There was a lot of out for number 1 and teamwork was lacking. Many teams did basically the same thing and didn't even know their counterpart teams existed (including mine).

headline: Sen Software Engineer
pros: Great place to work, full freedom
cons: RSU/shares keep moving up and down. :-)

headline: Internship
pros: Good for interns, interesting location, good benefit etc. Nice co-workers. Nice location, I am not in US, but in Europe!!!!!! This is cool
cons: Not fast pace, people can enjoy life. Good to re-visit. Need to publish papers. The whole pace is not fast. I hope it could be a little bit faster.

headline: support
pros: Not from that position. None that I can think of. Some decent people on my same level, not many above me.
cons: under pay, long times to promotion if at all, too much internal politics.

headline: Great Culture, Hard Workers
pros:
Yahoo has a fantastic culture and management actually cares about your well-being. I have never felt unwanted.

The work you will do needs a lot of focus and thinking outside the box. It will challenge you every day, but in a good way! I have grown so much in my short time here!
cons:
The work load can get pretty crazy. Managers recognize it and try to minimize it, but just because of how the company is right now, it's a ton of work!

Working with engineers can be frustrating, they build products how they think they should function, when they aren't the ones using the tools every day!

headline: working experience
pros: It's good for a new graduate students. Good learning opportunity, nice people to work with and very good food for employees.
cons: Not much challenge. Management and organization is not so good.

headline: Strong Upward Mobility
pros: Executives are very approachable and open to suggestions. Many chances to rise in the company due to regular reshuffling and departures. Easy to shine if you do great work. Easy to make big impact. Colleagues are friendly.
cons: Morale isn't the highest, especially after layoffs. Engineering practices are behind the norm, but they're working on it. Quality is often lacking in products. Company focus is unclear, and changes regularly. Lots of thrashing in orgs like talent. Future is uncertain, so often the focus is very short term.

headline: Good window-dressing, but poor management and job security
pros: Free stuff:  food, coffee, snacks, movies, concerts, shuttles, and some very friendly employees.  Best for SW engineers.
cons: Quarterly, stacked ranking reviews have intensified the "watching one's own back" and micromanagement and quarterly terminations along with the ongoing layoffs.  Transfers and advancement is possible if you brown-nose with the right higher-level managers, but opportunities to learn and grow aren't available, especially if you don't have CS degree or Masters. Management/people skills are not valued there;and some managers like to yell and swear at employees during meetings and bully during 1:1s because they lack these skills, yet they often get promoted.

headline: Company culture
pros:
- Excellent people
- Motivating CEO
- Free food
- Work culture/camaraderie
cons:
- Constant org changes
- Uncertain future with potential job cuts

headline: Great Company, Bad Management
pros:
Good perks - staff functions, activities, corporate mobile, health fund reimbursement
, flexible working hours, benefits, and Good office locations.
cons: No rewards or recognition for good hard work. Promotions only result in a small pay increase (6%) in my experience which means that good employees often leave as they can earn significantly more elsewhere. BAD and manipulative direct manager,  lack of accountability when things go wrong,

headline: Great people and benefits
pros: The people who actually care about the business are great. And the benefits are on par for what most internet companies provide.
cons:
The executive staff is a joke. it's a good ol'e boys club run by a women. A women who is there as a token to run it to the ground for a profit. 
It's also hard to transfer internally because despite what is being told to employee's they really do care about where you went to school.

headline: Sales Manager

cons: Not clearly see future vision.

headline: Labs is good

Laid-back, autonomous-style environment.

Good compensation and benefits.

Work/life balance respected.

Difficult to advance.

Analysis/paralaysis can stall projects

London engineering team all made redundant

headline: Fun, exciting

cons:
Hard to get stuff released - by the time you are finishing up a project, management might just change their mind and pull the plug on it.
Frequent reorganizations and layoffs make for a lack of job security and, ironically, a lack of organization.

headline: great place to work

cons: there are no cons as such .

headline: Great place to work!
pros: I had a really good time working for Yahoo! Smart people and a great environment.
cons: I have heard from several former employees and discovered for myself that you don't know how great the company is until you're gone.

headline: Good place to work, but the media bashing is tiring
pros: Free food, phone, good work environment, wide range of products/technology, talented and intelligent co-workers.
cons: Bad media image, sometimes the quarterly/annual review process is tedious.

headline: Not so good as it used to be
pros:
- free food
- lot of fun events on campus
- trying to revive the culture and moral 
- few teams are really doing good work
- CEO is putting relentless efforts to revive the company
cons:
- middle management is clueless
- middle management talks more and deliver less
- quaterly performance rating (QPR) is a farce
- constantly changing leadership also keeps changing product roadmaps and vision and makes individual goals ambiguous
- some stuffs in management is not technically sound and nurture favouritism to get things dine in their way
- team morals are at the rock bottom
- work life balance is at toss

headline: Engineer
pros: good employee benefit, good working environment
cons: quarterly performance review, high pressure

headline: Great work environment
pros:
Great work atmosphere.  Good office administration and great dispositions from admins to help in any needs the staff had.
Good perks such as free food or medical insurance, among others.
cons:
Big differences between senior and not so senior staff 
Terrible differences between contractors and Yahoo employees.  Although contractors worked as hard as the rest, they did not have any of the benefits (medical, life insurance, stock options, etc).

headline: Fun if a bit frustrating
pros: Some great people working there. Great food. Fun atmosphere.
cons: Overall feeling of being second rate. Everyone uses Google products, even if Yahoo equivalent exists. Yahoo ads often market scams/malware, but nobody I talked to seemed to mind.

headline: Takes advantage
pros: The pay is on the higher end.
cons: They really take advantage of freelancers. You're working 40 hours a week at least, so really you're not able to have another job -- yet you're denied benefits or treated as well as full time employees.

headline: Good
pros: Really cool and friendly environment to work at
cons: The company is sinking in the recent past.

headline: Too busy fighting internal problems
pros: Great for life work balance. Great benefits. Nice and generally collaborative people in teams. Great food. Shuttles in Bay Area.
cons: Too many status updates and too much politics. Best people are leaving yahoo or have left a while ago. Hard to hire smart motivated folks. If you happened to be one - you might make an impact... Or not.

headline: Respectable tech company
pros: This was one of the best companies I ever worked for. The benefits and perks, which include a few paid weeks of paternity / maternity leave as well as one's own laptop along with smartphone among other things, were very generous. Salaries and compensations were also highly competitive and slightly above market rate.
cons: The selection process is very competitive and onboarding can be arduous and protracted as well; therefore patience is in order. Additionally, once hired into a role, movement in terms of promotion (especially vertical moves) proved a little challenging.

headline: None
author_position: Senior Small Business Sales Representative -Merchant Sales

cons: Lack in quickness to market.

headline: Director

cons: Beaurocracy. Good leadership scarce so you may feel lost without it.

headline: Yahoo Internship
pros: Professional and joyful team, with young and proactive people. A lot of creativity and a company with a strong innovation mind.

headline: Yahoo review

headline: Mixed feelings
pros: The company is very premium so all the staff have access to the latest technology to work, including great laptops and smartphones. They are also very transparent with global live streaming of the CEO's updates every week and the benefits are great (including free breakfast and free lunch every day)
cons: There is no international strategy whatsover, so outside the US is a big mess, with people being hired and fired all the time. You can be there for 15 years or 3 months and you can be fired just like that, there is no security. The QPR process is also extremely though and unfair and if you get too bad results in one year you are automatically fired. The communication outside the US is extremely bad.

headline: Senior management needs a change
pros: Free food and beverages. Newer management additions are bringing intelligent ideas and change for the better.
cons:
Senior management in the location has no clue how to run the support business unit in Hillsboro and continuously makes uneducated decisions. Morale is at an all time low and most of the talent has already left the company seeking new opportunities and career advancement.

When job opening come up they are almost always filled from the external sources since backfilling positions is close to impossible. The hiring process needs to be completely revamped or internal growth will continue to be a scarce commodity.

headline: Fun place to work with great perks
pros: Great perks and a really fun culture. Great CEO who ensures the entire company understands the company strategy and direction. Office is located on the pier and is a beautiful location to be every day!

headline: Good pay, perks, decent people, but lacking direction
pros:
- Pay, bonus and share scheme were all very competitive
- Good perks - excellent free canteen, holiday purchase, company phones etc
- Good travel opportunities
- In a large office of >250 people, an impressive lack of unpleasant people - generally a friendly place to work
cons:
- There is an atmosphere of slow decline - despite efforts to come up with new products and offering, numbers aren't significantly improving and this does reflect on the mood
- Relatively frequent redundancies
- It feels like markets outside of the US are always an afterthought, and generally have to wait in order to get new products and offerings
- Strategy seems to change focus often

headline: Great People, Still Struggling to Find Vision
pros: The people are intelligent, driven, and humble.  The strategy is clear, but it probably won't move the needle much given the size of the company and the shifts in the advertising industry.  The company is unlikely to build or buy a breakthrough product in the next few years, but it's a pleasant enough place to work.
cons: There is still high turnover.  There is a tendency toward hiring youth and work life balance was starting to disappear.  Performance is stack ranked and struck many as unfair.

headline: No Job Security

Did not care about their employees.  People were swearing at customers and not doing their jobs, but they didn't get fired.  There is a lot of favoritism.

headline: Product Marketing
pros: My manager was really solid.  He gave great direction, and was there when you needed help but not a mirco-manager.  Quality of people, culture and work-life balance were good.  Marisa is a force of nature and it was inspiring watching her (and her team) implement change.
cons: Cross department politics were prevalent and disruptive.  I supported dialing back work from home (as it was out of control) but felt they could have left a 1x per week option as many of us traveled from SF and beyond to HQ.  New review system promoted an eat or be eaten culture.

headline: Red Tape, no work-life balance
