headline: Yahoo's Bangalore center is a gas chamber (This review is only for Bangalore center)
pros:
1. Use to have an excellent culture
2. Amazing perks and pay
3. Excellent quality of work
cons:
1. Higher layer is tight lipped about future of Bangalore center. Leaders at Bangalore have no clue about the future. Massive exodus of people from Bangalore center (either to the US or outside). Many talented folks have left the company to other companies in Bangalore. With the remaining beaten down, low-in-moral and tired people death of Bangalore center seems imminent.
2. Performance Evaluation is done quarterly. This has created a lot of pressure among peers to outsmart others. Very unhealthy competition. In the wake when there is no meaningful work, people fight like dogs to take credit for what ever meager gets delivered from Bangalore
3. Salary hikes and promotions have not happened for 70% of the people at Bangalore this year. Clear sign by management that "We don't want you. Please leave"

headline: Yahoo is a great company that is goal driven and cares about their employees.
pros: I love the culture, leadership and compensation/perks that Yahoo provides to employees.  There has been a tremendous push to make Yahoo the place to work.
cons: Yahoo is a big company and with that you need to have a number of processes and transparency is difficult to obtain since so much is happening.

headline: You get what you put into it
pros: Surrounded by extremely smart and talented people.  Work on products that are used by hundreds of million of people across the world.  Benefits are great, as is the work-life balance.  This company truly cares about employees and their families.
cons: If you "thrive" in the startup environment, this is not the place for you.  Everything has a process, or hierarchy, that must be followed.  In such a massive organization, it's hard to stand out.  Keep your sanity by going with the flow vs. trying to swim upstream.

headline: Great technology stack; but too much bureaucracy stops technically inclined guys
pros: If you want to know about the thick of things that happen in large-scale internet backends, it's a great place. Until they closed down their research labs, they were in top 6 software research organizations across the world. There is a whole technical lot they built over time.
cons: Most pathetic environment, especially lately as the company is in shambles and facing survival/stagnation challenges. Most of the middle management is clueless and is looking for only their survival. My manager, reportedly learned from an HR friend, was scared as I had a pay-scale too close to his. When I tried to move around to other project groups, I faced a stiff bureaucratic setup that simply did not give in. People who did not know what was the difference between internal and external smart pointers (and I told them about that during the interview) told me I did not have enough hands-on. And yes, as you can guess it's full of such people as they were never very particular about their hiring.

headline: Still lots of potential there!
pros: I loved working for an iconic brand with a long history (within the internet time period anyway).  Their editorial teams are top notch and they're doing a great job building a fantastic publishing platform.
cons: I was shocked to hear how poorly the product development process worked - even just to fix the many problems in the password reset process would take months!  The "Winchester Mystery House" theory of many disparate silos within the world of Yahoo was totally spot on, and I'd seen and heard of teams working on very similar projects with no information sharing at all.  I think the walls were starting to come down when I left, but there's a long way to go before there's an easy flow of communications between departments.

headline: Great co-workers and fun work environment
pros: Amazing training programs and trainers, really spent a lot of time learning about all aspects of an internet company.
cons: There were clearly favorites among management who didn't have to worry much about job security while the rest of us sweat it out daily

headline: Great work culture and learning
pros: Brand, Challenging, Learning, Great people to work with
cons: Sometimes processes, but have improved a lot

headline: Smart people and advanced technology
pros: Experience large scale apps, big data and deployments
cons: no clear strategy and confusing priorities

headline: Revolving management door creates chaos
pros: Good people to work with, fair life balance and very competitive salaries.
cons: Lots of politics, and a revolving door for managers. I had six managers in three years. Very difficult to advance ideas even though the company mantra is to "speak up and be heard". Be careful about this, because if your ideas clash with others more politically connected you could find yourself shoved out of the way very quickly.

headline: Wasted potential
pros: The good things about Yahoo! are that there ARE opportunities for those who are smart self-starters and demonstrate results. The Company tries to cultivate a relationship with their employees and create a energized work atmosphere.
cons: Unfortunately, leadership has been so overwhelmingly poor and disfunctional for many years, and priorities kept shifting, which resulted in team burn-out and inability to make real change. The Company has never been able to truly innovate because of this churn, losing out on the potential of engaging it's massive audience reach.

headline: Incredibly good place to be yourself and lots of opportunities to learn and contribute

- good benefits
- free meals (it was subsidized when I was there)
- smart people
- most coworkers are helpful
- one of the few companies where most of the managers are there to help you grow
- was a leader in its fields and is finding its way back to be leader again

cons: No work-life balance, absurd policies, processes are old and bureaucratic. Things don't move due to office politics. Most of the people with innovative ideas receives constant cease and desist from peers in other regions.

pros: Yahoo has a great culture and has many, many avenues to explore. It is a great place to learn about internet products and monetization.

headline: Potential but still a lot of baggage from the past.
pros:
I liked Marissa Mayer a lot. She was pretty inspiring and seemed to really care about the welfare of the company. There is a lot of fear and baggage from the past that seeps into everything. Company has some sort of complex despite having a lot of smart people and good content. 

The research work I did was really interesting. And in the time I was there, I saw some major improvements. I use Yahoo more than ever now. Met a few nice people. Fun sports and food. Had all the parts.
cons:
Not the most ethical group. Fear and the past challenges really have clouded some people's outlook. Quite sad. Typical big company politics and back stabbing. Felt a little more magnified here.

Some people really lacked character. Many who have been there a while have a very pessimistic view of Yahoo!. At times I wondered if they wanted Yahoo! to fail. I had never really seen that before. 
 
The review "process" was a mess and not followed at all despite earnest promises. Still lots of non-sense.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Lots of talented engineers. Great place to work.
cons: revenue is flat.. lots of policy changes. QPR. No life changin product at this time.

headline: Interesting company getting better.

cons: You could tell the shifting nature of roles and some of the carryover from a bloated early existence was still causing a lot of trouble. There are plenty of public issues now, but the company seems to be hanging on.

headline: Great CEO, Great benefit, poor middle management and politics

Marissa is the greatest asset in yahoo. She has lots of great ideas and she put lots of afford to make Yahoo a better company. Very transparent with company policy and very open minded to new ideas that is good for Yahoo.
cons:
Non technical manager are leading the team that create many misunderstanding. It is hard to imagine the person giving the task without knowing how to do the task.
Middle management are not working but surfing online. I have seen some people that never be in the office but only come when their boss is here.
Peer review is great start to review talent but a lot of people are not telling the truth as of i heard

headline: Awesome!

lots of resources of any type, endless possibilities, the people is great, humble, happy to help each other.
Great learning resources,
cons: processes documentation and orientation, goes reaaaaally fast, many changes in a very short time.

headline: Yahoo has a grim future
pros: Looks good on your resume as one of the pioneers of internet technology
cons:
- the managers, worst of the kind I have ever seen. they do not care about quality of the product they deliver. the code looks like it is being done as part of high school/college project. all these managers do is to ask for updates from one meeting to the other. they add zero value to any product.
- no real focus on any specific idea or product. focus keeps shifting resulting in half baked products and junk code that never gets cleaned up
- absolutely insane timelines

I believe all the "good" reviews here are given by new joinees. anyone who has worked for atleast half a year know things are going downhill.

headline: Yahoo IDC Don't have any future
pros:
Good work, Free food, Decent package, Employee benefits are good.
good people around
cons:
Under the new management there is no vision for IDC. 
First step towards that was they laid off entire TA team. 
Now they are moving all work from India to US.
Not sure what work would remain in india. From past 4/5 years they had layoff's but this time there would be massive headcount reduction.
Even if you survive layoffs for some reason, there is concept of QPR where manager's are forced from upper management to give less ratings. Because of which internally politics will be there.  In the name of QPR they laid off so many people.
I still thought to stay back in yahoo as I haven't completed 1 year at Yahoo!.   Let me talk about my journey in Yahoo.
I joined Yahoo in June. In the month of Oct/Nov I had a 1-1 with my manager he say's "Please start looking out".  I was shocked and asked him why? He says team is moving from India to US. Since I haven't completed a year in Yahoo! he can't transfer me to US. I asked him about internal team transfer he says not possible.

I started looking for internal team transfer also  job search outside. Next week my manager comes back and say's I am transferring you to US please stop your job search. 
Again next week he say's "Start searching outside".  I started searching for internal team transfer . Lucky found some openings . But the new team manager says there is no vision for this division after 1 quarter. I can't promise anything

About my QPR, my manager write's in QPR " My biggest weakness is I should handle org restructing smoothly even if there were so many confusion" --> How funny is that :P

Yes finally I reached my goal I completed a year n moved out of Yahoo!.  Yes for sure must say I learn't a lot from Yahoo. How to have patience in life. :) :) :)

headline: Life as a Yahoo!
pros: It's a fun place & provide a great work atmosphere. Employees get pampered quite well with free food daily, gifts & freebies on numerous occasions throughout the year. Lots of interesting activities happen all year round that are related to work & CSR.
cons: Roles at every level are very restricted & constrained due to the sheer size of the company. 'Performance Management' is on going process & this ups the pressure to constantly be on top of your game - it can be a good thing & a bad thing... if you get fired! Career growth is very bleak unless you are on the engineering, products or management teams.

headline: Very Poor ending due to "Stacking" policy.
pros: Company has a good "cool" factor.  It was great the first 4-1/2 years of building teams and making "it" work.
cons: Mid level management seemed to "implode", especially in facilities infrastructure.  Upper level management became focused on team destruction instead of building after "stacking" policy was implimented.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Private communication has always been an important part of the picture, and I think it’s increasingly important,” he said. “Anything we can do that makes people feel more comfortable is really good.
cons: “They have gotten enough privacy black eyes at this point that I tend to believe that they realized they have to take care of consumers a lot better,” said Pam Dixon, executive director of the World Privacy Forum, a nonprofit research and advocacy group.

headline: Business Development Manager
pros: Great innovative environment to be in!  The benefits and salary are competitive and the people you're working with are really fun.  The leadership in Sunnyvale is really taking positive changes and actions at Yahoo to get the company back where it should be again and that makes for a great environment in HQ
cons: If you work in a foreign office it can take a lot of iteration with HQ to get decisions made!

headline: Work hard play hard
pros:
I have been working at Yahoo! for nearly a year now in online advertising and it feels like years regarding all the knowledge and experience I have acquired so far. 
It is a fast paced environment and we are challenged on daily basis. Our management gives us complete responsibility dealing with partners and clients. It is very challenging, we might work overtime from time to time to meet deadlines but the culture and work environment helps to overcome these challenges.
work life balance mostly depends on your way to manage your workload and also on the challenges we might face sometimes.
In a few words: Great people, great culture, fast pace environment,flexibility, team work
cons: it will be great to have a better view on career progression for new hires. And also more recognition on the work provided.

headline: Great environment
pros:
Good atmosphere
Strong challenges
Good salaries
A lot of trainings and meetings to help employees to stay up to date regarding industry news and products
cons: Too heavy procedures and process, sometimes slowing down the business

headline: Great place to stay
pros: great environment, comfortable work place
cons: management way of dealing with employees and reviewing them.

headline: Worked for the Wrong Department
pros: Senior management "gets it", and is actively working to both trim the fat and enhance the muscle.
cons: The company is heavily silo'd, with competing fiefdoms fighting their way to the bottom.

headline: Engineering Leader
pros: Company culture, flexible work hours and mostly nice people to work with.
cons: A lot of political within middle management

headline: Overall very positive experience
pros:
-Great place to build your career.
-Lots of very smart people 
-Opportunities to take ownership and responsibility
-Transparency and visibility
-Compensation is great (the average engineer at every level has a higher base salary at Yahoo than Google, for example)
cons: -Work life balance could be better

headline: Intriguing opportunity with growing pains
pros: Very transparent from top level, great initiatives and incentives to make Yahoo the best place to work, fun and smart people all around.
cons: Lots of old culture still dragging the company down, internal competition causes a loss of focus of what is important, still difficult to move around the company.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Company culture, flexible work hours and mostly nice people to work with. Marrissa greatly boosted company morale and public image.
cons: A lot of political within middle management

headline: Yahoo: where every decision is based on office politics
pros: I worked with a fantastic team, which I spent most of my time trying to protect from outlandish demands from random VPs, SVPs, EVPs and the ever-changing cast of CEOs, from the founders to the Hollywood hangers-on and back. I did get the resources I asked for, in both head count and budget, to turn around a support group that had been floundering, and we succeeded with flying colors.
cons: "There's the right way, the wrong way, and the Yahoo way" was a common saying during my years with the company—and "the Yahoo way" was always the most convoluted approach with the least chance of success. I had 7 different managers in 8 years while my department boomeranged from division to division: reorgs are constant, secretive, and often poorly planned. It's difficult to identify key stakeholders when launching a project, and more than once we had significant initiatives torpedoed without warning by executives who had interest in or connection to them, but used their influence to make a point or demonstrate their power with no regard to the negative impact on the business. Obtuse bullies.

headline: Met and worked with some great people
pros: Worked on a great team that was very proud of our product. Compensation was fair and so was the work / life balance although there were a lot of late night calls.
cons: Too much turn over in exec team. It was almost impossible to deliver on a corporate objective before the priorities had changed. Lot's of technical debt - at least at the time - made it challenging to innovate.

headline: Top talent at the forefront and centre. Great opportunities to innovate and show entrepreneurial spirit.
pros:
Working with very talented teams. Innovation and entrepreneurial spirit is at the centre of talent ethos. Transparent! Moving fast.... Deliver at speed
Free food is a nice add :) Very proud Yahoo. Have seen career go from strength to strength. One of the most transparent companies I have ever worked for.
cons: Such a large company with many matrixed teams. However, under Marissa leadership, leaner cleaner teams structures have been implemented: making our decision making process so much quicker.

headline: Good
pros: Lots of extra benefits (phone, t-shits, gym, Up band, free food, etc).
cons: Can be difficult to move up; seems like constant reviews (quarterly).  Mid-quarter reviews, end of quarter reviews, yearly reviews.  You have peer reviews, etc.  Feels like you have to have your peers like you in order to move up.  Can be deflating if you are doing a good job.

headline: IT Technician Lead
pros: fantastic working culture in this company
cons: be good for my carrer

headline: Good place to work, challenging projects
pros:
- Challenging work
- Good work life balance
- Many senior engineers are very smart
- Decent perks
cons:
- Not all teams are good
- Quality of engineers  varies with teams
- Bangalore location not getting much love post Marissa

headline: Great if you're an Engineer or Developer - Otherwise, beware.
pros: Good benefits, perks, most people are nice.
cons: Executive team is not aligned. Open and constant bickering leads to a volatile environment. Limited to no communication. Inconsistent direction given be each executive. Limited accountability with mush blame being pushed to lower management. Extremely political with tons of micro-management.

headline: Looking back 3 years after I left, it was really great company with many smart, talented and fun people!
pros: At the time work life balance was good, comp and benefits were also great
cons: Was always hoping for a good visionary CEO.  Now it finally has the right CEO and that the Street likes.

headline: good
pros: lot to learn and contribute technically.
cons: personal growth may not necessarily that easy.

headline: Excellent
pros: Forward moving company, dynamic, cutting edge, cares for employees. Upward mobility  is a plus, some in HR are stars so they keep your best interests in mind. Fair time off policies, great maternity leave. Love a woman in command.
cons: Big so sometimes unwieldy, some departments may be lost in fray. Sometimes user experience is compromised to great chagrin of Y!, but that is change- not everyone loves change.

headline: “So Far, So Good”
pros: The people, The office/environment, Flexible hours, relaxing working environment
cons: Loss of focus in some areas, slow execution

headline: Not much left to market at Yahoo!
pros: Good pay and flexible work hours.  Fun branding and great history and past legacy.  Good facilities and comfortable workstyle.
cons: No vision of how we are going to win vs the competition.  Waste money on paying off executives who fail.  Little product differentition.

headline: Yahoo Bangalore has lost focus
pros: free food, perks, open source technologies, cab service, lot of smart people (who are now leaving in large numbers), was a fun place to be
cons: everything else. management has become extremely political and they just do whatever it takes to save themselves and the engineers are the scapegoats. There is no real innovation happening here since people have become extremely defensive to meet their QPR numbers. Everything is now tied to your ratings (e.g if you want to transfer to another team you need to have above average ratings which you can get only if you can lick your manager boots). Marissa has destroyed the company culture and values for her own benifits

headline: Developer
pros: people there are very nice
cons: sometimes there is too much work

headline: Part confusion ,part Chaos...part of the company works like a startup, part of it struggles with old platforms n product
pros: Great challenges, focussed direction under Marissa
cons: Too much legacy debt-- technical and people, its a real pain to navigate at times.

headline: Great place to work with nice perks, but does well in parts of its products
pros:
Great culture, committed employees
Transparency at most levels
Good work-life balance
Building new products and features at good pace
cons:
Career growth plan is not well laid out, more so there is too much confusion in the last few years
Focus seems to be on select products/features
Many times good talent are not recognized due to multiple organizational changes and structure
Performance reviews happen too often causing friction between people at all time all too often.

headline: Interesting time to be working at Yahoo!
pros: fast-moving, lots of flexibility to work on interesting projects, great campus, focus on work-life balance is real, cool, smart people to work with
cons: unorganized at times, not a great place if you like a lot of structure

pros: good culture to be in yahoo
cons: stressful work due to QPR

headline: Fun place to work in
pros: Flexible work schedule and colleagues are nice
cons: salary increment % is low

headline: a great company
pros: Yahoo is a true good place to work at. Great corp culture and good perks.
cons: unclear ways of development on some area, too slow on the change for really old products, and annoying QPR

headline: business analyst
pros:
great company great future and stable income.
plus very good manager
cons: not very creative, working hour too long

headline: Great Experience
pros: Wide breadth of solution practices available for you to learn and utilize (from inception to deployment).  The best perks period.
cons: Frustration for remote offices that aren't "executive preferred" offices.  Too much buffer in certain levels of leadership - lack of clear direction for some initiatives.

headline: fast-moving, smart people, good perks
pros: failure is an option, free lunch/cell phones/new computers, lax hours, friendly atmosphere
cons: old company with rusty pipes.  takes a huge effort to turn a ship this big around.

headline: Not #1 in industry
pros: Benefits might be ok with the health, vacation, stock options.  Opportunities are in California.
cons: Management needs to learn how to manage a team

headline: Not for everyone!
pros: Great engineers but poor management.
cons: No flexibility and strict management.

headline: Yahoo
pros: The food in the kitchen is free
cons: The process is all over the place

headline: Great people, nice atmosphere, good balance of working hard and having a life.
pros: Proud of the brand, great group of people, planned out time lines so projects got the attention they needed. nice campus and working environment. Good selection of food in cafeteria.
cons: Ran into problems with projects with low budgets and lack of internal resources to complete big approved projects.

headline: Aging Company Trying to Catch Up In Everyway But Not Doing It Well
pros:
* Tight knit group of experienced people who actually knows what they're doing if given the chance rather than chasing after strategy of the moment.
* Can you say Alibaba?
cons:
* The next level of senior management below Marissa is comprised of yes people who are more interested in covering themselves than having the backbone to offer an opposing view which can lead to so much more creativity and innovation.
* Bizarre HR practices and company policies in the name of "creating a company with cream of the crop" staff which are rather time-wasters like the quarterly review, the chokehold on the hiring process, inflexible working schedule and the unspoken insistence and veiled threats on making everyone move up to Sunnyvale or you can kiss any kind of advancement good bye. All morale killers. The latter is really hypocritical as the day-to-day folks are demanded they know how to work in a global environment whereas the Sunnyvale based folks are unable to work effectively with offices located elsewhere.

headline: The payments department will make you work like a slave.
pros: There are some smart people there and its great to work with smart people.
cons: Leadership has no idea of work life balance. Make you slog like a slave and then have the gall to say that 'this is not enough dedication'. People work 12 hours easy and apparantly thats not enough. Plus promotions are rare.

headline: Toxic experience
pros: Some of the people I worked with were amazing. The rest were there to take up space and collect a paycheck.
cons: Terrible place to work. Toxic environment. Total pressure cooker. The harder you work, the more they dump on you. Many employees slide under the radar. Only saving grace was that most of the work horses survived the frequent and MASSIVE layoffs.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Smart people, exciting projects, good work-life balance
cons: Large company, lots of hoops to jump through sometimes.

headline: Anonymous
pros: Tremendous improvements in Branding! Great Food, perks & opportunities for innovation. Recognition for your hard-work will depend on which group you are in and the leader of that group.
cons: In some groups there is no work-life balance! Aggressive schedule of the projects stresses out every one and quality of the product is compromised at times, to meet deadlines.

headline: Not so great
pros: Great environment, great people. Opportunities of growth if located in a hub.
cons: It was very misleading and discouraging. The strategy changed several time, along with having 3 CEOs during my short tenure at the company. This lead to a lot of miscommunication, change of direction for my job and even the closure of the market I was reporting into.

headline: Growth company in an exciting and growing industry
pros: Flexible hours, relaxing working environment, collaboration among different teams, competitive compensation package, free food and many employee perks, innovative and creative.
cons: Loss of focus in some areas, slow execution, evaluation and reward process not so effective, engineering instead of product driven.

headline: Moving in many directions
pros:
-Dynamic company with lots of good engineers
-Company offers lots of perks, free food, free coffee, free smart phone.
-Free Shuttle transportation to San Francisco
cons:
-Lack of focus.
-Out of control Quarterly review process.
-Lack of employee development opportunities.
-Out of date proprietary deployment tool.

headline: Click here to work in an open and friendly environment
pros: People are nice to help those starting out at Yahoo!  They have all the work resources you need to perform on the job.
cons: My job was project based only so no permanent positions were open.

headline: the office environment is good
pros: environment is good, facility is good
cons: the morale is not high

headline: Great place to work. People are talented!
pros: Flexible hours and awesome benefits package.
cons: Not be able to work from home could pose a problem for most working parents.

headline: Amazing
pros: The working environment is great, a lot of cooperative and friendly people. It's easily possible to maintain a healthy work/life balance, and there are lots of great amenities at the main campus to help that balance along.
cons: It isn't always easy to get the resources you need, and priorities are eternally changing.

headline: clear product north
pros: company scale and strategic direction
cons: pressure on middle management, inconsistent employee assessment narrative

headline: Great company with great people
pros: The chance to make a difference in the digital market arena with a fantastic solution.
cons: There are no cons to working there that I can think of.

headline: Great company to work for - amazing benefits - very smart people!
pros: Lots of freedom to do the things you want and how you want to get them done - no micro managing and each employee has a great amount of accountability.
cons: Have not found many yet - other than the challenges that come from working for a huge company.

headline: Flawed company with some upsides
pros: Generous compensation for many and nice benefits, including free food. There are many competent and driven people who want to get things done.
cons: Lots of red tape, difficulty dealing with proposals across properties. Company lacks direction and is not as technologically proficient as a tech company should be. The competent and driven people who want to get things done may be outnumbered by those who make getting these things done more difficult than it should be.

headline: Amazing place to work.. But growth and pay scale is not upto industry standards
pros: relaxed work atmosphere, Friendly managers, Great facilities like Iphone and Macbooks provided. HR policies are more Employee friendly. Unlimited sick leaves.... Good recreation facilities within the office... No work pressure.
cons: Layoffs. They just lay you off out of the blue with no pay... No job security. Top management changes plans drastically which inturn affects BU's.. Pay scale is poor compared to industry standards for non technical folks. You will quit instantly if pay is what drives u...

headline: Quality Engineer
pros: Open to new technology, open minded people.
cons: I haven't seen any cons, probably because it was just too ideal.

headline: nice company
pros: lot of oppurtunity to learn.
cons: Some good talent left because of politics...

headline: Good place to work, but engineering focus wanders
pros: In my experience, most of the people working at Yahoo are level-headed and easy to work with.  They are generally good technologists, and implement good solutions where the engineering atmosphere encourages that behavior.
cons: Management turnover, from the highest level down to the lowest.  This undermines morale and also provides for an ever-changing technological focus, which is one of Yahoo's problems.

headline: headed back downhill again
pros:
you can learn a lot and take a look at a lot of different technologies
standard silicon valley perks
there was a lot of positive energy and buzz in 2013
cons:
surprise changes in policy that are to your disadvantage (e.g. shortly before annual rewards per level bonus payout percentages are lowered drastically)
unfair compensation, huge spread
the old guard still rules, hard to change things, change is slow
a lot of policies sound better when announced by the CEO compared to what happens when they are implemented
lackluster products, no real innovation
a lot of iteration and reimplementation without ever shipping or only shipping after a lot of iteration and several reimplementations
bureaucracy, red tape and policy jungle
you might wait months until IT has your notebook ready (backlog due to budget constraints)

headline: Incredibly Refreshing and Exciting
pros:
While on the campus and during my interview I was amazed at the positive energy coming from everyone.  There is such a belief here that IT can be done, with IT being whatever it is you are working on.  

There is also just moment after moment where you hear the CEO's name, Marissa and the contributions she makes to so many teams and projects.  I can't say that i have ever worked some place where the CEO takes such positive actions towards group's projects.
cons: Can't think of any yet.

headline: Really not that great
pros: Good benefits and free snacks and drinks in breakrooms.
cons: This was a company I really had high hopes for and after one year left with a bad taste in my mouth. The job presented during the interview process was not at all what it really was along with not being told we'd be working all holidays including Christmas! Important policies were never discussed or thoroughly understood at any level of management at our location and threats were given to employees before managers even had correct information on policies. Disorganized, very unfair work environment, favoritism that was blinding at our location and downright dishonesty from management down. People in our department were given special projects before even proving they could do the job they were hired for as other solid workers that had been there longer sat and watched in disbelief.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Global company with good infrastructure and benefits. Professional but friendly environment. A good mixed of talents
cons: Leadership has changed often due to layoffs and reorgs. Losing it competitive advantages and trying hard to play catch up game.

headline: Rudderless company with too many ideas
pros: Plenty of opportunity to advance, generally good projects to work on. Decent benefits.
cons: They could never make up their minds about where to go: About every 6 weeks we'd have to stop what we were doing to make a new deck about what we're doing to justify what we'd been doing to the new management. Frustrating.

headline: Your soul will die
pros: Great cafeteria!  I met some really great people.
cons: Working environment is stale.  People are afraid to speak-up as they might be layed-off - leadership creates a hunger games environment.  Infrastructure does not support growth.  Products are from 1998.  Sunnyvale makes your soul wither away.

headline: Great place to work
pros: VEry good and effective communication
cons: Not good perks among people

headline: Used to be a great company but it's nothing like it was
pros: Flexible work hours, casual dress, free phones, free food, upgraded laptops, good benefits, great pay
cons: Org changes very frequently.  No more work at home. Very ambiguous ratings procedures. Once you are "ranked" it can't be changed even if a grave mistake has happened.  There is not appeal process and the ratings are not transparent.  Poor communications with employees as far as business direction from top down.

headline: Old, slow, lazy and not really improving
pros: - higher salary than competitors (because they have to)
cons:
- demotivated culture (though improving since Marissa got there)
- poor talent quality (even the companies they are buying are failed startups, B-level at best - except for Tumblr)
- little vision and structure from executive team

headline: Senior Software Engineer (Ic4)
pros:
Work life balance is good.
Work is good , learning is much better than other companies
CEO is good trying hard but all need to help her to get turnaround( I feel that 'all' is missing)
cons:
Direction is lost. Seems like swimming in ocean water and trying to reach the shore.
Executive management does not know much whats going on ground other than very high level.
Head count is way high than needed. No one asks for justification why we need so many people.
Middle management is not higher quality.
Frequent layoffs in company. Wont recommend if you plan for green card by yahoo inc.

headline: Excellent work, screwed up management
pros: Very exciting challenges to solve using the best possible way. Nice people, good perks - good tech culture.
cons: Lots of incompetent managers. With a screwed up employee rating system, they are just more powerful and causing more harm. In order to save their buddies, they have already sacrificed real good ones, who make them feel insecure. As a result, the stale proportion has actually increased.

headline: yahoo
pros: free food, free phone, weekly senior updates, nice campus,
cons: low salary, low bonus, company firing people, boring projects

headline: Yahoo will remain immortal. Always a young firm!!!
pros: Lots of opportunity. Very Cheerful crowd and departments. Unique energy. Great working environment!!!
cons: Work Life Balance Issues. Especially since the firm is on an aggressive swing, there was less personal space.

headline: Excellent place to work. Great culture and people
pros: Small team, feels like family. Salary above market average.
cons: No career progression. No free food like Google.

headline: good environment
pros: a lot of various food friendly people
cons: low efficiency of human resource

headline: company has fundamental structural problems that have long gone un-addressed
pros: friendly, collaborative work culture. Nice people. Good perks - in line with the best tech companies.
cons:
Lots of incompetent Sr. level managers. Henrique de Castro and his $100M severance got a lot of media attention, but ineptitude reigns supreme in many functions. 
Employee rating system is a farce: it's just a way for managers to pick their 'buddies'/pets and get rid of competent emerging stars that make them feel insecure.

headline: Great people, lousy management
pros: Many really smart and passionate people
cons: Lack of direction from management because a lot of middle managers came to just ride the wave then move on to another company

headline: yahoo review
pros: Nice people to work with at the peer level.  Free food and free coffee.
cons: The company seems to be doing way too much at the same time.  Yahoo has a very aggressive management; they seem to be trying to please the investors more than their subscribers.

headline: Rocking co-workers
pros: benefits are great along with very relaxed working environment,
cons: Sometime you meet people who cn be defined as 'burned-out'

headline: I love Yahoo!, I hope I retire here, I think Marissa rocks
pros: Great CEO with actual product experience and the focus to get us in the right place in the market.  We've turned the corner with traffic and should be turning the revenue corner in 2014.  Bonus is fairly good and they are becoming less stingy with equity.
cons: No raises if you're higher paid in your cohort.  No explanation of who's in your cohort.

headline: Network that last a lifetime
pros: I really enjoyed working for Yahoo for almost 4 years. My job was to bring in the best possible talent and to make the process as simple as possible for my hiring managers. the staffing team is awesome and they work very hard to produce results quickly. Yahoo is a great place to build long lasting relationships.
cons: Management should not contact their employees around the clock expecting emails to be answered.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Nice working environment and nice colleagues.
cons: The areas out side of HQ get fewer support.

headline: Tough sledding ahead, despite the stock price
pros:
o  Learn all about how to transform a huge company from the ground up - it's what they need.
o  Smart people work there.
o  Incredible benefits and good pay.
cons:
o  Horribly political - not sure it's changed much since 2012.  It's who you know, and top management likes to "skewer" people.
o  Addicted to display advertising as primary source of revenue, and seemingly unwilling to make investments in alternate revenue streams.
o  Still about content vs. technology.  If you want to gain some chops in tech, not the place to go.
o  About 5 years late in mobile.

headline: Invigorating
pros: Highly collaborative atmosphere, swift pace of execution, razor focus on growth, tremendous scale of operations, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be involved in the resurgence of an internet pioneer...need I say more?
cons: Nothing is guaranteed here -- sign up for the mission at your own risk

headline: technicals in Amman
pros: nice office, very great deal of experience, traveling often
cons: very poor stability, really low salaries

headline: Had great working experience with people at Y!
pros:
Lots of energy and passion.  They were amazing people to work with.  The work with the team was very productive and common goal helped to solidify relationships with hring managers.
Goal was to hire the best talent possible in a very competitive environmnent.  Yahoo! has presence and branding which went a long way when engaging with candidates.
cons: frequent changes that often casused uncertainty and angst.

headline: Sr. Architect
pros: Free food, Smartphones , experience to work at a big scale
cons: good talent is moving out, Re-shuffle india operations to US

headline: Yahoo is a great place to work
pros:
smart people
interesting work
good reputation
good atmosphere
Upper management is now very open to new ideas
cons:
mid to lower level management can be weak
Prior to the current CEO direction was  confused and opportunities were missed

headline: Platform solution at scale
pros: The opportunity to work with solution on a large scale internationally in a company that has re-born under the leadership of Marissa Mayer
cons: Large enterprise means projects move slow

headline: It was a nice place to work but salary is medium compared to all the tasks to manage.
pros: It was good to have the possibility to share your thoughts with the high level managers.
cons: the organisation is not top so you have to check and monitor the people involved in the same tasks as you

headline: Great people but too corporate
pros: Great people who worked hard and were ton of fun.  Also had regular happy hours and office parties
cons: As of 2011, was not at all the typical "silicon valley" culture, it was a cost cutting corporation.

headline: Fun, dynamic, chaotic, stressful, and fun again all rolled into one
pros: Smart people, exciting projects, great compensation, and amazing perks comparable to any big tech company
cons: Extremely aggressive goals that are impossible to meet, no consistent strategy, way too many conflicting priorities and groups to deal with, one acquisition after another which leads to even more confusion in strategy and purpose

headline: Nice
pros: Yahoo, is one of the best companies to work with. Its values, the talent base, perqs, etc. Over the years, I have seen a lot of good things happening. First thing that attracted me was the culture - people were so friendly and healthy, early days the managers were so good and motivating. Then, there have been ups and downs like any other company. As a company, it is progressing well. The latest strategies, the latest innovation plans and strategies are quite encouraging and motivating.
cons: There have been downs as well. I have had in average 2 managers per year. And many things are tied to your manager. Thus, this is a big minus. From my perspective, Salary is the biggest con. Opportunities are sometimes not equally given to all; this is again a drawback. So, Career growth takes a toll, at times (for some).

headline: Great experience
pros: Great people amazing opportunities to grow
cons: Being stationed in Cairo Egypt, not dealing with clients would have been the biggest inconvenience

headline: bureaucratic, poor middle and low level management
pros: improved quality of upper management after new CEO. Good quality is slowly but nevertheless trickling down to middle management. Great engineering talent.
cons: bureaucratic, poor middle and low level management

headline: Good experience
pros: Transparency and working on core technologies
cons: Not keep up the same space of industry on revenue growth

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Interesting issues, smart people, great culture
cons: Quarterly review process is onerous and destructive to small teams that are performing at a high level.

headline: Great company to work for for an engineer!
pros: Yahoo uses leading edge technology with a lot of focus on open source exposure, large web scale problems to solve, a bunch of talented good people.
cons: Prior to Marissa Mayer, the company was stuck in decision paralyis, the executives were unable to decide a strategy and lot of competing products were developed which never saw light of dat.

headline: As bad as you've heard, and then some.
pros: The gym is open all day, the cafeteria food is better than average (and apparently free now) and the coffee is free.
cons: Engineering is a mess. Officially supported software was super outdated (Apache 1.3? FreeBSD 4.x?), teams frequently duplicated effort, official standards (No more FreeBSD!) conflicted with reality (Work in mail? Write your code on FreeBSD). Want to get a small change pushed out live? Hope you like meetings and overhead. The team I was on was "Agile" which meant we sat through 4 hours a week of sprint-related meetings. I was hired to rebuild an existing system only to find out after I started that I wasn't allowed to change said system because too many people depended on it being exactly the way it was (said system came originally from another company Yahoo acquired in the late 90's - think DHTML and Java applets for scrolling text on the screen and you're in the ballpark). So after two months I had nothing to do other than use the gym and hunt for jobs.

headline: Good company poor upper management
pros: great coworkers and engineering staff. The perks were getting better but lack of bonuses.
cons: upper management didnt know how to manage. There was too many management levels. Lieing and berating of employees from upper management. very poor work environment caused from the upper leadership

headline: Great place to work for
pros: Amazing work cluture this place has
cons: revolving management (used to be before Merissa took over)

headline: Great experience
pros: Good food, good environment, people are so kind
cons: I think Yahoo can do better than they are doing right now. They need to recruit more smart people

headline: Good company
pros: not bad company for growing career
cons: very low salary and bureaucracy people.

headline: Pretty nice working environment and culture, outstanding employee's benefits
pros: Excellent pay, outstanding welfares, open-minded working culture, your innovation did count, dare to try new stuffs and beer everywhere
cons: red tapes and cross team working dependency

headline: Great.
pros: Great environment. Choose your own tool to solve a problem.
cons: Company as a whole is not doing great.

headline: OK...not the glamor you think it is...
pros: This is a company that seems to be turning a corner, however 2014 will show whether new management's initiatives will be bearing fruit or not.  There is definitely an energy on the main work campus which hasn't been there for a long time, and people are generally feeling positive.
cons: The company tends to operate in silos, so much so that information sharing can be difficult, especially for larger multi-team projects and initiatives.  This makes it especially challenging for program managers.  There is no consistent way to run projects, which further makes it difficult when dealing cross-group.

headline: After Marissa came, it's completely different and thriving even in my non-us office.
pros: You can always have chance to be involved in the development, design, and discussion of cutting edge front-end technology. Yahoo's front-end engineers are undoubtedly the best in the world. Right now, they are also moving from PHP/C to JAVA for their back-end web services. I believe it's a very clever and correct decisions. Yahoo also provides training for employees to be familiar with JAVA technologies, such as maven, jersey, and so on. There are also a bunch of documents which wrote by awesome people waiting you to discover.
cons: There are still too many properties and legacy in the company. Because of some reasons, some properties are still using out-of-date technology and struggling to revamp it. Yahoo mail is still struggling and face several security problems. Not only mail, but also other properties, some security issue might not be very serious, but they are still waiting to be resolved.

headline: Be cautious
pros: The perks that are given by being employed by Yahoo! are great. There is a lot of opportunity to get great insurance and to get many discounts locally just because you are with the company.
cons: No work/life balance. Micro-management, dishonest authority, untrustworthy work environment, and heavy office politics. Your actual performance is not what gives an employee value here. It is who you know, or who you can successfully push the spotlight to, that is what will get you advancement.

headline: Great Overall Experience
pros: Very Work Friendly and Goal Oriented
cons: Before, was not organized at all

headline: Former Great Company Struggline
pros: Great Benefits, Great People, ok atmosphere
cons: management has been changed so many times and the direction of the company keeps chaning

headline: Yahoo was an awesome employer
pros: Yahoo was a good place for innovation
cons: Management decisions were questionable back than

headline: Very satisfying experience
pros: Some of the smartest people I worked with in my career were from Yahoo. You get to do some really interesting work and learn a lot here. HR policies are good with a nice work life balance.
cons: Too many changes at the top level led to shifting priorities. Road maps were made and abandoned and this led to a drop in morale

headline: Great place to work
pros:
A lot of great engineer, good work/life balance.
The working place environment is great with nice design & spacious.
cons: Career opportunities was seems low.

headline: Good company
pros: A lot of good technologies.
cons: Company appears to be going through a lot of re-organizations.

headline: Interesting Place to Work and Learn
pros: Worked with very smart people, who had innovative ideas. Also, almost everyone behaved in a very professional way. Truly interesting and fun place to work.
cons: Changes brought about a different kind of organization.

headline: Yahoo review
pros: Great Benefits, Flexible Hours, Decent Wages, Rapid changes are happening to try and position Yahoo for growth into the future.
cons: Internal ranking system can seem unfair to some, changed are almost too fast to keep up with, changes being implemented before they are actually ready to go because employees want to hit their quarterly goals, regardless of potential errors or flaws in new system changes.

headline: You cannot plan to build a career here..
pros: good start, you will feel all is good with the advertizement that is thrown at you during induction
cons: You will soon realize you that you will not get anywhere, and will be having nil to very little leadership with no direction or vision apart from blindly following directions from executives. who themselves are relying on trial and error. you can not plan a career here.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: flexibility, free food, transparency, egalitarianism
cons: Promotions are sometimes hard to come by

headline: Great, but too top-down decisions
pros: I loved the kind of startup spirit, very nice team I really enjoyed working with and very good technical guys.
cons: I don't like the top-down management at Yahoo!. Engtineers are usually here to do what PM want without asking anything, which is frustrating and doesn't help to be involved.

headline: New CEO instills confidence, transparency, and technical changes that make Yahoo a great place to be right now.
pros: Transparency of CEO and Sr. Mgt. strategy, thought process, and decision making; incentives for those who drive change and revenue; talented and cordial people.  The fast-moving culture is back with breakneck speed.
cons: Company still is a risk to join due to its uncertain future (some thrive in this situation, some do not).  There remain some bugs to work through in the corporation as it moves upward.

headline: Technical Yahoo
pros: Very Good company. Good place to work to learn cutting edge technologies and to work with brilliant and smart people. Great Perks ...
cons: Not that I can think of.

headline: Not recommended
pros: casual dress. free food (although it really comes out of your salary...)
cons: Dishonest management in the Omaha office. The whole company is so disorganized and the higher ups have no idea how bad it is (or just don't care). They get rid of new employees who work extremely hard and bring fresh perspectives to the company, while virtually all managers and directors  who have been there since the declines began are unquestioned. No way the company will return to its "glory days".

headline: Smart people, fun, lots of change always going on
pros: Smart people, fun, excellent benefits, interesting work and interesting times.  Willingness under Marissa Mayer to fail fast and break some eggs.
cons: Too much change, all ramifications and interactions among multiple changes not always thought out.  But Yahoo needs a lot of change so I guess the alternative is worse?

headline: Great energy and work, with some increasing overhead
pros: Company is constantly working on exciting, innovative projects and engages employees across the company to make meaningful contributions and execute quickly.
cons: Increase in administrative overhead such as quarterly goal setting/scoring, performance reviews, etc. starts to get exhausting. HR seems really off as a whole, resulting in a lot of missed deadlines for things like hiring decisions, benefits enrollment, delivery of employee reviews, etc.

headline: A good place to get experience with working with services dealing with a large scale traffic.
pros:
All the perks expected in a Silicon Valley internet company of the size.
Diversity of products and expertise within the company.
cons:
Becoming too much like Google and losing identity as Yahoo!
The performance evaluation process that discourages collaborations.

headline: A real roller coaster of a ride.
pros: A huge audience means a huge impact for your work.
cons: Upper management turnover can leave you with whiplash.

headline: Headed in the right direction.
pros:
Working at Yahoo was incredibly rewarding.  Yahoo is an established media company that has pioneered so much of internet culture.  Working there was never boring; there was always a new strategy being put in place and new areas of growth to focus on.  

Yahoo is a staple of the internet and of internet culture that often does not get the credit it deserves.  I learned more during my time at Yahoo than at any other period of my career.
cons: Frequent changes in senior management/C-level management lead to a lot directional changes.  Working in a satellite office was difficult at times because we would hear about changes well after they had been implemented.

headline: Fun, challenging and personally rewarding
pros: The sales team and management were dedicated to helping sales professionals develop their skills.
cons: Management levels kept shifting. Senior leadership issues because the company spend several years trying to re-position and re-identify itself.

headline: High profile organization
pros: There are still some smart established employees who still maintain company ethos of innovation, with hard work and fun
cons: The culture is becoming more and more regimented - Google-like. Innovation stiffled

headline: Yahoo in Boston
pros: Good People, free food, great benefits.
cons: office is outdated, not much opportunity for advancement in this office

headline: Good place to work
pros: Fast-paced, always evolving, great benefits
cons: Hard to get promoted, fierce competition

headline: Employee's are treated as more of a number than a person.
pros: Free food (breakfast and lunch). Iphone. It feels like they try and make up for the fact they aren't paying you enough with some percs.
cons:
Wage is below average. Exceptions are hard to make a case for. It's all numbers and real decisions seem to be made elsewhere and not on site. 

Very poor communication.

headline: Chilled Place to work
pros: Nice culture, free food, iphone, good laptops
cons: Non-competitive salary, currently going thorugh re-organisation, goal is not clear

headline: Worst job I ever had!
pros: Free food, cell phone expense
cons: Worst management in the Omaha office! They treat their employees terribly! They are verbally abusive and they lie. They offer you a severence package when they find out you are looking for a new job so youll leave right away and then they revoke it as soon as you walk out the door! Do not trust this company!!!

headline: Good company to grow in
pros: Lots of talented people, very high profile projects to work on. Instead of having to pretend you work to scale, it is very much a daily given that you have to.
cons: Lots of hierarchy, many middle managers battle another by trying to get lots of people reporting to them, which means you might get tossed around a lot without being able to leave your mark in a project and fully understand it before you move on.

headline: Great place to work
pros: very smart people, great perks, free food, overall, a very nice place to work. the campus is nice and in a convenient location
cons: things change very often, too many layers of management, reorgs all the time, for a long time, no decisions were made, and then changes for the sake of it, without any need

headline: wide breadth of opportunities
pros: global, large-scale company offers a wide variety of job opportunities
cons: over 15 years and still not operating like a mature company; senior management doesn't have the vision to run a global company effectively

headline: Great company that lost direction
pros: Great brand, solid customer base and motivated employees
cons: Lack of direction and poor execution

headline: IT Technician - Employee Support
pros: There was always a great work environment with open communication between everyone.  Was very easy to approach managers.
cons: As a company in a whole I do not have any cons.  For the job itself, can be working with several people at once to solve their computer issues.

headline: Good now, went through a rough patch
pros: lots of area's to work in, work with man smart people
cons: stack ranking of employees, bucket/quota rating system

headline: No direction while I was there.
pros: Nice company culture. Yahoo has (had) some very solid engineers and you will learn a lot while working there.
cons: Too many org and strategy changes and org changes. No one wanted to do anything for the 3 months prior to a re-org or after a re-org. Very disruptive to work.

headline: Great benefits, great culture, great people....
pros:
The benefits are incredible (healthcare, time-off, 401K, etc.)
Friendly, intelligent coworkers that are passionate about their jobs.
Opportunity for advancement.
Competitive landscape and exciting market make the company interesting.
Flexible schedule that leads to a good work-life balance.
cons:
Things move slowly. Products aren't shipped as quickly as needed.
Executive seemed clueless at times.
During my time there company moral often shifted on a monthly basis.

headline: One of the best places to work
pros: Great company, good team work. Compensation and perks are good. I have had a free hand implementing and learning.
cons: The rating system that was recently implemented sucks. Good employees lost jobs due to the forced ranking system.

headline: It has been very pleasant, but outgrowing the role and size of company makes movement tough.
pros:
- Solid Company
- Innovating to catch up within the space
- Work life balance still good (although changing)
- Diverse and intelligent people to work with.
cons:
- Work life balance beginning to shift toward Google
- High pressure with more reviews and box-checking for every employee
- Very structured, limiting movement outside the org you are currently aligned with
- Rapid changes without support plans provided make for a frustrating environment

headline: Used to be a great place to work..very average now
pros: free culture, innovation, creativity, one of the top notch in world
cons: too many products,no focused execution.

headline: Instill job environment where cornerstone's based on distrust, pile-on, competition amongst peers & broken model of QPR
pros: The comprehensive Medical and Misc. Benefits Package. Also have the chance to work with some very smart, funny, and downright cool co-workers.
cons:
Absolute Burn-Out: Requirements and mandates keep piling on pre-established role. Constant ReOrgs and sudden meshing of completely separate departments/platforms into one single entity. More work, less resources, longer hours, no pay increase.  
 
99% Employees = frustrated/demoralized...

...while 1% (yes, that 1%) of C-Level Execs, SVP's, VP's and Board Directors are Laughing and Singing all the way to the Bank "Mo' Money, Mo' Money! $$$!"

headline: good working place
pros: talent colleagues and free food
cons: bad manager management and hard to be promoted

headline: don't have great prospect in India
pros: India is doing bad. not vision for bangalore r & d. Please don't join
cons: India is doing bad. not vision for bangalore r & d. Please don't join

headline: Yodel like a Yahoo
pros: Yahoo has an innovative and fun, casual environment which attracts creative employees and strong talent. The company events were large and lavish at the time, and tchotchkees were aplenty. Upgrade to Pro Fantasy Football was an appreciated ++
cons: While I was at Yahoo, it seemed the company as a whole was moving too slow. Yahoo was trying to do too much and be the #1 in every category, and along the way it was losing market share. Processes were time consuming and there seemed to be a lot of red-tape. With the change in CEO came (ultimately) positive changes for Yahoo as a whole.

headline: Tremendously positive experience with great people working very hard!
pros: Great people and energy. The momentum is in a growth cycle.
cons: With a growth cycle, there are always pitfalls and rough patches. Yahoo is experiencing those rough patches yet proceeding forward.

headline: Painful.
pros: The snacks were always good.  Very often there would be bottomless laffy taffy.
cons: Everything else.  A bunch of dummies.  New CEO every 6 months is kind of funny.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: No Micromanaging,  Freedom to do what we like.
cons: Work Life balance slightly impacted.

headline: No future for blr under new management...
pros:
Work Life Balance
Deadlines are not too tough
Good work if you can learn a lot by yourself
Good colleagues
Good facilities like transport, canteen
cons:
No direction in products
Too much reorg
Bangalore employee strength is being reduced drastically in 2014
Hiring freeze in Bangalore

headline: Intense since Marissa arrived.
pros: Lots of great focus on products and product experiences.
cons: Stack ranking and falling quality of work / life balance.

headline: fast paced applied research
pros: Challenging problems at scale,  lot of learning everyday both system and algorithms
cons: sometimes too fast paced, and mediocre work gets into production

headline: really good
pros: exciting work at yahoo really
cons: long hours at yahoo really

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Yahoo offers great benefits and cultures. You get to work with brilliant programmers. This is one of the companies that handles the biggest amount data. Get to experience a lot of new technologies for handling it.
cons: Once you get to know you job, it can get boring because there are things that just have to get done. But there is a room to be creative and have fun.

headline: Rankings Suck.. even for top performers. Pay sucks.
pros: The rank and file people are awesome.
cons: Human Resources and Executive Leadership

headline: Nice place to work but changed drastically over past few years
pros:
Friendly environments with great perks
Smart people to work with
Agile development process, so it always keeps you on your toes (I personally like that, it may be a cons for others)
cons: Work environment changed a lot during my last few years as the company was not doing well. So many lay offs led to lot of uncertainly at work place and people losing their productivity.

headline: Good place to work, but needs some small tweaks.
pros: Lots of different area of technology to work with.  Good benefits.
cons: The review system needs fixing, seems to be a disconnect between what the CEO says and how mid-level management actually performs reviews.

headline: Great working environment
pros: Good to work with and learn from smart people.  Free food, snacks, and drinks.  Good benefits.  Great CEO
cons: Big organization so moves slower than startup.  Cannot take too much risk because too content in maintaining current position

headline: Value your employees
pros: Good working culture, Training ground,  benefits
cons: Politics, Bureaucracy, sense less managers, pathetic engineers and pm's in APT

headline: Analyst
pros: Fun environment and very talented people
cons: not moving or innovating fast enough. unstable with several restructuring within organization

headline: Great Products, Fast Paced Team, Culture Needs Improvement
pros:
Yahoo! definitely has it's perks as a company, but make sure to vet the team you'll be working on
-smart people on my team
-fast paced projects with company wide scope
-volleyball courts
cons: -some folks are just there to pay the mortgage

headline: Right domain but not good company
pros: Internet Domain offers very good technical challenges
cons:
Tools and infrastructure technologies used are outdated and not on par with industry. This causes valuable time on site up activities rather than developing new capabilities.
Quality of the products is poor. Takes away job satisfaction for quality conscious engineers.
Performance evaluation is very subjective and mostly tied with visibility.

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Catered lunches; relaxed atmosphere; really friendly coworkers; occasional after-hours poker or whiskey bar
cons: Sometimes feels like have no say in direction of products; sometimes akin to body shop

headline: Bug Fixes != Cool Technology
pros: Salary, bonus, easy life. Being in Champaign one is not expected to be producing out of the world results. Low expectations that are easily met. Work is okay, good enough to beef up my resume.
cons:
Work is slow and not that great. Hadoop and Cloud technologies are well advertized but a closer look will tell you that most engineers are fixing bugs.

Pros are the biggest con. I ruined quite a few years of my career working for managers and especially the directors at Champaign site. Managers have no real control over their teams, all is dictated by the Directors. Some other reviews also mention this and is true that these Directors are technically incompetent and use their political influence to keep themselves at the top. Somehow it has worked for quite a few years. The decision makers in HQ do not want to change them to keep a smooth sailing impression. These Directors have ruined quite a few careers by initially hiring people who were not a good fit for the job, but hiring them allowed to meet their hiring quota. Then they fired some of these people on account of poor performance - of course a bad fit will not perform well. So on both occasions Directors come on top, first by meeting their hiring quota and then when the company was looking to trim, they got rid of the same people. Ironically and ridiculously, some of the same people were hired yet again as part of site growth agenda.

There are three distinct groups of Champaign Yahoos. First with the ones that came in bulk from Motorola. They are the older people. They stick together and take care of each other. Some are good. Difficult to break into this group. Second group is in Champaign because their spouses are in the area for employment. These people are the most political ones and will do anything to hang on to their dear jobs. Group three is made up of independent Yahoos who think they can make a career and living in Champaign.

headline: Great place to work... as long as you don't have to keep looking over your shoulder
pros:
- Absolute best benefits
- Great work-life balance
- Great campus vibe
- Opportunity to learn a lot
- A lot of smart people work here
cons: - Stack ranking has made it very competitive and it's not enough to just do your job well, you have to outdo your peers which makes things very political

headline: Fun, for a bit
pros: cool people, interesting scaling problems, Fun Parties. Still have many friends from there to this day. Its good for a big company.
cons: Constant treat of layoff. Low pay, benefits were ok. Re-org, re-org, re-org. Too many bosses, not enough workers. Older technology.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Fun, supportive culture. Amazing technology
cons: So much management change over 5 years it was hard to get consistent focus

headline: system engineer
pros: Large scale servers - due to which SE world will be very narrow.
cons: Crazy bureaucracy, Upper management is good, but middle and lower managers need improvement

headline: Wonderful company that treats employee well
pros: I have been there during the most difficult years of yahoo, but yahoo treats employees pretty well,  general packages for employees being laid off etc
cons: Morale.  People cannot focus on their work because all these rumors around yahoo

headline: Great experience, but depends on the team
pros: Yahoo! offers a lot of great perks. Depending on the team you are in, often you will work with many talents. Yahoo! has its ups and downs and it constantly learns from its mistakes. While it is not a perfect company, this also means that you can make a difference to make Yahoo! a better company.
cons: Just like other companies, you will work with less talented people sometimes. My advice is to coach them and let the management know if that becomes counter-productive.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: friendly, free coffee, high energy
cons: lots of changes and reorgs

headline: Headrd of Review
pros: employee friendly, professional work, challenging and satisfactory
cons: Difficukt to get identified,team  syncronisation is a challenge

headline: Great place to work. Lots of smart people
pros: A very focused company on the web, yet has many successful products that truly delights many users everyday. Still one of the most successful companies in the internet space.
cons: Silos within the company is widespread.  Working with remote teams is harder than it should be. Weak presence in many international markets

headline: Smoking Mirrors.
pros:
- Free food in cafeterias and kitchens.
- Free music, food and booze around key holidays.
- More free booze every Friday after work.
- Free smartphone and new laptops.
- Free commute bus for certain locations, one even has an employee run bar!
- Many high profile, expensive acquisitions to keep the company in the news.
cons:
- All those free perks mean less salary when you sign on or no raise.  
- Expect to be on-call and working 24/7/365.
- Little to no room for advancement.
- Cumbersome, ineffective quarterly performance reviews.
- Constant negative press is distracting.
- Not sure what all those acquisitions mean for the company.

headline: bring us to the new world
pros: i am the liberal minded
cons: yahoo needed more recruitment the unique peoples

headline: Behind the doors politics
pros:
Salary, work flexibility most of the time.

Marissa has been good for Yahoo! I do not agree with people who diss no more work from home policy. Maternity and paternity benefits are just great. Even though many will not get to use these, it shows what is important to company and the culture they want to build.
cons:
Good new talent is very difficult to attract.

There is a cultural disconnect between Chamapign and the rest of Yahoo. People who have never travelled to HQ don't even know. Older managers try gimmicks to keep their influence because they are aware of their technical shortcomings. Sadly likeability of managers is what is keeping them in place. Fiefdoms!

Managers do not give real feedback face to face because it makes them less likeable. Behind the doors though, they do not shy away from taking others down. I know first hand because I overheard a very interesting conversation through the porous conference room walls. There is a very well defined them Vs management Vs HQ thinking.

headline: Bait and Switch
pros: The maternity benefit was decent. Benefits and salary paid.  Up to sixteen weeks for women and eight weeks for men.
cons:
I was misled about the position during the recruiting and interview process.  The job description was completely inaccurate. Yahoo blatantly lied and lied by omission during the recruitment and interview process.

I was informed the hours of operation were M-F 6am-6pm and that I would have a set schedule.  During the recruiting/interview process Yahoo informed me the job would entail lots of detailed analyzing and helping clients to the full extent. I was informed that they would like me to learn some of the technical aspects of the job to start but with my background I will be promoted extremely fast. The recruiter even asked me to stop looking for employment after the interview. She said Yahoo really wanted me to join their team and asked me not to accept any other offers weeks prior to actually extending me the actual offer.   

Now fast forward to week 2 of training.  My entire training class gets bamboozled with the information that the hours of operation are actually 7 days per week 6am to 9pm and we would be required to work every holiday. 

Next, the duties of this position were not Customer Service duties. I was resetting passwords all day.  Management focused on how fast and how many calls you were taking rather than the content and quality of the calls. There were no details or analyzing.  Not to mention they didn’t want us helping customers to the full extent.  Example, one day I had an elderly lady crying to me on the phone because she had a sick family member oversees and she didn’t know how to respond to the email. Management wouldn’t let me help her?  I had to tell her to go to the help pages and figure it out herself.  

So as time goes by I discussed my concerns with management.  I ask about future plans and maybe posting out or being promoted.  I'm told, “We’re learning as we grow & we don’t really know what opportunities will be available in the future.”  Management clearly developed favorites and placed these favorite employees on special projects.  The individuals who spoke up about their concerns were clearly held back and treated unfairly.  Management made up the "rules" and policies as they went.  To me, this place and especially it's management team are unorganized and extremely unprofessional.  You'd be taking a gamble to accept a job as a Customer Service Agent.  If you're lucky enough to be one of management's favorites, you might be okay.  If not, you will be completely miserable.

headline: Its gonna be a terrific ride, buckle up!
pros: Lots of learning, loads of fun, awesome people, challenging work. Have a chance to impact millions of people with your work.
cons: Sometimes things are too much top down and the pace is so fast that you get very less time to think through and you end up executing at break neck speed and sometime end up doing things that are not as good as you want them to be.

headline: could have been better
pros: Good Perks and lately morale is good
cons: Curves can be used to get rid of people

headline: Need technical leadership
pros: Agree with some latest comments. Good talent, salary. Good going for now. Champaign is a small site so the general fear of something bad happening persists. With expansion projects things will get better.
cons: Layoffs have not been consistent with performance. Impacts morale. Surprised that some non-technical managers and directors continue to be around. Politics at top level is bad for long term success.

headline: Fun, Smart People, Great Office!
pros: Working in Yahoo! straight after my college year has given me lots of great knowledge. I met great mentors and dedicated colleagues. And the most important thing is the culture itself, purple and fun!
cons: The company receive lots of attention from press, negative and positive. It's very dynamic.

headline: Stuck Careers
pros:
Good salary, good work, good co-workers. Small community town. University town with some very decent food joints.

Marissa is cool and taking bold steps to move the needle. Presently she has tail winds beneath her wings. Good for general morale. Good for stock but real revenues are not up to mark. Fixing that will take time. Hope that the board will have patience this time.
cons:
Bad for career development good if you do not plan any progress. Bad if you only want to do your job good if you look nice to your manager. Bad managers who look like deer in headlights when technical questions come up good managers who lack courage to stand up to management. Bad if you raise Qs on management style, good if you can suck up to managers.

Some current employees will not fit in with evolving culture. Some are already trying to fake it till they make it.

Corn fields everywhere.

headline: Redundant people and roles
pros: In CU area Yahoo is one of the better option for software development. All at site enjoy work and $$s.
cons: Subtle level politics to keep favorite people (read "yes sir/madam") around by shuffling them around to different roles or teams. Good engineers who disagree have been let go using HR designed performance tools. Managers here define their own version of Yahoo way/culture to justify their deplorable actions.

headline: Technical Yahoo Senior
pros: Good salary. Stock has been doing good. Decent work with new technologies.Several great colleagues.
cons:
Not against Yahoo but in general working for Yahoo in Champaign is risky. If you loose your job where to go?

Senior managers are not technical. Senior engineers are the ones who are helping bring in work. There are pyramid building undercurrents in management.
