headline: All Smoke and Mirrors
pros: Free food (but isn't good), good health benefits..
cons: Terrible 401k first and foremost. For a company of this size, offering 25% on the dollar is miserable! Also, if you care about being a good worker and being recognized for your good work then don't bother working at Yahoo because it will not help you in the long run. Everything is determined by who the Directors and managers like regardless of work ethic or quality. The worst nepotism I have seen to date.

headline: Yahoo has left its best days behind
pros:
- New product launches are bootstrapped with millions of users, which is a rare luxury in this space. 
- The company still has some good talent remaining, although I am not sure why they are still around unless they are the recipients of RSUs that the CEO has given out to a lucky few. 
- Free food. Free shuttles. Company sponsored Mac Air and iPhone with unlimited minutes and data plan.
cons:
- The company, its products and technology are well past their prime. Their loyal users are aging and the brand is no longer relevant. Company's strategy to get back to relevance is still unclear and performance to date remains spotty.
- Marissa makes every single major product decision in the company - feature, functionality, pixel level design decisions, you name it. Nothing moves without her approval, which can take a while coming while teams burn rubber iterating through multiple options as they try to second guess her constantly shifting preferences.
- The internal work environment is stressful and fast moving in pockets while other teams still churn out buggy code once a quarter. It just depends on where you happen to work and how important your team is to Marissa Mayer
- Career advancement is limited as leadership is being brought (or rather bought) from Google and acquisitions

cons: I didn't want to relocate so my opportunities to changes positions/roles was limited.  I ended up being laid-off, as well as, the majority of the rest of my team in New York.  The company itself seems to be doing poorly so that may affect other peoples decisions to work for this company.

Tim Koogle was a top-rate and outstanding CEO: passionate, wise, visionary with second to none people-skills.  After him it was all downhill: a hollywood tycoon that cared mostly about the hundreds of millions he took, a foul mouthed lady with no vision, a resume liar, and now a narcissistic, somewhat dictatorial, knows it all type. headline: Exciting time to be at Yahoo
pros:
I joined before Marissa took charge so I had the privilege of seeing the change from old Yahoo to new Yahoo.  

Perks of old Yahoo: Free medical and dental coverage, casual attire, smart people (but jaded due to poor leadership), buzzing office environment, very competitive pay.

Additional perks after new Yahoo w/Marissa: Free food, free smart phones, strong leadership, smart people (now enthused about the great trajectory and changes that have been thoughtfully and efficiently executed), the leadership sets challenging goals, they are not just sales people they work very hard to fix issues that were previously ignored.  It of course takes time, but changes are absolutely happening. It's a great time to be at Yahoo.
cons:
We do not market.  There is a mentality about not bragging and I hate that people love to hate on yahoo because sometimes people love to see an old successful corporate giant fail and this is what happened.  

There is practically no PR team.  Before I joined Yahoo, I felt the same way as everyone else...it was an old giant trying to stay alive and losing to Google and FB.  After joining and after Marissa's complete overhaul of management, I learned we are top rank in a number of categories: Yahoo Sports is #1, Yahoo Finance is #1, Yahoo Mail is #2, Yahoo is #1 in traffic, Yahoo Weather App won "Apple's Design Award" beating out all other apps...these are just a few of the 2013 rankings.  

5 years ago, I'd want to work at Google, but you want to be somewhere that's gaining momentum and that's Yahoo.  We are an underdog, but we stay hungry and we have a strong leadership now.  There is so much to be excited for.

headline: New competitive culture contradicts "collaborative" rhetoric
pros: Yahoo! is full of extremely smart and dedicated employees.  It's a big enough company that you are sure to find some area to work in which you are interested.  Yahoo! offers good benefits.  It has an informal culture.  You are generally allowed to do the right thing.  If you're an absolute superstar you'll be well compensated.
cons:
A new way of evaluating employees has come along which, in my opinion, greatly detracts from the once collaborative culture.  On a quarterly basis all employees are stack-ranked against their colleagues in their respective departments.  They are then placed in a "bell curve" where each slot in the bell curve *must* be filled.  If you are in the bottom of that curve for three quarters in a row, you're fired.

This means that if you work in a high performing group you could wind up toward the bottom of the bell curve even though you do a good job.  This creates an incentive not to help coworkers, to avoid hiring superstars, and to generally not wish good things to happen for your colleagues.

cons: Still some tough decisions ahead..  Focusing on the high growth strategy. Some senior managers still need to go.  HRVP is qualified to lead biz dev but doesn't seem to get people stuff.  They ought to let her do biz dev by itself, bring in somebody like the guy at Google

headline: Awesome company, awesome people.
pros: Yahoo! is a great place to work. The work environment in Sydney especially is really laid back and the office location, while out of the way, is pretty cool. I work on interesting projects with some really talented people. Working hours are flexible and company events are always well organized and lots of fun.
cons: The company (up until recently) suffered from a serious lack of direction, the hiring process was also questionable. We're also forced to work with fairly old, entrenched technology rather than having the freedom to branch out and select the best tool for the job. Flexibility of working hours also swings both ways - sometimes you'll be putting in 60 hour weeks to get something over the line.

headline: Horrible review process -- ratings on a curve

headline: OK if you're an engineer, not great if you're in media
pros: Good benefits. Free food. Salaries are OK. Company-provided laptops, smartphones, and other equipment. Good opportunities for hardworking employees to learn and grow, at first, depending on what group you work for and who your supervisor is. Given that the CEO is an engineer and the focus of the company is on product rather than media, this is a better place to work if you're an engineer than if you're a content creator.
cons: Things have really changed over the last few years as we've gone through 3 different CEOs and are going in yet another new direction with the 4th. The new goals/performance review program is demoralizing, arbitrary, and used as a way for middle managers to play favorites. Supervisors and middle managers are not very good leaders, organizers, or managers, and they are under pressure to make their workers perform, so non-managment employees are cogs in a machine. Quantity of output is far more important to managers than quality. There is little to no communication on the media side (engineering may be different, since it's more collaborative in general), and that may be because coworkers are pitted against each other even if they're on the same team. Opportunities to advance are few and far between. HR is charged with managing people up and out, so don't bother turning to them for advice or help.

neophilia: Because it's new, it's better.

headline: I'm leaving soon for better pay.
pros:
Work: Learn a lot. Get to work with smart people. Solve complex problems at scale.
Perks: Free food, free iphone, free coffee bar, free vending machines, 16GB Retina with 512 GB SSD.
cons:
Even if you've contributed a tremendous amount, if you're not in the top 20% you get almost no salary increase. This has happened two years in a row.  

They also took away the 24 month ESPP plan and replaced it with a new 3 month one. That perk alone was worth $15k a year for me at the current stock price.

Also no RSUs after you join.  Unless you're special.

headline: Night and day improvement from one year ago. Still work to do, but great momentum now!
pros: Marissa has brought huge, positive changes to the company. The company is operating with a sense of vision and urgency that hasn't been seen since it's very early days. What used to take 18 months to get done is now taking less than six. Having everyone work in the office everyday again instead of seeing random people working from home on any given day and on every Friday has made a big difference. With everyone working together in the office 5 days a week instead of 3-4 days a week the company overall is noticeably more productive now. The free food and free smartphones are great, but by far the best change that has happened since Marissa took over is seeing the company focus back on making user-centric products, instead of developing products primarily to satisfy the demands coming from advertisers. The culture of transparency exhibited at each Friday's all-hands meetings led by Marissa has been a breath of fresh air.
cons: Despite all of the positive changes we've seen over the past year, there are still way, way too many managers. The company could eliminate 50% of the managers and there would still be too many managers.

headline: The good, the bad and the ugly
pros: Yahoo was a fun place to work provided you landed in the right business unit.  HQ is a  beautiful campus with free coffee drinks (often barristas will commit your favorite beverage to memory and start your drink order while you are waiting in line).  Many onsite amentieis include subsidized cafeteria food, dry cleaning, oil service, fitness classes, hair cuts, dental visits and of course educational training.
cons: Unfortunatley, Yahoo was one of the most complicated, politically matrixed organizations you can imagine.  There was lots of politicking and in-fighting between business units with many embittered longtime territorial veterans.  Be ready for turf wars!

headline: Marissa's getting rid of a lot of disfunction
pros:
Things were kind of stagnant under Bartz and Thompson. Marissa Meyer has really stepped up to make life better for the employees and get rid of soul-crushing disfunction. There's a lot more transparency and feedback mechanisms now. 

Internal training.

Can work on well recognized consumer brands.
cons:
It's still a large company. Even though Marissa's made a lot of changes there's still some work to be done. 

Shuttle schedules don't have a ton of options.

- Never ending the re-orgs and lay offs 
- Now it became a stack ranking company,top %25 gets some bonus,%50 gets nothing,bottom %25 is to be laid off 
- Managers offered bonus to manage out bottom %25 
- failed immigration department,thousands of desi people stuck on green card queues forever

headline: Good benefits, but way too much incompetent managers that stand in the way of innovation
pros:
* Top notch benefits
* Free hand-made, Starbucks-like coffee (and now even full food, I hear)
* Fun events for employees and family
* Well known brand
cons:
* Way too many (~7) levels of management
* Incompetent managers that are clueless about what their job really is
* Agile software development limited to isolated pockets
* Waterfall process causing constant fire drills
* Extreme turnover and low morale

headline: Solution looking for a problem
pros: The Technical staff is fantastic
cons: Watch out for the CEO

headline: One good place to work. Just don't expect it to be speedy.
pros: Friendly, smart people with lots to offer.
cons: Too slow to enact change.

headline: It was not a good experience at all
pros: Compensation is OK. Good free coffee. I
cons: Nobody knows what is going to happen next day. Products are not good. You do not feel proud while working at Yahoo!

headline: lost goal
pros: You job will be recognized by million people. Good culture, nice working environment.
cons: Many project did not work out finally, many efforts are wasted.

headline: Good culture
pros: Usually good salaries on hiring
cons: Difficult to get pay rises, promotions once you are in the job

headline: Nice and casual tech company, but somehow lack of challenge
pros: with huge legacy of tech and platforms, one can learn much from working here
cons: This company seems to have some trouble in finding out what should it be, and how could it bring value to users

headline: Worked as Software developer at Yahoo!
pros: Good benefits and compensation. Work was reasonable as a new hire freshly out of university. They have a good mentoring program and good tech talks to gain knowledge of other teams' work.
cons: Sometimes the teams lack direction. Work gets boring or monotonous after a while (depending on the team). It does not seem easy to switch teams.

headline: Great for Work/Life Balance, flexible working hours and great people to work with
pros: Great for Work/Life Balance, flexible working hours and great people to work with
cons: Uncertainty of Business outlook, Senior Management

headline: Great people work there
pros: Considering all the turmoil that Y! has been goring through in the last years, there are still very smart people working there.  It is a very collaborative environment where things can get done quickly without much bureaucracy.  The push to mobile first is the right direction and we work on the latest trends, and mobile customer needs
cons:
Lots of re-orgs and turn over (getting better)
Salaries should be more competitive (hopefully Marissa will fix this)

headline: blah
pros: good people trying to make changes (below the silly executive team)
cons:
poor board
poor senior leadership
lack of agreement and vision
married to 1999 and the past of email and portal

headline: Not for the types who need or thrive on stability in the workplace.
pros: In the past, movement within the company was relatively easy- people could explore other roles and teams to find better fits and as a means of retaining talent.
cons: That flexibility seems to be dwindling with more rigid process being instituted around transfers. And as it is in any large corporation, there is a lot of ambiguity in roles/responsibilities and constant change.

headline: Bad management and low morale
pros: Good work life balance and you get to work with some pretty smart people. You also get to work on some businesses that really have scale.
cons: Low employee morale, and depending on what group you are in, career advancement is difficult. Also, if you are on the product management side, most of your team will be distributed (engineering in India) so expect meetings at night.

headline: Not What It Used To Be!
pros: Open work environment, good benefits, great people to work with, access to perks if you're in Sunnyvale
cons: If you're in one of the satellite offices (non-Sunnyvale), you're basically just an appendage, not really remembered until something is truly damaged. Career pathing works for some teams, but not all. Management is not always aware of a problem until the problem is going nuclear, despite repeated attempts by employees to address issues with systems, other employees.  Other managers micromanage, which hinders progress, other don't manage at all, and are content to spend their days in their cubicles talking with favored coworkers.

headline: Challenges in Yahoo!
pros:
1.  Opportunities to work in many exciting new technology.  There's an incorrect perception that Y! is not innovating sufficiently; but this is an incorrect perception.  This perception is motivated by challenges in execution & ability to drive a new innovation to market.
2.  Great diversity.  Y! still has many opportunity to work with people from different parts of the world.
cons:
1.  Too many turf issues among middle management, especially among Dir & VP.  These wars result in inability to innovate & execute.
2.  Lack of accountability.  There's no penalty for failures, thus it has become a culture where result is not important anymore.
3.  Too perception driven.  Talents with capability but poor people skills, are never promoted, resulting in loss of valuable talents and a culture where employees care more about good people relationship than delivering user stunning innovations.

headline: Solving Big Data Problems at Yahoo!
pros: Yahoo! is one the best companies with respect to work culture and work - life balance. There are so many opportunities to innovate, so many challenging problems to work on.  There is an active support from managers and upper management to help people innovate, hack and put forth their ideas.  It has some of the most amazing people in its work force. There is an open culture where people can freely speak their mind.
cons: Losing Marketshare, constantly changing upper management.

headline: Fun & Great place to work
pros:
Product that you work on get used by millions of users, that's a nice satisfaction especially when you get positive feedback from users.
Great Work Culture
Get to work with good talent
cons: Nothing that doesn't exist in any other company of this size.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good workers and great career path
cons: Some lack of innovation from management

headline: Up and downs, too many product managers
pros: Massive traffic and influence on peoples lives
cons: Too many product managers, too much politics

headline: Some great people in the trenches, less so with VPs and above
pros: I've met some of the best people at Yahoo!, many very dedicated , smart, and just good people to be around.
cons: When I was there, it was unfortunately a very silo'd top-heavy organization that had zero / little accountability.  There were lots of political fights amongst different teams due to the matrix organizational structure.  I would a vast majority of projects that required cross-team collaboration either failed or was diluted so bad in the end, the resulting product/service ultimately failed the end user.

headline: Great experience
pros: Worked with really creative people, energetic company and atmosphere. I learned a lot and got great experience working with a variety of clients. This was my second job out of college (undergraduate), and it was great to have on my resume and gain the experience.
cons: Not a lot of promotional positions available in my area. Didn't have much work/life balance in my role.

headline: sr QE manager
pros: good working env, great people, great technology
cons: no vision, no consistent vision implemenation

headline: 2000 and continuing at Yahoo!
pros: Wonderful benefit, very nice people
cons: slow decision making, US centric

headline: Its kind of ok
pros: Quite a peaceful place to work at. You get some work life balance. The work place is well set up with some good facilities.
cons: Growth rate is very bad, don't be surprised if you are in the same place as when you joined even after 3 years.

headline: Yahoo! is a great place to work
pros: Now - direction is clearer, employees including management are held accountable.
cons: Previous years - lack of decision makers; slow to react.

headline: An opportunity full or promise that fell very short
pros: A lot of new people brought in to help save a sinking ship. Very positive vibe, but a "feeling" can only carry you so long.
cons: Too many people leading teams who had no business leading, or this was one of the few places they worked so they had no concept of the real world

headline: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros: Amazing People, Great Perks, and Encouraging Environment
cons: This isn't really a con but you do have to find your own way

headline: Graphic Designer
pros: Great people, decent pay, casual work environment, great opportunities, I loved working there.
cons: not really room to grow

headline: Amazing
pros: Good work, nice work culture and awesome perks
cons: It has been a good experience

headline: Great place to work
pros: You work with great people, office culture was very casual and fun. Overall, it's an amazing company to work for.
cons: Systems and processes are terribly slow and often down. Need better management - it's hard to respect a manager who does not know what you do day-to-day.

headline: Great working environment!
pros: Friendly people and many opportunities to progress within the company.
cons: Not a big intern group (or others my age), but everyone still made me feel welcome!

headline: SWE
pros: good pay hard work, lots of fun
cons: good pay hard work, lots of fun!

headline: Great perks, smart people, and awesome culture
pros: Hard-working, dedicated people here.  Everyone knows that, while we lead in many verticals, we fall behind in others.  Employees recognize that and genuinely want to work to better the company as a whole.
cons: Middle management is full of idiots who play favorites, yet somehow stay in C-staff's good graces.

headline: Good experience, lots of complex systems which can enhance learning
pros: Convenient location, good work hours, employees' needs are taken care of very well, above average pay, lots of excellent colleagues
cons: Attrition - lots of good employees are moving to other companies, your experience highly depends on which team one is working in, very gradual hikes & bonuses

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Smart People, lots of passion.  Great benefits.
cons: Corporate Issues, Upper Management Turnover,

headline: Lots of resources, little focus.  The People Magazine of Online Media
pros: Yahoo makes a lot of money in Internet media.  Great brand, global presence
cons: The company has no focus and is not a product, technology driven company.  Brand experts say the biggest problem with Yahoo is that you can't describe it in 5 or 10 words, let alone any single one word or concept, (like Search, Social Network, Online Auctions, etc..)  Therefore the Brand and the expectations related to it, are all over the place.   No compelling vision, all things to everyone therefore nothing great to anyone.  Behavioral Targeting and data-driven personalization technologies were the most interesting area at Yahoo.  The rest of the media properties are average at best.

headline: Good company to work for
pros:
1. Great work culture and loads of talent
2. Lot of untapped markets and unsolved challenges
3. The new board and the leadership team in incredible
cons: 1. Company has gone through some rough times

headline: Good place to work, getting better now.
pros: Good salaries, good food, good benefits, onsite gym, good work life balance, good technologies to learn and work with. Food is free now.
cons: Lot of people were leaving when I left. To many changes. Be ready to work in different teams and different projects all the time, priorities change very often.

headline: Things are a lot better since Marissa came onboard. Definitely one of the best places to work at so far.
pros:
Free food
Free phone
Up to date hardware
New focus on cutting edge
Work hard play hard
cons: Expected indirectly to check email / be ready for an emergency at any time of the day/week

headline: A lot of improvement in the last 6 months
pros:
- Opportunity to grow
 - Fast paced environment
 - Really smart people
cons:
- Constant change with very little stability
 - Lack of overall direction from management

headline: Used to be where greatness goes to die; but maybe Marissa Mayer can change that.
pros: Yahoo properties are visited by hundreds of millions of people every day. Compensation is good. Freebies abound.
cons: Yahoo lost almost all of its A players, thanks to managerial incompetence and territorialism. This eventually infected every part of the company. Winning ideas did not just fail to thrive, they were actively hunted down and killed. Marissa Mayer may be changing all that - finally.

headline: Office politics, nobody really works, managers only care themselves
pros: The pay is good, nobody really works, so work life balance is great.
cons: Office politics, nobody really works, managers only care themselves

headline: A mature company with a feel of a startup
pros: A bunch of exciting and bright people working there and relevant and challenging problems. I love the culture, environment and of course the perks.
cons: Personally I would prefer to live in san francisco, but as Yahoo is located in Sunnyvale it is a bit of a commute, nevertheless Yahoo provides free shuttle service which is nice.

headline: Amazing place and right time to join!!
pros: Perks, Work Life Balance and a Uber cool CEO
cons: Not noticed any so far. Probably havent been here long enough

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great perks, smart people, fun company!
cons: Outside view of company- the Media loves us.

headline: Underrated place to work
pros:
Finally, a product-oriented CEO who gets it!
Huge opportunity for impact. 
Good work/life balance.
Renewed management transparency.
cons:
SVPs and VPs could be stronger.
Prior issues with accountability
Lack of conviction/patience on new products.
Silicon Valley journalists love to make the company look bad.

headline: It's getting better!
pros: After 5 CEO's as in as many years, the outlook here at Yahoo! is looking much brighter since Marissa has come onboard.
cons: Free food? Free iphones? Free Macs? There isn't a CON I think of. Other than I wished these changes happened sooner (Marissa) before we lost so much good talent.

headline: great comapny
pros: threats its developers as rock stars
cons: middle management... as mostly everywhere.

headline: great
pros: talented, smart and fun people,
cons: nothing that could think of right now

headline: Great in the beginning then downhill...
pros: Great environment to work in.  Main campus was extremely comfortable.  Great flexibility and work-life balance.
cons: The people used to be the reason to work there.  Smart, engaged, excited and passionate.  Then everyone got lazy and morale was low...probably around the time Jerry & Dave decided not to sell to MSFT.

headline: Opened a Lot of Doors for Me, Company Had Some Struggles
pros: Fortune 500 Company, Network of Talented People, Recognizable Name/Global Brand, Fun Corporate Parties, Decent perks
cons: Management, Bureaucracy, Headquarters in a boring location

headline: The company totally lacked focus
pros: You will work with some of the best minds. There are lot of PostGrads and Phds around you. There is almost no politics. The biggest assets are its people. The company culture is pretty open. Employee welfare is taken care of. The knowledge sharing is enormous.
cons:
The company spends lot of money for people travelling to US from India. There are many frequent travellers. Nobody knows why they travel. Once an employee was sponsored for a trip to New Zealand for presenting her paper which she submitted during her PG days. That paper had nothing to with what Yahoo was doing. But she was sponsored by Yahoo to travel.
Some managers are not technical and that affects the appraisal. In one appraisal my manager said I am an expert in an area. But I was only good in that area and started getting lot of works in that area from that point of time. I got the feeling that one can easily manage to deceive the manager.

headline: Still trying find its way
pros: It is a great place to work with strong culture irrespective of the location one works in.  The people are pretty smart and easy to work with.
cons: The management direction until the now has not been that great.  It remains to be seen what will happen with the new CEO at the helm.  Many projects get canned after a lot of investment which is a loss both to the company and its people

headline: Good company
pros:
- good perks, benefits
- good culture, food
cons:
- no direction
-  very few profit making divisions

headline: Awesome work ethic
pros: great people, free food, morale is high, hopefully some innovation soon
cons: Pressure of proving, middle management, too much work

headline: Amazing change
pros: Marissa may very well be turning Yahoo! around. It is a new place in just a few months. Inspirational to see how a company's morale can indeed be changed by a skilled operator.
cons: There is still a good deal of reorganizations expected as a new leadership team is in place. Plus, there is always the possibility of layoffs until the course is fully corrected - but then again, there are rewards to be in early in a turnaround.

headline: Lots of smart people, friendly people, good work/life balance, but too many middle managers
pros: My group is awesome: friendly people, very supportive managers, great work/life balance and fun place to work, great perks (free food, free smart phones & laptop of your choice)
cons: Too many middle managers who unnecessary complicate and slow down the projects, regular lay-offs which demoralize employees

headline: fantastic , rich learning, rewarding
pros: good people, great products to work on
cons: slow decision making by top management

headline: good place to work - not great management
pros: people, perks, work life balance
cons: Senior management, lack of decision making, career prospects

headline: Bastards laid me off, but I still love them
pros: Nice people.  Good work environment
cons: What the hell is up with their leadership? The revolving door holds no optimistic outlook for me.  They let good people go just to cut costs.  Not good.

headline: Great company, lots of incredibly smart people
pros: Great industry vantage point and many large scale projects to work on
cons: Several management changes and mid-level employee jockeying

headline: Finally good upper management, but still poor middle management
pros: Marissa Mayer is doing great, most of the new exec team is well seasoned and doing good things.  Fantastic new tech choices. Overall, the company is on an upswing.
cons: Middle management is still terrible, the new QBR system only allows for top down review, and nothing is confidential.

headline: It was great while it lasted, but it couldn't last forever...
pros:
- Ice-cream and popcorn Fridays!  Treats at the front desk!
- Casual dress code
- Cool decor
- Opportunity to work with global teams (open door policy if you travel to another country that has a Y! office)
- Gumball machines for employees after 5 years of service (if you last that long)
- Good wages & benefits
- Discounted pop & snacks (used to be free)
- Lovely view of Queens Quay
- Employees seem to genuinely love their jobs (at least they did in my department)
- Free French lessons
- Opportunity to travel
- Great benefits/vacation/salary
cons:
- Coworkers are a bit cold (heads down, keep to themselves, no real team atmosphere)
- American HQ controls EVERYTHING, no Canadian autonomy
- Bad press haunts you wherever you go
- Focus on sales comes at the expense of everything and everyone else
- Some of senior management in Canada was truly terrible (out of touch, didn't understand what their direct reports and departments actually did, backstabbing, wouldn't stand up for employees)

headline: Its a good company to work for...just make sure you know your manager before you join
pros:
Lots of benefits and perks for working in Yahoo!
Coolest work culture I've ever worked in.
Being around intellectual people certainly helps
cons:
Some of the managers can be very unlike-Yahoo...specially the ones coming in lately.
Just make sure what you are getting into before you join and you should be fine.
Try to interact with few team members you will be working with and especially your manager before joining.

headline: Flexible hours but big turnover
pros: Flexible hours, could often work from home, generous benefits.
cons: Big turnoer every year, low morals, hard to get promotions.

headline: The fun place to work!
pros: Awesome work envirornment, great work culture, flexi time, good managers.
cons: CTC is high compared to Gross

headline: Lots of ups and downs
pros: Great new management, lots of accountability and things moving. People starting to feel excited to work on things and seeing new products released real fast.
cons: Still buckling under the dead weight carried over for the past 4-5 years. But management is doing everything it can to fix that.

headline: Financial analyst
pros: unbelievable people- loved it over there because of my coworkers.
cons: we would get beat up in the media, but on the inside, we were a family.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Very challanging work environment. Fantastic engineers to work with. I've personally learnt a lot for the talented group. Good work life balance.
cons: Not great senior leadership when I was working. The company tried to copy the innovations/ business models from the market leaders. I wish the senior leadership focused more on innovation.

headline: No complaints...
pros: Good people to work with. Scale if you are an engineer. Huge learning experience.
cons: Stock not moving up. Direction not clear.

headline: Massive scale, great culture, smart people  but too much red tape which makes it impossible to move fast.
pros:
Great learning environment.
Opportunities to work on products at a scale that most other companies do not have.
Great work/life balance.
Above average pay package, great benefits ( 401k matchingg )
cons:
Promotion and hiring inside Yahoo! is now more or less a question of knowing someone, not of being the best at your field. Hopefully, Marissa will address this.
Most work is maintenance while developers and engineers wait for the next round of management changes, starting something new is guaranteed to being shut down as soon as the next reorg happens.
Politicking, backstabbing, no directorial and above direction, constant goalpost changing, cronyism.

headline: Yahoo means Layoff
pros: It is a company where you can have good work life balance but only if you survive because in yahoo it's all about layoffs.
cons:
1-You'll be expecting next Layoffs all the time.
2-Too many managers, 50%
3-Too many changes in the name of strategy but no body is sure if they'll survive next layoff
4-Difficult to change team if  you really want to get there in fair way, if you have connects then it works.
5-You'll Old technology new stuff are never meant for yahoo.
6-It's a sinking ship. Layoffs are next.

headline: Internet giant not to be confused only as a search engine company
pros: Work culture, leadership, flexibility, benifits
cons: too many org changes, top management changes

headline: Overall good company, good benefits, room for improvement.
pros: Being part of such a large scale, global company -- with such well-known media properties -- is rewarding and great experience to have.
cons: Still a lot of bureaucracy to deal with, and some cross-departmental challenges.

headline: Great place to learn and get rewarded for results
pros:
Great place to learn: companies with this kind of scale can be counted on one hand.
High-performers are rewarded extremely well for the results they produce.
Marissa is changing the culture is so many positive ways.
cons: The mistakes of the past are still being paid for.  (That being said, Marissa is doing all the right things to fix that.)

headline: 5 CEOs in one year says something
pros: Good salaries. Used to be valued and have autonomy.
cons: Hugely under resourced. New regime is self-entitled, but lacking expertise.

headline: Amazing peers, frustrating organization
pros: Exciting work, and sense of pride throughout the company.  A strong sense of fun and innovation, and camaraderie among teams. Many opportunities to learn and advance.
cons: Constant reorganization - I had 10 managers in my last two years there. Often felt that senior management was detached from what we were doing, and there was no flexibility in, for example, HR policies for different kinds of teams. (E.g. The lowest performing person on a team of all-stars was put on performance management for low performers, even if his/her performance rating was in the top percentile across the organization.)

headline: Fantastic company - great people
pros: good brand value, large audience
cons:
Slow velocity
redundant layers of management
Many many Senior execs need significant introspection

headline: Nice place to be in  for easy goers

Work Life balace
a cool place to be in
You can learn a lot.
cons:
Politics ,
Lack of focus
None of the things that you work might go out.
Too much afraid to take risk
You might get easily type casted and you wont be allowed to explore more .

headline: Status Quo
pros: Affect millions of lives daily
cons: unclear direction overall for company

headline: Decent
pros:
- Good place to work
- Free food!
- Free phones
- Great learning experience
cons:
- Difficult to break the mould and do what you want always
- Its still evolving from the recent layoffs. Eventually, I hope it comes up stronger.

headline: One of the coolest places to work
pros: Awesome atmosphere, transparency, and the enormous size of the company. Seniors are very friendly and the work itself is awesome.
cons: Salary is not that good.

headline: great people, great products, no direction

people and culture
products - mail, sports, finance, homepage, news
brand recognition
cons:
declining share and lack of innovation
reactive rather than proactive regarding decisions
revolving door in upper management
lack of career growth/opportunity
need to get with the program on the mobile side (started to get lapped by competitors here just like they did in search and display)

headline: Good Place to work
pros:

cons:
No much negative points to mention, but a few:

headline: Lots of bad execs still at Yahoo

cons: No accountability, poor decision making, lack of product and technology understanding.

headline: They have fallen ... and they can't get up.
pros: Free coffee, above average salaries. Sunnyvale office has great amenities, from gym to (now) free food at URLs.
cons:
Politicking, backstabbing, no directorial and above direction, constant goalpost changing, cronyism.

Promotion and hiring inside Yahoo! is now more or less a question of knowing someone, not of being the best at your field. Most work is maintenance while developers and engineers wait for the next round of management changes, starting something new is guaranteed to being shut down as soon as the next reorg happens.

headline: People focused
pros: Benefits and work life balance
cons: Too many internal changes and career pathing was unstructured.

headline: What a mess!  Can you say YA-WHAT???
pros: Great working environment in terms of comfort and perks.  Most people are friendly and work diligently.
cons: No direction and culture is undefined.  Turnover is ridiculously high especially at the top.  How can you expect employees to be focused when the company has no direction.  Management in the department where I worked led through intimidation, dishonesty and fear.

headline: Its a great company to work for
pros:
some of the best minds in the industry
flexible work timings
opportunity to work on the cutting edge of technology

headline: Yahoo is a great place to work

headline: Great company, great people, constant moral issues due to lack of leadership

headline: Advertising solutions is stuck in 1999
pros: Yahoo has everything it needs, audience, smart talent, brand recognition

headline: Love working here.
pros: Love the culture and the people who works here.

headline: company has no direction
pros: free coffee, casual workplace, jeans all the time, "fun" internet company, nerf guns throughout the office
cons: no directions whatsoever, always chasing after google. Many many layoffs are disheartening to see. Bloated management stucture.

Great learning environment.
Opportunities to work on products at a scale that most other companies do not have.
Great work/life balance.
cons: Politics of a large company means it takes a long time to get things done.

pros: family friendly, recognized and respected brand name for users and as an employer, lots of opportunity

headline: Employee friendly company
pros: good culture, people are good. company is good.
cons: management is poor, disjoint. and burbank is not place to be in

headline: Great company, great people.
pros: Lots of opportunities and interesting projects to work on. Plenty of smart people to work with and learn from.
cons: Complicated management structure, lack of accountability when things go wrong or need fixing.

headline: Great company, bad compensation
pros: Good culture, good opportunity for growth.

headline: Overall its good company...........
pros: Career Opportunities and Benefits ,Strategy and values are good.
cons: Still senior management  need to work better

headline: Culture is awesome!
pros:
Good work culture
Work-Life Balance
Compesation is good
cons: What is the future of the company?

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great engineers, great culture - average perks. This company has great potential. Big management shakeup is required.
cons: bad management decisions took the company to nowhere. CEO's kept changing year over year, and company lost direction. sometimes it is called media company, sometimes it is called tech company.

headline: Work harder and get recognized
pros:
There are not many other company where you can experience scale this big. Everything you touch is global and has instant influence toward the world.
Perks & benefits are attractive, including recently started food.
cons:
Despite recent effort from the company, some good talents left looking for more exciting start ups or competitors.
Initial starting position often determines how far you can go in terms of salary if you stay as individual contributor.

headline: Good company
pros: Competitive pay and great benefits
cons: lots of bureaucracy and sometimes difficult to get things done

headline: One of the best company to work and very much an employee friendly company
pros:
Following could be the pros:

Employee Oriented Company
Good Career Growth
Nice facilities such as snacks(for free), subsided lunch, food card etc
cons: Sometimes mass firing happens which is little scary though the chances are not that much.

headline: lack of opportunities, both within the company and the industry
pros: good work-life balance; good benefits; friendly co-workers
cons: lack of opportunities; industry is too small and immature in Hong Kong

headline: Under new Management
pros:
Great benefits and pay
Delicious food
Interesting work
Enormous user base
Solid revenue stream
cons:
Lousy management
Fading relevance
Many subpar engineers
Little if any vision for future products
Terrible sales people who pollute every property with obnoxious ads

headline: good company to work for
pros: Great technology and good talent. Good learning experience for for fresh graduates and professionals.
cons: Have lost direction and low engagement level among employees. Define better product direction and accountability.

headline: Good company w/ great benefits
pros: Good culture, Lot of freebies, Good technology, great perks, laid back work environment.
cons: Unstable Management, A lot of bureaucracy that hinders your work, Some Sr IC like Chief Architect etc treat others very low and think they know the best.

headline: Depends on the team you get into
pros: Free food, good work life balance, good benefits and compensation
cons: Difficult to change teams. Some teams have pathetic infrastructure setup to work on and test in production with very old legacy code. You get stuck in such a team, it'll be difficult to change to a better team.

headline: the only way is up ...
pros: there is hope ... with the new CEO ... that changes are in the works to make Yahoo! a more exciting company to work at.  free food and iphones are nice ... but i really like the weekly friday meetings where we get to hear more about what is going on with the company.
cons: even after rounds and rounds of layoffs ... there are still too many managers.  it blows me away that good engineers (and managers) will be layed off ... and within a matter of weeks ... new reqs will go out for more managers.

headline: Confortable. Boring if you're not in Sunnyvale
pros:
- Good office
- Good products with scale
- Loads to learn
cons:
- Low impact opportunity
- Very political
- Slow

headline: Exciting and Joyful
pros: A good place to work at. Awesome co-works and work culture
cons: Nothing gets done her. Bureaucracy from managers

headline: A great company that has fallen down
pros: Great brand and technology, with great benefits
cons: Poor business model and very political management.

headline: Great exposure and opportunity for professional growth
pros:
* Incredibly supportive management
* High-level exposure with a lot of responsibility
* Innovative and fast moving environment
cons:
* Sometimes difficult to navigate through org efficiently 
* Bureaucracy can get in the way, but is changing

headline: Enjoyable, Fun Environments and colleague
pros:
flexible working hour
Fun environments
Good colleagues
cons: Need more self development program

headline: Loved my time at Yahoo.
pros: Wonderful group of people to work with and it was an exciting time to be with a fast-growing and dynamic company.  I wish them well.
cons: My job required a great deal of travel which grew to be a bit much after a few years.  Still, I had a great boss and a wonderful time working at Yahoo.

headline: Very high moments, but also some down times...
pros:
- Depending on the management you can have some incredible experiences and learn lots!
- Very good team members
- Good human resources management
- Home-office was totally accepted for the teams I worked with
- Good work structure
cons:
- Depending on the management, you won't be working with agile methodologies
- With distributed teams you'll have to learn to work in some strange timezones sometimes
- My management at a time wasn't good at all with people skills
- You'll see at least one lay-off at your time at the company

headline: Balanced Work life
pros: Very nice environment to work for. Nice Gym facilities. Free food.
cons: Middle leaders need to take more innovative ideas.

headline: software engineer QA
pros: Great talent , great work environment
cons: bad management bad execution no vision

headline: culture of consensus, not culture of innovation
pros:
- some very nice people
- flexible work hours
cons:
- entrenched culture of consensus that impedes innovation
- decision-making is slow as molasses
- risk-averse employees
- composition of employees who just want a cush job is growing

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Innovation is valued,  open culture, you can approach any one. lot of tech activities.  good perks, flexible timings
cons: hiring and firing is common,  climbing the corporate ladder is hard, bureaucracy,  too many meetings

headline: this company is cursed
pros: some great people, good compensation and benefits, good corporate culture, probably a lot of upside for the right management team
cons:
terrible results in recent years in terms of revenue, profits and stock price - its become embarrassing.
some really stupid people work there, lots of people just hanging out collecting a pay check

headline: Great place to work with too much politics
pros: Awesome place to work dealing with scale, and a fun culture.
cons: lots of politics and nepotism, the focal process and hacks are is rigged to promote the favorites.

headline: An enriching experience
pros: Good work, great opportunities, good work life balance.
cons: Too many management changes, no strategy.

headline: Extremely bureaucratic
pros: There are a great deal of talented people, still clinging on to hope and dear life here.
cons: The management team - director and above is a bunch of nincompoops when it comes to business delivery and performance! Most of them are corrupt and make money on the sly, and entire teams are built to serve these motives.

headline: Great changes happening!
pros: Great people. Great systems. Lots of scope for revenue generation.
cons: Lack of vision, everything is very scattered

headline: Great tech, terrible product leadership
pros: Yahoo has amazing technology and a lot of expertise. I learned a lot working at Yahoo from other really smart people. it's hard to find work at Yahoo scale in other places so this is one of the few companies you can really learn how to scale technology or teams.
cons: When I worked there a lot people had great product ideas that never made it into products. Rather than innovating or taking risks mostly the product managers seemed to want to copy companies that were taking risks.

headline: Great team, no consistency
pros:
+ great team
+ great product, and a brand to be proud working for
+ good perks
cons:
- At least in our office, to much power for sales
- no consistent strategy
- reorgs have no time to establish themselves

headline: a fun-filled ride
pros:
The people! Amazing technical talent.
The freedom to work in whichever way suits you. Flexible work hours. 
The benefits - the tech talks, the learning sessions, the food, the macbooks and the goodies
cons:
Frequent re-orgs, shuffles
Clueless upper management (circa 2009-10)
Bleeding technical talent due to above reasons. The amazing people I knew kept leaving Y! for greener pastures. They just needed a reason, a goal, some direction and they couldn't get that at Y!

headline: Great place to work
pros: Interesting projects and products to work on
cons: Focus is more on engineering than design and UX

headline: Comfortably working inside Yahoo's golden bubble, while Spain is in crisis
pros:
- Working for one of the biggest brands in the internet industry. 
- Good salary and bonuses;  especially when compared to national standards (Spain is equally valued to France and Germany).
- Plenty of ways to socialize and relax during working hours, increasing productivity.
- Great people!
- Office is very well-located.
- Room for special projects (MBOs).
- Management is very approachable and flexible when it comes to annual leave.
cons:
- Work itself can become pretty dull from time to time.
- No(t much) field/outside office experiences.
- Little to none (true) projects in the Barcelona Area regarding corporate social responsibility.
- Extremely process driven working culture, with from time to time absurd reporting requirements from management.
- Very slow innovation; mostly months of delay after changes in US have taken place.
- One size fits all mentality, doing Europe the American way. Doesn't work.
- Few career opportunities inside Barcelona Area; hardly any opportunities that are not directly about generating revenue.
- Unrealistic goal setting; although most achievable, some markets over-achieved by far whereas other nearly made it.

headline: Solid place to grow a career.
pros: The people are wonderful. The brand is very strong (everywhere but Silicon Valley) and there is a lot to work with. Also the work environment is really a lot of fun. People do work hard, but they also play hard. The facilities are nice. Great gym, free food, pretty flexible work environment. You'll develop a killer network of people who get jobs all over the tech world, and you'll have a great company on your resume.
cons: Yahoo! has been plagued with dysfunction and confusion at the management levels. This is a fact, but it's not a showstopper. If you are a leader, you are needed here. And if you are OK with some drama, then hang in for the ride. But it does get frustrating. You have to ignore the press, they are brutal against Yahoo!

headline: Not what it should be
pros: Flexible, allowing you to work when you want and write what you want.
cons: The so-called opportunities are getting fewer every day as they take more and more writing opportunities away and cause a loss of income for many of their senior full-time writers.

headline: what a fun company but it's in chaos
pros: great campus and great people
cons: too many to share here but most importantly the lack of direction the company is going

headline: Hard working, talented people failed by management
pros: free food, good benefits, decent pay
cons:
Senior managers have completely ruined this place
Lots of unmotivated, undervalued, overworked people
Constant fear of layoffs
Low morale - especially in marketing organization

headline: good
pros:
AWesome place........
best compensation....
free food...........
free transportation.................... no work load............flexible timing......best compant to kick start your career
cons:
Few Cons............
Management is not focussed........
key people losses.......
NOT much training....
Demarcation between iit people and non iit people at fresher level

headline: They buy companies and proceed to run them into the ground...
pros: Pretty good benefits. The company has a bunch of good products and content to offer.
cons:
If you are not in Sunnyvale, you are not treated very well.
Don't get bought by Yahoo! If you do, you probably won't have a job in 2 years.

headline: It was great while it was great
pros: The people are fantastic at Yahoo!
cons: Senior management is not cohesive in it's approach. Morale has suffered enormously over the last few years and products seem to languish before they're killed off.

headline: Welcome to a geek universe
pros: Some cutting edge work, a good library, Good perks and a decent work-life balance. Immense learning opportunities and excellent knowledge sharing
cons:
4 CEOs is less than a year
No clarity of approach or direction at the middle management level
Higher attrition rate - poaching by rivals

headline: Yahoo
pros: people are nice, work hours are flexible,
cons: too many CEO's, Too many management changes.

headline: A mixed bad: Great people, Lousy management
pros:
- Great people to work with
- At the cutting edge of technology
- Nice culture
cons:
- Terrible, highly political, overblown management
- No long term vision for the company. The only emphasis is to survive the next quarter
- Too many product managers

headline: Great place to work and grow!
pros: Excellent talent overall - many people to learn from and collaborate with.  Flexible working environment, and great work/life balance.  Ability to work virtually anywhere if necessary.  Pay and benefits are good/competitive with the industry.  Excellent brand equity to build up your experience and reputation.
cons: Company is so big that there is often a lot of red-tape that isn't there in a smaller company.  Organization can be a challenge.  Re-orgs have been common.

headline: QA Engineer or Technical Yahoo!
pros: Working culture and environment is good at Yahoo!
cons: Work is not recognized by management.

headline: yahoo! is cool place to work at
pros:
platform that the company has 
people are nice
cons:
re-org
my regional development is hard to implement

headline: awesome place to work
pros: Very Flexible , Good Salary and Perks
cons: Instability  , Public company so decisions too much biased to shareholders

headline: Place to grow and innovate
pros: Tons of really smart  in-house technology, that invokes innovation. An excellent place to grow if you want to - and with some very open, honest and nice people.
cons: Some parts of the company have grown to be bureaucratic; but I see that as yet another challenge, since the real world isn't all rosy after all.

headline: Culture and people are great in Yahoo!
pros:
Yahoo has some great and smart people in the company.  The culture is also great, and the company has a lot of perks. 

Since the new CEO, the company looks very promising.
cons:
Note, my comments are pre-Mayer times.  I feel that it is a very self-serve model.  It is your responsibility to advance your career.  It is your responsibility to file a patent.  

Also, I feel that there is too much in-house technology.  This is fine, if you provide sufficient engineer resource.  Otherwise, I believe this company needs to use more open-source.

Direction of the company is always changing, which is due to the many management changes.  We finally find a consistent direction with the new CEO.

headline: Good working culture, collaborative
pros: Smart colleagues, good working environment. Despite all the external drama, we kept our heads down and focused on shipping products. Free coffee was a bonus.
cons: Senior management decision making left a lot to be desired.  Kept changing direction. Lacked a will to win.

headline: New CEO, New Attitude
pros: Very smart group of people to work with. One of the world's largest user bases with huge product potential. Incredible new CEO with the vision to bring Y! back to life.
cons: Past failures (CEOs) still haunt Yahoo!... but Marissa is making fast work of retrofitting the company for the future. It will take time to turnaround.

headline: Cool place to stay as a start
pros: great and flexible culture, great people!
cons: inconsistent changes of company's direction from upper management (whole company, not specific to HK)

headline: overly bureaucratic and very top heavy org
pros:
smart technologists and product people still abound
new google ceo in 2012 may change culture
cons:
too many executives and no singular focus
too many touch points to get anything done

headline: Awesome!
pros:
1. Freedom
2. Great Work culture
3. No Boss Culture
cons:
1. Not growing much.
2. Wrong Strategies

headline: Trying To Innovate, But Too Many Legacy Yahoos Get In The Way
pros: Friendly coworkers and some really smart people trying to make a difference. Relaxed atmosphere, good work life balance.
cons: Too many legacy Yahoos in middle management who block positive change.  Culture of wait until a problem is escalated and out of control rather than working on prevention. Bad decisions based on favoritism.

headline: Excellent place to work...!!
pros: Really smart people, excellent facilities, very interesting projects and super charged environment
cons: There seems to be a lot of confusion and insecurity and this sometimes cripples the company

headline: Great place!
pros: Great environment and perks with great people. Great connections for an internship.
cons: None everything was great about the company as you work at your own pace

headline: Driven by politics ....
pros: Many nice people, they try to make employees happy with events and nice cafeteria.  Some latitude to contribute and work independently.
cons: Lots of managers who got there by playing games rather than on merit.  Fat management.   Product roadmaps were silo'd and people didn't work together or help each other.  Very disorganized.

headline: Company review
pros: good technology and people and work life balance
cons: instability in growth of the company

headline: Great technology, rudderless leadersip
pros:
You will work with some very smart and bright people.
Yahoo! experience especially on Hadoop, Pig etc is always a plus.
cons: Leadership is generally direction less.

headline: Yahoo Research Engineer
pros:
Laidback, Flexibile timings
Interesting Work
Great People to Work with
Good perks, lunch, transport
cons:
Interaction with product teams can be tedious
Yahoos brand value keeps fluctuating

headline: Lots of opportunities at Yahoo!
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of support.
cons: No restaurants near the Sunnyvale campus

headline: about yahoo
pros: decent benefit, including generous 401K match, health insurance, ESPP plan, less pressure,  relaxing working culture, several competitive services such as news, mail, sports
cons: too frequent CEO change, not stable, yearly layoff, not clear direction and strategy, no strong growth in business, good engineers leaving

headline: New to Yahoo?
pros: Endless career opportunities, high exposure to new products, fast-paced, high level of talent. Excellent work-life balance, lots of perks (work from home, cell paid for, stock options, flexible hours, excellent benefits, etc.).
cons: Lack of leadership at all levels. Lack of company vision, which trickles down into all facets of the company. 5 CEOs in the last year, and it is certainly felt throughout the company.

headline: Amazing culture, smart fun sales teams but low employee morale
pros:
culture
fun
smart sales reps
fun team outings
great on-going training opportunities
good sales materials 
great research and analytics available
cons:
Account Managers are overworked with too many accounts - Many AM's are both AC & AM
Too many company re-orgs with so many changes at upper level mgmt level
need to improve systems

headline: Better than you would expect
pros: Smart people, good benefits, interesting work
cons: Bad publicity, lack of coolness factor

headline: Company of endless reorgs, lay offs and CEOs
pros:
- Good Health Plan
- Free Lattes at least
- You learn scaleability by serving one of the most crowded user base after Google and Facebook
cons:
If you work in Yahoo, you should have nerves to handle never ending reorganizations,lay offs and CEO searches ever since 2008. Since then massive reorgs took place every other year: 2008,2010 and 2012, along with countless smaller scale reorgs went unnoticed by media.
After every reorgs and thousands laid off, then yahoo start hiring agressivelly just after couple of months to fill very same racks, so then quickly Yahoo ends up same headcount before reorg started. 

Note for the Immigrants: If you are an immigrant,the outlook is even worse: Yahoo cannot apply for green cards  since it's constantly laying off people. Even though you were lucky to get your labor application while things are quite,your application will be denied as soon as Yahoo does a new reorg, which always does!

CEOs and upper management have no clue about reorg,so they hire Boston Consultancy Group to tell them what to do. Do you imagine any of a hot internet companies like Facebook, Apple or Google ever go and ask management consultancies what to do?

Yahoo has simple answer to most difficult problems: ship it to India! If product X,Y,Z (fill in the blanks shopping,travel,messenger,search,advertising) cannot compete with Google,FB et al,always solution is to ship those products to India,expect the amazing talent of India thrive those products. Google,Apple and Facebook must be stupid not do it this way!

From compensation wise,RSUs and stock options are like joke, even principal engineers given RSUs worth of peanuts. Most engineers esp those joined pre 2010 have options drowned way under the water.

Paid lunch

headline: Yodel all the way
pros: amazing work culture, friendly environment
cons:
high attrition rate
inconsistent company strategy and roadmap

headline: Good Experience
pros:
--> Uses the latest and best of technologies
--> Great people around
--> Work-Life is well maintained.
cons:
--> Frequent Re-orgs. These re-orgs disturb the whole organization. Some of the re-orgs result in firing of the employees.
--> Scrapping of projects.

headline: Yahoo WAS a great company to work for... and THEN...
pros: As long as things are moving smoothly your schedule is fairly loose and you are free to come and go as you like.  The people I worked with were all in the same boat and always were supportive and eager to work with each other
cons: With the financial situation they are in it seems they are simply not interested in investing in good talent.  Also they went from having their fingers in too many pies to having their finger in just one pie hoping it would work but with no real back up for if/when it fails.

headline: Drives talent away
pros: Massive scale, good pay at high levels
cons: No idea how to develop the talent they have

headline: Good place to work !
pros: Good culture and friendly working env.
cons: Too many mid-layer managers not really help company move up !

headline: Only Engineering focussed ; not market focussed.
pros:
Very approachable senior management.
Nothing else I  can think of
cons:
Too many people managing the show, rather than adding any value at all.
Keeps building products with total disregard to what works does not work in the field
Nothing seems to be going right here.

headline: The dinosaur of the Internet that still kicks ass
pros:
- Opportunity to work with world-class technology & people
- Good & cooperative atmosphere among colleagues
- International environment without any prejudice against foreigners
- Good hardware equipment for all business units & easy software approvals
- Nice & modern office in the city center (Munich, Germany)
- Voucher coupons for lunch breaks (probably only in Germany)
- Cool social area for breaks including a PS3 running FIFA soccer, Foosball table, Tschibo coffee machines
- A lot of meeting rooms including two hi-end video conferencing setups  (Munich, Germany)
cons:
- Dishonest managers especially at the mid-level who think they will never need to work again after being promoted.
- Good tech people get promoted  to managers, get a 1-week manager-training and fail badly.
- Reward system not working. People getting promoted by threatening to leave. No transparency or career development.
- Yearly Focal performance review process is a mess where you colleagues can really hurt you. It's not used to develop people but to annoy people so much that they leave on their own.
- Frustrating re-orgs or unnecessary business unit naming changes
- Wrong people get hired as everyone is scared to lose the headcount approval and not many people apply. HR support is almost non existent.

headline: Great work culture
pros: Great Perks, large number of smart people
cons: Poor management and no definite set of goals or directions

headline: A lot of talented smart people but, sadly, no vision for the company at the senior levels.
pros:
Great people
Competitive salaries + benefits
Yahoo! has a lot of great products - it's a shame that there isn't a tighter/closer integration between them
cons:
Too many silos to work through
You spend more time in meetings than doing actual work (work frequently spills into evenings)
Lack of a consolidated vision for the company
Most people work hard, some are hiding in the gaps

headline: Fantastic family of talented and nice people. I'll always have purple blood flooding in my body and soul!
pros:
It's the perfect place to get knowledge not only about Internet and the business, from content to advertising, from search engine to mail, but also about personnal contribution and organisation. Yahoo! has an exceptionnal continous training program to develop personnal and functionnal skills.

Furthermore, the company has always been built upon a flat structure where accountability and responsability are equaly distributed. So you always have a priviligeous space to practice your personnal skills, test and learn. 

Finally, Y! is always looking for innovation, user experience and satisfaction. It clearly breathes 2.0 atmosphere.
cons:
Highly competitive market.
Difficult to maintain leadership over so many years.
Sometimes frustrating to struggle against Goliath.

headline: Great Company, talented people
pros: The culture and the people are great! Some of the most talented people I have ever had the pleasure of working with. Great perks, Yahoo! really values it's employees and treats them well.
cons: Too much uncertainty is negatively affecting the moral of employees, especially those that have been with the company for numerous years.

headline: Excellent and Satisfying work environment!
pros: One of the best things about working at Yahoo: Great People! There are a number of Excellent growth opportunities for those who are willing to work towards it!
cons: There are some politics but all at the higher level and don't normally affect the regular working employees.

headline: Great company .. wrong people in the wrong places
pros: Great environment, great products, great work process, great colleagues, very good salaries, great transportation very good benefits compared to other companies in Egypt
cons: Abroad management putting complete confidence in the wrong people in Egypt office. If you're not willing to put some serious ass kissing to people you can't even respect, you're screwed

headline: Best company ever
pros: Great and smart people to work with. Managers are mature and serious enough to give empowerment and trust to direct reports.
cons: Too much drama with the board and lack of stability at high level executive management .

headline: nice company to work for
pros:
great pay , great perks (onsite gym, onsite oil change, onsite massage .... these things can be invaluable: for example, with the gym you don't need to spend extra 30minutes driving to and from the gym everyday, so that prompts you to go to gym more, which promotes your health and overall happiness)

great technology (after 15 years of accumulation, it's got many secrets that outsiders don't know, what we had was already the best after trial and error). great people (at least before the large-scale attrition in recent years) so that you can learn a lot from them: to name a few: php inventor; the perl camel book author Randal Shwaltz;....
cons: some important strategic initiatives not pushing through. yes they are delivered, but the effects are not as great as wanted, so that they did not manage to turn the tide for the company's fate.

headline: Too many changes at the top in the last 5 years, but still got life.
pros: Despite the attrition, the engineers there are smart and passionate.  You have the opportunity to learn to solve scalability problems that few companies have to deal with.  The recent instability has created career opportunities for those who aggressively seek it.
cons: The revolving door at the executive level in the last 5 years have made it impossible to execute on any strategic plans, because every new CEO or C-Level executive will reorg and disrupt everything that was in motion.

headline: A leading tech-based media company facing lots of challenges with more and more confidence
pros:
People's spirit, employees ability to organize their time schedule and reward based on performance
Employees are very attached to the company and want it to win
Salaries and benefits are extremely competitive
Fantastic user base and brand name, although we need to reboost them 
Solid tech stack although it is being revamped and it can be old fashioned and not so efficient
Very good relationship with publishers, creating an ecosystem, not trying to destroy them
Agencies and advertisers expecting Yahoo! to succeed
Renewed leadership (Executive Management and Board of Directors) since April 2012 with clear vision and direction after years of back-and-forth and hesitations
cons:
Too many middle managers creating a complex organization to navigate
Executive Leadership is good but the level below is hugely criticized
Advertising systems are not competitive and we can expect changes soon
Publishing tools must be updated
Not easy to grow career
Brand popularity to be refreshed 
Lots of ground to cover in mobile publishing and advertising

headline: Very Employee friendly company
pros: Employee have a lot of free hand and good for them in terms of technology and problem solving.
cons: They stick a lot with the legacy systems and then don't maintain and grow with the existing technology and enhancements, So after sometime maintaining things becomes a primary work and people start loosing interest.

headline: Its a fun environment everybody is really nice and care for each other
pros: Great Salary, Awesome work environment, and kick ass benefits.
cons: Maybe some drainage of talent but we are ramping up and will be competitive very soon.

headline: Good projects to work on, top talents to work with.
pros: It's a good place for the engineer with more than 4 years' experience.
cons: But you cannot expect to work for more than 3 years here, you'll feel boring and no challenge once you get familiar with what you work on.

headline: Yahoo! Has taught me so much and excelled my career and knowledge.
pros: The people at Yahoo! are great!  the culture is fun, but hard working.
cons: The company is pretty unstable, but I hope that it does pick up.

headline: Yahoo review
pros:
Good company to work with..
Defined processes and work life balance
cons: presently going through a lot of changes

headline: A place to learn, to earn and to enjoy ;)
pros:
Will get challenge of any kind
Will get the opportunity to explore latest technologies
Will get the opportunity to work with world class talents
cons:
It is very uncertain for employees due to the regular lay-offs
There is no clear visibility of the future of the team, company

headline: Good Company
pros: Good company for you to learn a lot of cool and new technologies. Interesting problems to solve and good people to work with makes it very enjoyable.
cons: The constant churn in management and reorganizations impacts morale quite a bit and this causes a lot of good people to leave the company.

headline: got great technology but not knowing how to use it
pros:
Fun chill culture, great products, huge audience and great technology.
Lots of opportunities to interact with users and industry peers.
Clear career development paths.
Good benefit.
cons: Yahoo! started as a technology company and created a lot of great technologies that are the bests in the industry and got adopted by many other peers, however, leadership team does not know how to leverage these great technologies and pursuit media path ...

headline: had bittersweet experiences at yahoo!
pros: Great workplace for any fresher.
cons: Bad salary for people in the advertising and marketing teams

headline: Still viable and enjoyable to work at
pros: Good balance of personal / work life. With the recent layoffs, management is more sensitive to needs of the team, and is willing to make changes/adjustments necessary to prevent further departures. Even before layoffs, managers were very open and adaptable to the team.
cons: Food is terrible, leadership can be lacking at times.

headline: A company with no direction
pros: Yahoo hires top quality, the products and science is pretty good.
cons: The company has no direction and it is a dying company. The projects gets changes from india to sunnyvale so often. There is no sense of ownership. Some of the managers in yahoo so not good with people management.

headline: Love working here
pros:
Lots of smart colleagues to learn from
Wonderful laid back environment
Flexible Hours
Well rewarded for good performance
Foosball and pool tables
tasty cafetaria
cons:
Comparatively underpaid 
Dirty politics in some teams
Too much process
A little behind in adapting cutting edge analytics
Should provide a little training for engineers moving into data analysis

headline: Nice Place to work if you keep your head down
pros:
Great Benefits and culture.

Pro for some people:  this is one company that you can get rewarded and promoted for failed projects.
cons:
Poor Management - investing in products that have no ROI or revenue gain - lack of directions for the teams.   Decisions tend to be made more for personal gains than what is best for the company.

Too many academics and few think out of the box or care about the business of making money.  Lot's of inventions and ideas but no ROI.   It's sad to say this.... a billion dollar company that don't know how to develop software.  Lot's of talk about technology but none on monetize them.

Lots of failed projects - a failed project is one that does not work better than the previous versions, no addition ROI, users don't like it, and is not stable.

headline: Casual work culture with laid back environment

headline: Great workplace, but not so great company strategy
pros: With over 10,000 employees, you are bound to have a great network and wonderful people. Many of my peers are smart, dedicated, and fun. Depending on who you work with, the hours can be sane or insane.
cons: There is no unified and strong voice that makes sense and motivates the employees to drive the company. Leadership is frayed. Many of the employees parties have been eliminated in the last few years.

Great atmosphere and culture!

headline: Cool, informal, satisfying, but unorganized

Cool and Informal environment
